content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Before I say anything else, I'd like to point you towards this 7-minute review of Crypt of the NecroDancer on my channel. It condenses everything you need to know into what I hope is a very concise and informative video, so do give it a quick view if you're thinking of buying the game.


YouTube™ Video: 7-Minute Review :: Crypt of the NecroDancer! 

			Views: 149		

			Crypt of the NecroDancer Website: http://necrodancer.com/ ~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~.~ Welcome to OddyC's series of 7-minute reviews, where he attempts with all his might to condense everything he knows...		

For those to whom it appeals, rest assured that Crypt of the NecroDancer is something unique, beautiful and hilarious. I've never found such a good substitute for sleep in all my life. It's made me laugh many times since I bought it, and it's more than lived up to my expectations. It's a seriously great game that seems confident in its own abilities and rightly so.Studying and countering the attack patterns of each enemy you encounter is unbelievably rewarding. For most people, you'll start the game throwing yourself into a roomful of monsters and watching with fascination as you get utterly demolished. But the game relies on its own addictive nature to keep you playing, because the more you play, and the more you die, the more you learn how to stay alive for the next time.Rather than just repeating what I say in the video, I urge you to watch it and leave you with these remarks in summary:There is very little in this game that is not a reason to buy it. The gameplay, the variation, the creativity, the music - oh, god, the music - all of it is just astoundingly well-done.The game doesn't feel like it's in Early Access. Aside from the couple of features not yet programmed in, such as the full selection of characters to play as, everything is as polished as you'd hope the finished game would be.Despite dying more times than I care to count, I have yet to feel frustrated with the game. And I can get quite easily frustrated with games that kill me a lot. But with NecroDancer, I'm only ever frustrated with myself, for not quite moving fast enough, or panicking at a crucial moment. In a world of unfair gaming experiences, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a beacon of light that invites to you blame yourself, rather than the game!Yes, the game is challenging. Despite having played it long enough to know the attack patterns of most monsters in the game, the monsters frequently - shockingly often, in fact - get the better of me. It's not just a matter of learning the game. Thanks to the fast-paced rhythm aspect, it's instead a matter of calling upon your knowledge at a moment's notice, and staying calm even at the sight of a minotaur charging towards you, or a red dragon preparing to unleash fiery chaos upon you in the next half a second.The soundtrack is one of the best I've ever heard in a game.There is simply nothing to criticise - at least, nothing apart from the most minor issues, such as monsters occasionally getting in each other's ways and forcing each other to remain stationary until you kill them. But that rarely happens, and it's certainly nothing even close to a game-breaking issue - it's just a quirk of the game. And seeing as it's still in Early Access, I'm surprised that's the only one I can think of!Closing remarks: Crypt of the NecroDancer is amazing. One of the most flawless games I've ever played. If it appeals to you then buy it. You will not be disappointed, I guarantee it.

number of helpful: 19 of 23 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
Early Access Review
[early access - review]As an avid musician and part time gamer, Crypt of the NecroDancer was a "have to" buy for me. The idea of incorporating music as the mode for a metronomic gameplay system was intriguing. After finally getting this loaded up, I thought for sure that I had an advantage in this game given that I've honed my own internal metronome for nearly a quarter century and my gaming skills for nearly 3 decades but little did I know that this game puts a whole new meaning into the expression "beat down." To elaborate on that further frankly, I got beat down to the down beat.With NecroDancer, it takes more than just timing and gaming experience to survive, as this is a calculated, quick-witted, speed chess match and really is not a game you are going to get far in if you are distracted or not all in to it. The sound track is great and is one of the biggest reasons (for me anyways) to play this game. Being that I am a musician, my rig is setup with an audio controller and studio monitors, so that I can pump out some decibels and at high volumes this game sounds even better! If you don't have a decent sound setup, a good pair of headphones is crucial. The sound track has a wide range musical styles from the trancey-technoish electronic, chillin mellow reggae-ish, flowing hip hop beats, beatnik jazzy swing, to the grinding heavy metal; all of which is synthesized and composed sequencing. This is understandable considering the game play is tempo driven, though from a musicians point of view, some music wasn't meant to be synthesized and even though musically it is written well, the metal doesn't feel right. A minor gripe. Regardless, every style has a lot of energy with a beat that really delivers the tempo when playing. My last gripe, though petty, I think a little more could be done with the sound effects during gameplay to incorporate them into the music a little cleaner, being that attacks and movement must be done on beat. It is still early access, so we'll see.   There are 2 things that bothered me about this game. One I can look past and most people do not mind the uncontemporized 8-bit graphics but I'm hoping there is a little bit more updating to set it aside from the rest (again, early access). My other issue I had was perplexing and that was the controls. After calibrating to compensate for the latencies, I went to the options to personalize my joystick controls. The devs offer a lot of options in this screen, which is nice, but they have controls labeled 'Combo: Up + Down', 'Combo: Left + Right', 'Combo: Up + left', etc... that you assign to a button. What? This was confusing at first. Well, turns out that these are for using items and using some menu functions. It gives the controls an additional method by using both the movement combinations as well as assigning it to a button. This gives a huge advantage for using a keyboard over a joystick. I also found that when using the keyboard, it was much easier to keep the timing, as though it felt more "instrumenty' than the joystick. My last gripe about the controls is that they are not actually "full controller supported" as stated on the store page. Stick 2 on my 360 controller could not be assigned controls during setup. Oh well, I like the keyboard more for this game anyways! The gameplay is simple. Using the directionals, you move and attack on beat. The enemies will too, though they all do not move the same manner or count and as I mentioned earlier, this really makes it more of a speed chess match. If you are in the wrong square, miss a beat, or move incorrectly, it could mean game over. This adds a whole new dimension of difficult and for those of you that cannot keep a beat there are additional modes, like turn based, so even the musically challenged can enjoy this game. There are a lot of power ups and items available, though at the moment doesn't exactly feel "rouge-like" just yet but I'm sure that'll change. There are also a multitude of in game mutations that ramp the difficulty level up significantly. Even without them, this game is hard, which should appeal to anyone who likes a challenge in gaming.*Also note: do not expect a huge amount of content out of the box, at this stage in early access there are few levels offered in Crypt of the NecroDancer. At the moment 4 levels consisting of 3 stages and a boss level. (I'll update this review as the developers do... can't get enough of this game) There is also a daily challenge, though I'm not sure why these resources are not allocated to coding, sprites, music, sound, etc... OverviewGameplay: Music Driven Rogue-Like.
Graphics: 8-bit. They are okay but would like to see them a little more contemporized.
Sound: Sound Track is Phenomenal (by gaming standards)! Sound effects are good but again, I'd like to hear them mixed in on tempo with the music, making them one and the same.
Controls: Great with a keyboard. Though, as of now it’s a little disappointing with a controller but still decent. 
Replayability: Yes. The addition of seeding gives this game a ton of potential. 
Overall: 8/10 – Though it is nothing to scoff at, once new features, updates, and fixes are implemented; I'm sure this rating will be much higher in Crypt of the NecroDancer's fully released state. 
The element of music and gameplay make this a great game and one that I truly enjoy. I recommend this to everyone and is a must buy for anyone who likes musically driven games.

Early Access Review
								NecroDancer is an instant classic, and one of few games where Early Access is ABSOLUTELY worth it. The game is addicting and pretty much complete, and the updates keep coming hard and fast, bringing more and more variety and fun to the table.The gameplay feels complete, looks, sounds and feels great and is immediately addicting. Replayability is available aplenty via custom music, roguelike-characteristic difficulty, replays, leaderboards (for gold score and speedrun time, respectively), unlockables and a hardcore mode with optional seeds input.The only missing feature is a zone; there's 3 zones à 3 levels right now, which are plenty to bite your nails out already. Other than that, all that's left to be added are simply optional bonuses; more variety and options, of which there already exist a lot. This is legitimately the only Early Access game I can recommend and say "get this right now". The amazing music won't let you go for a while, you'll find yourself doing other stuff to the NecroDancer beat... that's how addictive it is.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												This game is exactly what it says it is, a mash between the roguelike genre and rhythm games. But it is more than that. The first guideline is fairness : It is one of the only fair roguelikes. When you die, you will be able to watch the replay of your last few moves so you can understand what killed you and why. I have played this game for almost 100 hours, and never have I felt like my death was unfair. It was always my own fault, so I couldn't blame the game for anything. And that takes the frustration out of the experience. The second one is mastery : while you will have to learn a few patterns and item effects, they are pretty straightforward, and the game has a training room where you can learn at your own pace everything you want to learn. But the real difficulty comes in when you have to adapt to those patterns, dance with the enemies without making a mistake, and when there are multiple enemies, you'll have to keep track of what each of them is doing and adapt to the situation. This would be easy to do if it wasn't for the time restriction : you can't stay here and think, you have to keep moving to the beat. That is why you need mastery : the ability to master the patterns to a point where they become second nature, for you won't have time to think, only react.Put these two wors together, and you get Crypt of the Necrodancer : difficult but fair.You won't need luck or knowledge, you won't need any wiki to remember what every item does, the only thing you'll need is yourself, your brain, your reflexes, your skill. Are you up to the task ? Can you manage to defeat the Necrodancer and escape from the Crypt ? You are the ony one able to answer that question.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Below you'll find both a video and written impression


YouTube™ Video: Crypt of the Necrodancer: Early Impressions 

			Views: 432		

			Crypt of the Necrodancer: Early Impressions Crypt of the Necrodancer video created on version: v.0.370 Alpha Crypt of the Necrodancer genre blends rhythm based mechanics with rogue like/lite much...		

Crypt of the Necrodancer genre blends rhythm based mechanics with rogue like/lite much more successfully than Limp Bitzkit's attempt at blending rap and rock. Think traditional turn based rogue like/lites but each beat of the game's music is it's own turn. It's a simple, but very well executed catch that adds a lot of flavor to the game. The pixel art is gorgeous, with detailed textures and animations, the up beat electronic music, though seemingly off themed from the game's more fantastical setting, is catchy and works well with the designed mechanics. If you're not a fan of the music (because you are probably insane), you can always play your own music which the game will build stages out of. Crypt of the Necrodancer also comes with a variety of different modes and features for you to explore, including hardcore, training, and a pile of items and upgrades to unlock. Even as an early access (or perhaps, especially because), it feels very complete. Further improvements from this point will feel more like free DLC than the game subsidizing for missing content. Overall, Crypt of the Nectrodancer is a very unique take on the rogue like/lite genre. It executes it's genre blending perfectly, offering easy to understand, but challenging mechanics, catering to the hardcore and beginners.Pros:- Excellent music- Great pixel art- Unique genre blending- Lots of features and promotes replayCons:- Those unfamiliar with rogue-like/lites could find this repetitive- Custom music could use some tweaking

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of the most unique games I have played in a long time.  As Cadence, you move through dungeons, dig through walls, use spells and items, attack enemies and bosses, all while staying in tune with the music.  You can not do these things if you do not match the music.  The longer you go without messing up, the greater the gold multiplier you have.  Which means more gold to buy an awesome variety of weapons, armor, and other items from the shopkeeper.  You can also find items hidden behind walls and in chests.  There are plenty of different maps, different songs, and different game modes, along with a bunch other special things you will unlock in the game.  There is also a large enemy variety, and each one behaves very differently from the next.  If you die, you are dead.  You start over completely.  This game is awesome, and definitely worth every penny."They told me I was too young.  They told me I needed more training.  I told them to drop dead.  How ironic...I don't know how I survived that fall.  Something strange must have happened.  My pulse is beating like a drum, but my blood is running cold.  I'm not sure what's going on but I came here with a question, and I'm gonna find the answer if it kills me." -Cadence

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												[Minor spoilers about end game gameplay].I had been in the Crypt for almost 20 hours before I first encountered the Necrodancer.I'd like to talk of that experience:The identity of the Dead Ringer revealed, I felt a pang of confusion, only to hear him guide me, and then to realize I had to juggle two heroes terrified me. How many runs had I failed this far? And another boss after what already seemed like an impossible ordeal. It only took me a few moments to realize the new mechanic I had to juggle in the last fight, and it was an amazing surprise which immediately filled the dancer floor with new energy. I spent the first minute of the encounter with the Necrodancer keeping my heroes side by side, getting used to the beat. The easy beginning really affords those fighting Necrodancer for the first time the time they need to get ready. And then, one by one I begin aligning my heroes, triggering bombs to the stage--not too difficult. When the Necrodancer took to the dance floor, indeed was my heart beating at the  120bpm step, in sync with the Necrodancer himself.  I begrudgingly set aside my Obsidian Crossbow and equipped the Golden Lute, determined to do this right. At first, I ran from his reanimated fiends and explosive spells, trying to realign myself and regroup with my ally, but as soon as I understood his rhythm I slided in for a hit. The Necrodancer skips away only losing a single heart from my note, summoning more monsters between us.Black Knights began to flank me on all sides and it's a challenge to keep them off with my ally's Flail. At one point I realize the Golden Lute can only sing its music if Cadence has a empty tile to move to, so being surrounded by shield bearing skeletons on two sides and a wall and ally covering the other two, I struggle to make any movements at all, all while rapidly losing health. For an instant I fear the worst, but in the next beat does my ally bash his Flail fowards, knocking back one skeleton--I immediately pounce on the next beat, allowing my Lute to sound the minions to dust. The fight continues with me piercing again and again with my Lute, bringing the Necrodancer to a third of his health, while monsters continue to scratch my ally and I. In the fight I've lost four of my nine hearts, leaving both my ally and I at one and a half hearts left, and as I continue to hit the Necrodancer do increasingly powerful monsters seem to appear.Eventually, there are too many skeletons in erratic formations I can't easily line up to attack, their pursuit herding me to one side of the dance floor where an Ogre has just joined. I've died many times to Ogres in the fourth zone, but I know the brute, slow, can be defeated if I merely kite around it. However, I worry that in the process, the new ally by my side would then get smashed in the ensuing blow. I move in, hitting him again and again as I circle to his back.It was at that time, checking the hearts of my ally and I, going over the directional combinations to use bombs, switching to my holstered weapon or beating my war drum, as well as predicting the path of the many dancers of the Necrodancer did I make my fatal error. My attention split, I panic and move one tile away from the Ogre, immediately attracting his singularly directed club. My obsidian armor, then powered down and thin as paper from the onslaught of reanimations is cleaved in two, Cadence immediately perishing under the mighty blow. I will now begin talking about my opinion of the game:I spent 20 hours trying to get farther and farther than before.  Being able to dance with the Necrodancer was an incredible experience, despite dying, my body is still flowing with music high. Please try this game. There are very smart design choices evident throughout every aspect. The music, the level design, the enemies and items all progress so well. Timing each act to the length of a song, having enemies which all have simple but broad ranges of dance moves to overcome make them easy to approach but brilliantly challenging in hoards. You feel extremely rewarded for your experienced-earned dexterity the roguelike demands--the game is a fantastic challenge that's never too easy.   A great example is in certain circumstances (secret vendors and trapdoors) do you find yourself in an incredibly confined space with two minibossess and two small minions. The first time you see this your fear and greenness lead to your immediate demise, but after enough of dancing do you begin to, not only feel comfortable with these, but even actively seek them out for the item and gold reward from defeating them.   Once you can beat bosses, your greed begins to demand you defeat them without a single misstep, for the glorious Flawless Victory that rewards your ego as well as giving you an additional chest to bolster your hero. I thought being an indie game this would be a quick fun change of pace but it's so much more. I've only played twenty hours but I don't intend to stop any time soon. It's a game I would recommend to any friend who comes over, it's a game I would play when I have a short break or if I have a few hours. Sometimes it can be tough if you keep dying but the rewards essentially beg you to succeed.  I keep coming back for more Crypt of the Necrodancer!

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												I waited way too long to pick this one up. On one hand, I love rhythm games and was huge into Rock Band's drums back in the day. On the other hand, roguelikes are a bit overdone at this point and even a game with a huge amount of depth can be a turnoff when you play for 30 hours and only see less than 10% of the content, often because RNGesus hates you.I'm going to assume that you enjoy rhythm games if you're considering this one, Crypt of the NecroDancer does three things that roguelikes in general can learn from.The first is that everything is predictable, even when it's random. The majority of enemies follow a strict algorithmic pattern and the better you are at discerning these patterns and reacting to them quickly, the better you will do. Red Bats' random movements are countered by paying attention to what tiles they are on and what tiles you're on. Bosses have reliable strategies that allow them to be taken out with zero damage suffered, even the ones like Death Metal who have aspects of randomness included. Item drops are random, but this matters less as you unlock higher and higher difficulties that are designed to deprive you of gear and demand perfection.The second thing is that the majority of things are unlocked within a relatively short span of play for a roguelike, about 10 hours. Furthermore, competitive modes such as the Daily Challenge and All Zones/Seeded put everyone on a completely level playing field from the start. No system of unlocks that favors 300+ hour players over the new installs, which is frankly a very good thing. It's not just even popular roguelikes, competitive has become a joke across a wide array of genres due to the industry's addiction to progression systems. It's used as an artificial longevity tactic and even though the store page isn't all 100+ hour reviewers, you know those reviewers' time wasn't wasted by grinding either. This trait gives Crypt of the Necrodancer more of an arcade feel, which is appropriate as all zone runs generally last under an hour. (with the world record seeded speedrun being under 2 minutes)The last kudos goes to the fact that you can enable an option (off by default) to make item names/descriptions visible. I love this feature -- a certain other mega-popular roguelike lacks this feature and as a result it feels like a Mediawiki simulator, constantly disrupting the flow of play. There are a few items without descriptions but these are clearly cursed or "double-edged sword" type items, so that's fine.Although not tagged as such, it's worth mentioning that this game is very difficult. You have a lot more information to process than other rhythm games, especially as enemies start becoming more numerous. The difficulty spikes drastically once you unlock the final story mode character, who can only survive two hits or missed beats. Needless to say the YouTube rendition of all the cutscenes is very popular as a result, but just looking at the global achievement stats (and the lack of achievers) will tell you that this game isn't messing around. This isn't a huge problem due to customization options being robust enough to suit any difficulty level, though the one thing they got wrong was hiding the "double time" character behind the "gold one-shots you" character. It's probably justifiable by difficulty scaling, but it's not all that justifiable by locking what many would consider to be the "fun hard" character behind "tedious hard" one. But this is a small nitpick honestly.There are plenty of ways to customize the game. The options menu supports a wide range of preferences, always important for letting people feel "in the zone" in a rhythm game. There's a modding system, though I haven't used it much yet. The song importer is pretty good, and it accurately timed songs that I ripped from my CD's as WMA and then turned into OGG with Audacity. (only mp3 and ogg are supported) Digital purchases will probably fare just as well. PC rips will require manual timing, which works well enough. It also gives you options to play songs at half or double time, which you might want with higher BPM genres like Metal. Necrodancer seems to have a range for where BPM should be, and halves any that exceed that range -- so you'll want to either play your Dragonforce CD as Bolt, or manually set it to 2x speed.One final positive to mention, and also advice for new players -- it's playable with a dance pad, but you probably need to be superhuman to have a chance in the more difficult modes. Keyboard is also supported, and if you're playing on keyboard, remap the spell/item/misc keys right away and disable the default combos. This seems to make the input more responsive...or maybe I expected it to and it just seems more responsive. It's also good to get used to your own layout right away as the inprecision of two key input will eventually end up biting you the more the game demands perfection.All in all, this is an amazing game...and I'll be there on day 1 if an expansion or sequel comes out.

content:
Posted: January 2
												I was initially turned off by this game because I couldn't keep to the beat and kept dying to the minibosses, but after initially refunding it I picked it up again in the Halloween sale and I'm loving it.Despite the obvious differences in gameplay and graphics, I find myself comparing it favourably to Dark Souls. It's hard but fair - like every roguelike, you'll be dying a lot, but it's usually due to your own mistakes. Every enemy has a pattern (except bats; screw them), and once you learn it you can breeze past enemies that used to mean a speedy end to your run.There's a huge variety of enemies which require varied tactics to beat. The equipment is similarly varied; weapons range from the basic dagger to longswords, whips, crossbows and even the coveted blunderbuss. Magic rings, spells, boots, helmets, torches and armour (randomly dropped from chests and stocked in shops) also contribute to making every run feel unique, as you'd expect from a roguelike. There's a great deal of progression, too - you amass diamonds from repeated runs of levels which allow you to add more types of gear to the item pool. You can also play as a bunch of different characters which are unlocked throughout the game. Each brings a new way to play, although I find the game hard enough without dying instantly when I miss a beat (as happens when you're playing Aria or Coda). I would have liked to see more characters like Eli, who shakes up the gameplay by only being able to use bombs as weapons, rather than insane challenge-run characters that only a tiny percentage of players will even complete a run with.The soundtrack is phenomenal. Made by Danny Baranowsky, of Super Meat Boy and original Binding of Isaac fame, it's undeniably catchy and covers a wide range of genres. Unlike most games, it's actually a significant part of gameplay - the tempo of the music determines how fast you have to move, and one particular boss (King Conga) switches things up by missing every eighth beat.The story is fairly bare-bones - you get a cutscene when you finish one of the four zones with Cadence, Melody and Aria, and that's about it. I don't mind, really - this game is all about the excellent gameplay.I'd highly recommend this game if you enjoy rhythm games or dungeon-crawling roguelikes.

number of helpful: 15 of 18 people (83%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
 Summary: My 4th best game of 2015, and for good reason. One of the best mashups of genres that I've seen over the last several years, Crypt of the Necrodancer has that addictive quality that will keep you playing the game over and over again, and enjoying every moment of it.  Strong internal game design revolving around the movement, not the rhythm, and yet the rhythm enhances every moment of gameplay. Dancing in between enemies and getting in the first hit while protecting your precious little health does keep you super aware of your surroundings, and enemy pattern movements force you to think outside the box, digging into the environment to escape or just give yourself a breather. A great solid soundtrack that's designed with the gameplay in mind, and yet importing songs works rather nicely too in a majority of cases. Look, I could go on and on about Crypt of the Necrodancer's design, it's smart gameplay, it's hours of re-playability, but I'm just going to get down to the chase. Everyone who even remotely likes roguelike/roguelite elements will have a fantastic time with this game, and those looking for something out of the rhythm genre will find something fresh and new here. Well worth the full price of admission, no questions asked.    Video Review: 


YouTube™ Video: Heart of the Game: Crypt of the Necrodancer 

			Views: 247		

			Heart of the Game presents a games strength or weaknesses in a CCG like format. The starting inspiration for the series is Crypt of the Necrodancer, a rougelike/roguelite rhythm game that shows how...		

 Lists: +: Strong base gameplay that doesn't need the rhythm to succeed, because the base roguelike gameplay works on so many levels. And yet the rhythm enhances things on multiple levels, forcing quick decisions on the part of the player, forcing mistakes for those not ready for what's to come..  Great variety in weapons and characters, forcing different play styles that still all work on basically the same principles, but you may not realize it. The different characters in particular add some clever elements into the game, forcing you to think about things that you may not have before, like using the walls wisely or avoiding enemies rather then confronting them.  Enemy movement patterns are very smartly done, force you to change up your expectations and react to the situation at hand.  Great soundtrack that is designed for the beat to be consistent, so players get adjusted to the game, but hits a variety of genres, and the remixes are something you'll want to put in your collection. Never get old, and I STILL wanna get up and dance at the opening theme. This coming from a person who has two left feet. Visuals work surprisingly, and you never get lost in the smart selection of color scheme versus background. Everything is clear and up front.  After first hating it, like the final duel they set up, as it takes the gameplay more to a completely new place I wasn't expecting. In fact, would love to see a mode entirely centered around it.  Importing songs works in a lot more cases then I thought it would. Good open source library used to detect the base beat, and is able to detect even if those really odd cases. Some good mods out there, even if half of them are only visual. I personally recommend the Mega Man mod. Because ITS THE GOD DAMN MEGA MAN.-: Minor bugs here and there. For example, it'll exit on the second time you go into import song after playing a round with the new one, and can't handle accented letters.In terms of importing songs, The dog song from undertale doesn't work well with it =(. Honestly, I'd love some DLC just for the fact that well, I just want more. Granted, what's there works, but I still love it to this day. Honestly I'm literally coming up with flaws out of nothing. That's how fun this game is. That it took me this long to do a steam review on this game.

You can upgrade it the sword to a broadsword, spear, longsword, whip, and even a bow and arrow which all have glass, obsidian, blood, gold, platinum, etc... variations. Same for the shovel.You will also get Headpieces, Shoes, Armor, Potions, Maps, Scrolls, Food, Magic, and other stuff.One complaint that i have with this game is that it recycles the enemies way too much. Want a example?"Oh look, it's a green smile""Wow, it's a blue slime""Watch out, it's a yellow slime!""Please don't kill me mr. lava slime!""This is getting repetitive, right ice slime?"And then there are white skeleton, white skeleton with shield, white skeleton with horse, yellow skeleton, yellow skeleton with shield, etc...They are all different but they're pretty much the same thing with different colors/health.8.5/10

content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: I've only played the alpha build, so some of this may be subject to change.Crypt of the NecroDancer is an incredibly fun take on the Rogue-like genre.At its core, NecroDancer follows the same tenants that most Rogue-likes do. You enter a procedurally generated dungeon with basic equipment and attempt to reach the exit. Along the way you defeat enemies, avoid traps, buy items, and make generally strategic decisions before you take each step.NecroDancer throws an unusual wrench in the works, however. You're no longer allowed to move or attack unless you do so in sync with the rhythm of the current song. Doing well increases the number of coins you get from enemies, and missing a beat resets this bonus. Additionally, if you miss, the enemies essentially get a free turn. No longer can you sit and ponder your next move, you have to keep moving with the song. Additionally, enemies follow a generally fixed pattern and will only manage to deal damage to you if you neglect to keep this pattern in mind.The result is a highly skill-based Rogue-like where decisions need to be made quickly, and mistakes are punished harshly. The game is definitely balanced around this mantra, as it's very possible to win without ever purchasing an upgrade for your character. In order to cater to a variety of player-types, the game includes both a "standard" mode and a "hardcore" mode. In the standard mode you're able to purchase upgrades that permanently boost your character, and there are essentially checkpoints that allow you to start from later levels. In contrast, "hardcore" puts you on the first floor with no upgrades and requires you to clear the game in one go. There are time and score leaderboards for hardcore, along with character unlocks that serve to boost the difficulty even more. The terrifying "Aria mode" is unlocked at the end of hardcore, and features a new mechanic where any hit or any failure to match the beat of the song results in immediate death.The end result is a very fun and refreshing game. Even in the alpha build the mechanics feel very polished, the enemies are varied and interesting, and the strategic gameplay is downright engaging. Much like Spelunky, you'll find yourself excited to die repeatedly as you learn to conquer the game's increasingly difficult floors. The less hardcore players will also likely find enjoyment in collecting new upgrades and unlocking new features as they slowly make their way to the end.The music is also incredible, featuring the composer from Super Meat Boy. If you want additional variety or don't like a particular track, you can replace any level's soundtrack with an MP3 of your choosing. I haven't played around with this much yet, but it likely adds a considerable amount of depth to an already deep game.Sadly, the Alpha Build doesn't have the 4th (and final) zone yet. However, if it is anything like what I've seen so far, it will be both devious and incredibly fun to play.If you enjoy Rogue-likes or music games, this is a great purchase.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												Don't get me wrong, I personally LOVE this game. The music is incredible to listen to; the gameplay mechanics are engaging and fun; and the overarching theme is creative and original. The concept is amazing, and initially I thought it was executed well too.The reason why I don't recommend this game is because of the absurd and arbitrary roller coaster of a difficulty curve that this game is.Playing Cadence was a fun and invigorating challenge. I banged my head a bit trying to beat the boss, but was able to eventually overcome it. The difficulty curve was fair and steady.Playing Melody was easy - a cakewalk compared to Cadence. I beat all 4 zones in 1-2 tries, no sweat. The difficulty curve was abnormally low here, especially after beating the 4th zone with Cadence.Then we have Aria... never have I played a videogame that it so unforgiving and punishing.There are several major disagreements I have with this:The cliff-like difficulty spike: especially going from Melody to Aria, this was a stark negative experience for me.That this ridiculous difficulty spike is included in the main storyline: This effectively locks out everyone but hardcore players from even the base storyline (Yes I'm saying that if you clear all Aria's zones I consider you a hardcore player!). I have nothing against the existence of Aria's gameplay; I can appreciate the level of difficulty that she offers. But I do take issue that the storyline cannot progress unless you play through all 4 zones with her.She has no advantages to other characters: Playing Melody was a new and interesting experience because of the lute and having to adjust my strategy to dance around the enemies. Aria doesn't bring anything new to the table; in fact, she takes things off the tableIf Aria's gameplay was adjusted to be more reasonable by giving her a unique gameplay advantage, I would not hesitate to recommend this game to everyone I know. However, the difficulty curve (i.e. roller coaster) is not something I would want those I know to experience.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit: As of December 25, 2014 (Merry Christmas)I really love this game. Danny Baranowsky does a beautiful job at making the music catchy and fit the theme of the levels. The game is incredibly hard, split into 4 zones (4th zone is locked as of the early access). Once you beat one zone (each zone is made up of 3 normal levels and a final boss, all of which are amazing and the music to the bosses are amazing as well) the next zone opens up. I've unlocked Zone 3 and it's nearly impossible for me. I mean, come on, there's a chess boss where the pieces move exactly like in chess, it's absolutely badass.There's a daily challenge much like Spelunky and SpiderMod for Isaac, and I've seen scores of people who have beaten the game, so it IS possible, it's just really hard. Don't let the challenge discourage you from getting it. Enemies have a distinct pattern (except bats, ♥♥♥♥ those guys), and you have to attack the enemy between their attack pattern to hit them unharmed, however if you stay in a square or attempt to move into a square that an enemy moves onto at the same time, you get hit. There is some knowledge you gain only by playing the game, such as attack prioritization. For example, the game prioritizes your attack over all enemies', so if you attack a 1 health enemy that's going to attack you at the same time, your attack is registered first and the enemy dies without you getting hit, but if the enemy has more than 1 health, you get hit because you didn't kill the enemy on that beat.When you get hurt or die it's ALWAYS because you messed up the enemy pattern, I've never felt the game cheated me on damage or death. And don't think the game is trial and error on knowing the enemy patterns, they nearly always have a tell when they're about to attack so you can attack them in between.There are very, very minor bugs in the game, sure a good amount of them are userend, meaning you might mess up thinking how something works and try to use it incorrectly only to have it mess you up (such as learning how the Cat of Nine Tails works, I hate this weapon), but the actual bugs in the game are barely noticeable and the creator does an absolutely fantastic job of updating the game and squashing bugs, he's very very active on the /r/necrodancer subreddit as well as the Brace Yourself Games forums where there's a bug database that you can add to or search through to see if a bug you found has already been seen.The visual style is nice, the pixelated art works fine, the level art is looks good. Most enemies groove out to the music so it's pretty cool.There's also a feature where you can use your own music and the game will process it and determine the beat of the music, so far it's pretty accurate though it does seem to have very minor issues with certain songs. But I really like the original music so I'm probably not going to change it.The more I play this game, the more I'm loving it. I fell in love with the Binding of Isaac and have about 230 hours in it, I can EASILY see myself outplaying that game in this one. Seriously, the music is some of the best I've heard in a game, the gameplay is fresh and the creator is constantly updating and improving the experience. Is it worth $15? ABSOLUTELY. I would not skip a beat even if this game was $30 dollars or even full retail at $60. The replay value is immense and if I get 200 hours in this game, even if the game was prices at $60, I payed $3.33 per hour, and I say that's an amazing deal. What makes this hypothetical even better is the game is FIFTEEN DOLLARS, NOT SIXTY. Come on, do yourself a favor and pick this game up. If the game is on sale (which it is for the Winter Sale), I say with 100% certainty that it is worth your time to buy it.At first I said this game is an 8.5/10. ♥♥♥♥ that♥♥♥♥♥♥ this gets 10000/10.

I don't personally recommend it because I found the experience frustrating and unrewarding. Judging by the fact the current store shows the ratings as 98% positive I'm obviously the minority here. There are folks with hundreds of hours sunk into this game, so take my negative opinion with a grain of salt obviously.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
TL;DR: Buy this game even if you don't enjoy rougelikesHmmmmmm, where do I even begin with this kind of game? The concept behind this game made this almost an instabuy. A roguelike where the turns are locked to the beats? Yes please. I haven't seen a concept like this before, and I haven't heard about another one if it existed.Unlike traditional roguelikes, there is no leveling system. You don't get "stronger" by defeating enemies or bosses. No, instead, you learn from them. Killed by a blue slime? Don't stand above it or below it. Out of 80+ hours of play, I have had zero unfair deaths. I could look at the replay and see exactly where and how I screwed up. You get better after every death.The music in this game is fantastic. Seriously. I have (mostly) had nothing but Necrodancer tunes stuck in my head ever since I started playing. My only complaint is that Jules' soundtrack isn't the best for playing the character it is assigned to. I've had little problems importing music as well, but it isn't 100% perfect. Instead of manually tpping out beats, I just use a program that generates the file for me.Make no mistake, this game is hard. It took me quite some time to clear the first character, and I am still working on the next two main ones. All zones mode is the main one for this game, and most of your character achievements will come from that mode. Play single zones until you're used to the game, then go for all zones. Do you think that being locked to the beat is too hard? Play as the bard. No beats and all the time in the world to make your decisions. Since you'll be dying a lot, it may or may not become repetitive. I haven't gotten bored in the amount of hours I put into it. This game is hard but replayable. Some characters are harder/more annoying than others. Experiment and see who you like best.Like roguelikes? Get this. Like rhythm games? Get this. Want to be challenged? Get this. Want to get angry that you went to an endboss and died? Get. This.9/10

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
 tl;dr: Buy this game NOW if you enjoy dungeon-crawlers and/or roguelikes of any kind, innovation, and kickass music. At its core, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a rouge-like dungeon crawler. However, as you become more invested in the game's unique on-the-beat movement system, you'll begin to realize that NecroDancer is much more than that! Strategy comes into play when dealing with enemies with increasingly complex movement systems, especially when you get the urge to compete for a top spot on the speedrun and gold high school leaderboards in each Daily Challenge. DannyB's soundtrack for this game is fantastic and somehow hasn't gotten boring to me even after hours and hours playing the game. There are now 5 soundtracks to play with, and there's also always the option to enchant the Crypt with your own MP3s with ease! The story is surprisingly deep and well thought out - cutscenes are quick but pack a lot of meaning. They flesh out the lore of the NecroDancer very well, and offer a very satisfying resolution that ties up all loose ends.Brace Yourself Games handled Early Access like champs - there was and still is a huge amount of community involvement, and I've seen many community suggested features be implemented! Crypt of the NecroDancer WELL WELL WELL worth the cost. Buy it NOW if you have any interest! It's easy to pick up, but hard to master!P.S.: for any musicians out there, I can say that this game has definitely improved my rhythm-keeping skills!P.S.S.: In reference to my hours played: it's ok.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												I should stop playing this before I break something.Edit: Okay, time for an actual review. It's also my first, so excuse me if it's a little useless.Crypt of the NecroDancer is built on a fairly simple concept: it's a turn based dungeon crawler, except each turn is restricted to the beat of the music, so if you don't think quickly enough or mistime your move, you miss your turn (and your gold multiplier, which can be crippling with certain items).As you might expect, enemies become tougher as you move through each stage of the game, with their movements becoming more complex as well. You can find new tools and weapons as you progress to give yourself a better chance, but ultimately, you have to learn how each enemy behaves to succeed.There are a total of ten playable characters, two of which are unlocked from the start (one using the  default gameplay and the other allowing you to move off the beat, effectively removing the time pressure). The unlockable characters offer more challenging scenarios such as: Instant gameover if you touch any gold dropped by defeated monsters Instant gameover (yet again) if you miss a single beat or take a single hit Elapsing turns two times faster than usual A ludicrous horror that combines everything above Not being able to deal any damage, and instead having to dodge enemies while going for the exitThere's plenty of replay value thanks to the different characters, and the game also generates daily challenges similar to those from Spelunky: everyone gets one try at the same dungeon each day, and your final score is uploaded to the leaderboard for that day only.You can import your own soundtracks and play along to them, provided you have them stored locally. There's also modding support, which is always nice.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												The thing is: I really like rythm games but I usually get bored quickly by them because they have nothing more to offer than just doing the same songs over and over again to get a better accuracy score.So here comes Crypt of the NecroDancer taking what I love about rythm games and combining it with another genre I've come to love over the last year: roguelike.There are various permanent options to unlock for your rounds, be it better and differently working weapons, armor, spells or other miscellaneous equipment. You don't just buy equipment to start with though, there are randomly generated chests in each level, you unlock better items to be found in those and/or more spawned chests. Which is an awesome way to keep the procedural feeling alive and not just making the game considerably easy to blast through.Each enemy has a certain pattern and rythm of moving and attacking, so due to the many different types of enemies there's a lot to learn and adapt to, which I love. If you don't quite have rythm in your blood, doing the constant moving to the beat and concentrating on visual patterns at the same time might get frustrating. Don't fret though! The game offers a training mode for both the basic monsters and minibosses - only ones you encountered yet, no spoilers.The music is fantastic and the artstyle just nails the whole serious yet not serious mood of the game. I'm totally in love with Crypt of the NecroDancer! <3

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								At its core, Crypt of the NecroDancer consists of one simple premise: move to the rhythm. The action unfolds according to the unholy beat of the Necrodancer - you must move with it, attack with it, dodge the enemy onslaught with it. The literal pulse of Cadence's heart drives a deadly crypt and the twisted monsters within.But underneath it is something more. Dig deeper, and the player uncovers a surprisingly deep gameplay experience, especially for one still in Early Access. Each weapon type sports a unique attack pattern. A cavalcade of items and equipment provides benefits ranging from immediate health recovery to phasing through walls or limiting the number of enemies. Spells can give you an upper hand against the thralls, freezing them in place or blasting them to ashes with a fiery bolt. Shrines, hidden shops, secret enemies, multiple playable characters... they all contribute to an experience unlike most other rhythm games you've played.Crypt of the NecroDancer falls into the "roguelike" genre and as such you'll see many of its usual trappings: procedural dungeons, high difficulty, an emphasis on discovery, bombs and consumables, etc. What sets this apart from other similar games, aside from the rhythm aspect, is that luck only plays a minimal factor in your success. Every level and every enemy is balanced in a way that completing a run from start to finish without ever upgrading from the starting dagger is entirely possible, and in fact has been done multiple times. If you're into other roguelike games there is a lot here for you to love and be familiar with. I, for one, never cared much for the genre. Games like Spelunky and The Binding of Isaac I've played a few times, but ultimately I grew tired of them. 120+ hours later, Crypt of the NecroDancer has me completely hooked.One of its biggest strengths is its absolutely stellar soundtrack composed by the well-known Danny Baranowsky. It was a smart move to focus the gameplay around this music - it provides just the right atmosphere and you'll find yourself bobbing your head to the beat as you play without even noticing it. One of the other aspects that really drew me in was that the game feels completely fair. You don't need one specific item to get a good run, and you don't need lucky shops or good spawns to make it to the end. Skill and familiarity with the enemies can carry you 99% of the way. Learning enemy behaviors and discovering new items become fun exercises. If you die, you know exactly what mistake you made and learn to avoid that for the next run. You can play with a keyboard, a controller, or even a dance pad, and you can even add your own music into the levels! The game also has a welcoming community and great forums you can visit to seek advice or share your latest victory.There's even still more to come! One more "zone" will be added to the game, there will be more boss fights, as well as the possibility for more items, equipment, mechanics, etc. Even in its "alpha" state Crypt of the NecroDancer is a deep and rewarding experience, and I personally can't wait to see more!

number of helpful: 16 of 23 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Yep, it's a roguelike played via DDR. Dance pads compatible but not required. It may technically be in Early Access but I'd never know, the game seems pretty complete as is and I keep getting my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me before I can even clear Zone 2 (there being 4 zones at present).The gameplay is pretty self-explanatory once you've gone through the quick tutorial, but is ever a matter of reflexes and quick thinking to keep yourself in one piece. Enemies are deviously varied to give you all manner of headaches to fight in conjunction with one another. Diamonds acquired through play are spent in the hub to unlock new equipment to appear in chests (as well as some passive upgrades like health). Rooms are available to help you practice fighting against specific enemies and bosses, and one character is available to let you just play the game as a regular turn-based roguelike. There's a local co-op mode of some sort too, hell if I know how that works. Hardcore mode is available for a no-upgrades run, and there's a daily one-shot hardcore challenge available, ala Spelunky.There are a few minor sticking points.1) You can import your own music for any of the levels you like, which is fantastic, except when the automatic beat detection--which, granted, is impressively accurate on the whole--doesn't work quite right and there's no way to attempt a manual fix.2) The game doesn't require you to keep on the beat perfectly, there's a fair leeway in the timing and you can miss beats if you don't mind losing your current cash multiplier (that is, unless you've invoked a risk shrine); this is open to some strategizing with skipping a beat to ready yourself for an enemy, but there's no actual control function for 'skip beat' and so you're left waiting for the input grace period between beats for enemies to make their move, after which it's hard to get right back into the rhythm.3) There's no "count in" between levels at all, so to keep your multiplier up you have to start moving again before you've even processed what's immediately around you or what the new rhythm actually is.4) Practice rooms for monsters are great, but having to defeat a monster or boss once during normal play to unlock them seems a bit counterintuitive.Minor gripes. Very solid soundtrack, very solid gameplay. Would probably be a HELL of a party game, with big picture running on a nice TV and a DDR mat set up.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								While the game is still in Beta, what has been completed is worthwhile. Necrodancer is a rhythm, turn-based, roguelike. It can be played with just directional keys, so dancepad friendly.  You move your character  to the beats of Danny Baranowsky (Super Meat Boy, Binding of Isaac) as you make your way through 3 (4 upon release) zones, each containing 3 levels and a boss fight. There are currently 7 playable characters offering various challenges with a variety of weapons and items to utilize. Floors are randomly generated and you can race for better times or complete to get the highest score. The game is challenging, but fair so when you die, it was probably your fault. The game provides a training feature so you can practice against any enemy and hone your strategies. Other features include a daily challenge, seeded runs, and creating your own levels. You can even customize the music that plays as well as mod in game sprites.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off, I have to admit, I fell in love with the opening sequence. It's the perfect blend of music, plot, voice acting and a beat to get me hyped all the hell when I start it up. DROP DEAD!The game is really enjoyable. It's a Roguelike, but it feels less dependent on luck, and more on skill and planning then most others. I don't generally feel like I was screwed too hard when I die; As far as I can see it, you should be able to clear the game without getting hit, or at least close, if you're god-like at pattern recognition.Every enemy has it's own pattern, which, I can't believe the game didn't refer to as it's unique Dance. Maybe it's too corny. As Cadence (oh, there's the corniness. Works, though.) remarks, 'learn that, and they'll never harm you.' (something like that.)I think the one negative I've had in dealing with the game is in using items and spells. It's not impossible, but it takes a good deal getting used to. You only have 4 keys, the 4 directions. To use items, you combine them. Ex, an apple is Up+Left, or whatnot. Keeping your combo going while using them very rarely works out for me in the heat of a battle.But, even then, you can bind those combinations to other keys, if you like. Up+Left could be bound to Ctrl, or Shift, or Left trigger. Yes, it works with gamepads. Personally, I bound XBAY and the Dpad to all directions applicable. If your one hand gets tired, switch to the other! Or, if you have a Left+Right item, it works well using both hands, I find, so it's Left+B instead. Aaaaanyway. Graphics are fine. Gameplay is fun (first level's tempo is a liiitle slow for my taste), and the feeling on beating a boss is rewarding. King Conga and his Zombie Conga Lines (yes) confused the hell out of me the first time, but when you learn it, it's just plain fun.In short, I love installing large screen televisions in doghouses, and Crypt of the NecroDancer is a good game.

Early Access Review
PROS+It's in early access but you should probably get it, does an excellent job at combining the rythm / dungeon crawler / roguelike genres.+The game isnt easy and requires some practice and time investment to beat all the zones (learning monsters patterns, items, shrines) but all in all its a very rewarding process.+Has Steam Workshop support and a lot of interesting items / equipment you'll have to learn. Also they do daily challenges and the devs donate some money to charities and top players.+Gets you humming to its great OST and moving to the beatThings I would improve-Some improvements to the custom music-to-beats process, using your own songs doesn't always work as expected-Adding some kind of end-game content (After beating zone 3 you are like "what do I do now"). Yes, you have hardcore mode, but I would add some minor and faster reachable achievements / milestones. Like "kill X red ragons" , "kill 3 enemies with a bomb", "kill Conga King with a glass shard". Maybe even add some more hidden collectibles or trophys which can be viewed in a room in the lobby.-Cloud save would be a nice feature, also multiplayer in the future would be something nice but it's ok as it is, I know it would be too much trouble.VeredictThis game is worth the money, some minor things could be improved, but even if it's in early access the developers are really active and care about the game!

1-sentence review:this game is a well crafted rhythm-based roguelike, which is fun and addicting enough, even for a player with average dexterity like myself, which is in addition not especially fan of hardcore roguelikes ; although the game is not without (small) shortcomings.Pros:- Well crafted roguelike, even without the rhythm component- Varied monsters- Relatively varied environments- Training room to beat each enemy individually- Boss fights are not too hard nor too easy- Playing with the Bard character makes the game turn-based (ie: no rhythm anymore), which allowed me to see the final zone ;-)Cons:- Having to play on the rhythm of the music can get really frustrating when it feels too slow- RNG is as usually in a roguelike too important ; getting a good weapon early or late in the run makes all the difference ; sometimes, the spawning point is next of the exit with a big dragon that burns you through walls before you can get an idea of your surroundings, etc... >_<- No difficulty settings, except for the separate easier 1st Zone & the Bard, but it's really not enough (eg: I wish I could have played with some bonus Hearts and more efficient healing from food)- Lacks a bit of content ; I played 12 hours and I feel I got all I could get from the game ; it is totally ok for me as I don't like to spend too much time on the same game, and if you get badly addicted, you probably can play a lot more than thatBonus Notes:- Unlike 99% of the other players, I'm not a big fan of the musics ; they don't hold up to the 80's & 90's scores I still have in mind ; I haven't played the game for 2 days and can't remember a tune right now... >_<   They do their jobs though and are alright.- the extra characters bring different gameplay, but exception of the Bard one, they'll be doable only by the most hardcore fans

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												I have a lot of good things I can say about this game.Out of every game I played, I can say this one take's the cake for:Most fair game. EVERY time I die, I can think "man, I know what I did wrong," as opposed to other games where you lose and feel cheated.Best difficulty curve. Starting out, I couldn't tap keys to a beat, but I was able to work my way up to fast reactions and even double-speed (a certain character). No matter how long you play this game, you can ALWAYS get better and notice the improvement.The music is FANTASTIC. Danny B's music has such strong composition. It really fits the game, the groove, and does a great job at letting the player 'feel the beat' of the game. The other soundtracks are also great. I'm not a big fan of EDM or Metal, but I still enjoy Jules and A-Rival. Girlfriend also has some great tracks, but I personally am not a fan of Virt.There are so many unique things about this game. This is the first music-based dungeon crawler I've ever seen. The shopkeeper sings! The characters, voices, sounds, they make you feel so good to play. You can compete against other players for fastest times, or highest scores.woopsirantedthisgameisreallygoodbuyit

								you need this game. YOU NEED THIS GAME. did I mention you need this game? No? Ok. Well you need it. You may not think you need it but you need it. Do you like the binding of isaac? if yes buy this game. Do you like rythm games? Buy it. do you like Skeletons that wiggle? This game has it. Do you like simple mechanics but hard to master? Oh did you know they have necrodancer themed DDR pads? well they do infact they are being sold at the regular price and the devs aren't even taking a cut.Seriously this may sound like i'm joking but you need this game.Edit:this game has multiple modes     Normal mode where unlocks you purcahse with gems (found while playing the game)  and beating a zone brings you to the menu     hardcore mode which means you get none of the upgrades and start with only 2 HP. you must beat all zones to complete it.     Other variants that involve characters that augment the game such as making the game in double time or miss a beat and you die.     Daily challenge like spelunky. A seeded run that you get one chance per day.You are able to use your own music if you so choose but the soundtrack itself is amazing.This game is very difficult but rewarding and it's continually improving.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												This is probably the best roguelike (or roguelite) I've ever played. :-)Why? Let's see...-the theming: it mixes classic dungeon crawling with rhythm (or at least: sets you on a beat), and it maintains that position to the smallest details. From singing shopkeepers to music-themed bosses, it's neither too corny nor not flavourful enough.-as far as variety in procedurally generated levels are concerned, things are pretty decent. There's a good amount of enemy variety and items, and all the systems seem to work together well (will you trade hearts for a better weapon? Will you fight extra monsters for gold to buy better gear? Will you risk stuff for diamonds to easy future runs?).-the whole nine yards: in the lobby, you can practice fighting enemies, there are other characters to chose from, lots of unlocks, and so on. I even had problems finding the actual story mode. ;-)-difficulty: as many roguelikes go, this follows the standard "extremely hard to complete" pattern, requiring many playthroughs from your end (reason why the variety is important). However, since enemies move to the beat in predictable patterns, all errors are technically your own fault. Still, even when playing as the bard (I'll get to that), it's pretty hard to actually make a good run.-music: as you should expect, the music is great. And I may be underestimating it when I say that.I've gotta say that Crypt of the Necrodancer feels like it has done its homework on the genre. It's like every plus point I find in spelunky, don't starve or nuclear throne is also somehow included here (though the beat-following is something of its own). The result is a very well polished and fun to play game.As said, the bard deserves special mentioning. Where other characters have slight variations on the main character, the bard doesn't follow the beat. While this makes the game less hard (it's still in no way easy), it does change the entire gameplay. It also removes the only gripe I have with the game: that the constant moving in a beat can get pretty annoying if you just want to backtrack to another part of the dungeon. The bard changes the game so much it's an entirely different game (rather akin to Nova-111, btw). A better one, some might argue, though it misses a bit of the magic that makes the game special.But whatever character you pick, this game has this addiction that when you die you immediately go "again! again!". So beware: your social life might suffer because of this game. ;-)

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												Beatgames (or rhythm games) tend to be very hard at first, but when you practice, you can literally see your improvement. Although this game is not a pure beatgame, it has the full characteristics of one. The concept of two different game genres put into one is incredible, but it is just EPIC when the execution of it is perfect.The soundtrack of this game is simply amazing. I've never really had a taste for electronic music or jazz, but the stuff they put into this game definitely made me change my mind. The way they've designed everything, I think, was so you, the player, could jam to any music that would hit you. Every moving object in the game has an animation that moves to the rhythm of the BPM (beats per minute; determines how fast a song is) of the song, the shopkeepers' singing is just perfect, and the rest of the sound effects (voices, attacks, monsters) flow so astoundingly. Sometimes I play this game just because I want to listen to the soundtrack. Custom music is a plus, and I have not found any errors working with it so far. It has it's own BPM detection that works fine. Randomly generated-ness (well that's rogue-like, isn't it?) makes this game never get old. The story mode is of moderate length, and surprisingly, or at least, for me, I have gotten tied to the characters and I have grown to have sympathy for them! If you don't have a thing for rogue-like games, this will surely change your mind (That's what had happened to me). The pixel art is adorable, and the character concept art for those monsters are.. dark and horrifying. Think you have a slow/old computer and can't run this game? This game ran at 60 fps on mine, so you're fine. (In case you didn't get it, my computer is very bad.)When you first start playing, the thing that you need to remember is to never give up. If you die five times in a row, you should either take a break for a while and come back to the game later or keep playing. You will  see that improvement and it will just feel amazing. You actually feel accomplished about something, which is what very few games are able to do.As for going into more depth about the gameplay, no need for that. It is all for you to discover yourself. But here's something to remember: although the content of this game doesn't seem that abundant, trust me. It was way more stuff than you think. They also have a level editor after you complete the game (or should I say, a fraction of the game [Note what I said to remember]), so you can upload your creations to the Steam Workshop that is connected to the game or just play them alone. Nothing wrong with that.To sum it up, this game deserves every one of those awards that you see to the right. If not, more than that. This review cannot express how much I enjoy this game. It is one of the most unique and unforgettable gaming experiences ever. Get this game if you're looking for something new to enjoy. Highly RecommendedAlso, sorry if I have any grammar/typing errors. I did not read this over.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								NecroDancer is a great rhythm-based Rogue-like where you take turns to the beat of the music.  Miss a beat, everything around you takes a turn anyway.  At first it sounds weird to not have all the time in the world to plan a move in an RL, but NecroDancer makes it work with basic patterns to all creatures.  The main challenge is balancing keeping the beat up with putting yourself in a good position to deal with whatever comes at you.  You need either quick decision-making or good muscle memory from repeated plays to deal with complex situations.Unreservedly recommend it once the game is completed.  $15 for early access is alright, but you'll probably have to be interested in the concept beforehand to feel fully happy about your $15.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is a unique take on the Rogue-like genre - in that it also doubles as a rhythm game! Bounce to the beat as you read enemy movements and dispatch them; collect better items, weaponry, or scrolls; and defeat hilarious bosses from a moving chess board to a zombie conga line - and of course there are the final bosses in the game as well.The game features a multitude of different characters you can play with to win the game - starting with the default character and bard with several more unlocked as you go along. Speaking of unlocks, you will unlock new items, weapons, and other npcs that can grant services for you as you proceed through the game.While it is overall quite a neat take on playing rogue-likes, there is certainly something to say about lack of 'game' to play. There are essentially 4 different zones to play it with a multitude of enemies to encounter - but eventually it will quickly come across as same-ish and old hat. There is also a limited amount of items to unlock and eventually you'll unlock everything fairly quickly.This is a game I recommend - though I do encourage getting it at a discounted price.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												This game combines rhythm and roguelike like fried chicken and waffles. If you haven't experienced them together, you think it's a bizarre combo that won't mesh well. Then you try it and you wonder why you haven't had the two together before. Where has this magical combo been your entire life?Gimmick aside, the game is still beautifully designed. The enemies all have tells and literally have choreographed attacks. Everything gives signs before the action takes place, much like many roguelikes. It's just that this game took that dance and set it to a kickin' soundtrack. You can even practice against enemies without needing to throw yourself into the deep end to figure out their tells. Even the characters are more upbeat and lively than your average roguelike. The little things, like how they greet NPCs (shyly VS boldly VS force of habit) and their surprised reactions to teleportation make them seem less like digital avatars and more like humans. A little detail that adds a lot of magic to the game.[edit] THE STORY. Add the story to another fantastic bit of this game. Only frustrating bit is how hard it is to complete story mode, but hey, it's a roguelike. That's to be expected from the genre.TL;DR - A wonderfully charming game that blends two very different genres in a lovingly-designed piece. I strongly recommend you pick up the game and the soundtrack!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29
												Honestly, if you're not already interested by the description "rhythm dungeon-crawler" I don't know what else to tell you.I can say every single thing about it stylish as hell, it has one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard from any video game in my life, and the two genres blend together shockingly well. It's not a hugely innovative roguelike, you just explore a randomly assembled network of rooms and tunnels full of monsters and gear. And it's not a hugely complex rhythm game either, you just take every step in beat with the music. But putting them together REALLY transforms the experience of both. Having to work out your own "dance" to outmaneauver enemies and traps as you come to them makes the rhythm game feel clever and engaging in a way they're usually not. Putting that dance into every little thing makes the busywork of a roguelike feel satisfying and just GOOD in a way I've never felt before.This is one of those mashups that sounds pointless when it's described to you, and after actually trying it, you don't understand why there haven't been games like this since 20 years ago.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the NecroDancer is half turn-based dungeon crawler with randomly-generated dungeons. The other half of the game is rhythm: each dungeon floor has a unique music track with a visually emphasized steady beat. Your moves are (ideally) made to that beat. Enemies also move to the beat, so the pace at which things happen is determined by the music. Having a steady rhythm locks the participant into a timeframe in which to act, not unlike speed chess or the rate at which a block lowers in Tetris. By removing the infinite time in which a player could decide which move is most optimal in your traditional turn-based dungeon excursions, the game becomes instead one of relying almost wholly on experience. After a while, experience becomes instinct, leading to creative leaps of strategy made entirely in the moment, in the space between the game’s figurative and literal heartbeats.You play as Cadence, a headstrong delver who - through an unfortunate combination of a terminal fall and an evil NecroDancer stealing her still-beating heart - must now travel down multiple dungeon floors, fighting monsters and finding useful items. You technically don’t have to move to the beat, but not doing so will cause you to lose a vital multiplier that increases how many coins you earn from defeated monsters. The higher the multiplier, the more likely you can afford powerful weapons and items found in dungeon shops. You know when you’re moving to the beat, because the dungeon floor starts pulsing with light, making it your very own little dungeon rave.There is very little randomness to the combat in Crypt of the NecroDancer. Everything behaves according to very set rules. You move into a monster to attack it, different weapons change the shape of your attack. If an enemy moves into a square you were trying to move to, you’ll take damage instead. Certain enemies take advantage of your urge to rush in, waiting a beat before moving, or moving in interesting patterns. Monsters have unique little dance animations, their movement sounds become a part of the melody of what’s happening on the screen. These sounds are often a clue to defeating them. As you delve deeper, the music becomes faster, the monster patterns more complex. The game is ingenious, fun in ways indescribable unless you’re there, in the moment, taken by the rhythm and amazed at how well you’re doing.You can use your own MP3s for the soundtrack, and there’s even a DDR mode for use with a dance pad. The DDR mode makes a game a bit easier so you don’t kill yourself. There’s permanent progression via character upgrades, like a health increase and magic spells, unlocked by collecting diamonds. The music is being provided by the excellent Danny Baranowsky (Super Meat Boy, Canabalt, Binding of Isaac, Desktop Dungeons).

												One of the best rhythm games I have ever played. One of the best roguelikes I have ever played. Two of my favorite genres, tasting oh so great together.Crypt of the Necrodancer requires quick thinking, a good sense of rhythm, and a keen strategic and tactical sensibility to win, and those wins are so rewarding. With a rollicking feel, great pixel art, and excellent screen effects, it's easy to get pulled into the action and hard to put down. Possibly the best feature is Danny Baranowsky's amazing soundtrack—you can play with your own music, but I never have; I love the original soundtrack too much!

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												Now that the full release of this game has been out for awhile, I feel compelled to write a review of this game.Crypt of the NecroDancer is a rogue like, rhythm based dungeon crawler that offers a unique challenge and experience, complete with multiple characters that have their own playing style that affects the gameplay greatly. Pros:- Probably the most important aspect of a rhythm game is its music. Crypt does not disappoint in the slightest with its amazing tunes, composed by the one and only Danny Baranowsky as well as awesome remixes by FamilyJules7x and A_Rival.- You can use your own music in the game, and this feature is implemented well. - The game provides a hard but fair style of gameplay, something that is sure to keep people doing runs over and over again.- Each of the characters adds an interesting twist (such as moving in cut time or being able to only use bombs) that provide an additional challenge for players to overcome.- This game has high replayability as no two runs are exactly the same.- A mix of items provides players with multiple ways to beatdown enemies to the beat.- The devs constantly provide updates and work hard to fix any bugs that people encounter along the way.Cons:- It can take awhile to get used to. You're probably not going to be able to get through Zone 1 on your first try. For some people, this may be a turnoff, though, if you're willing to put in the effort, you can really get a lot of enjoyment out of completing a run.- If you're trying to 100% this game... think again. One of the achievements may be impossible to get, which may turn some people away.- Pausing the game and regaining your pace can be rather difficult. While this may not sound like a big deal at first glance, there are some characters who will die if you miss a beat (Aria and Coda).Some people may complain about the price, but you can find some 33% off coupons floating around on Steam. It's not much, but 10 bucks is less than 15. TL;DR: If you like rogue likes, rhythm games, or dungeon crawlers, get this game. This game is an astounding combination of the three that works harmoniously. If the price seems like too much, go get a coupon from groups like Coupon Dumpster and that.
