content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I love this game. A lot. Now, take into account what most of the high-rated reviews say, because I agree with them. But what I'm going to touch on is something specific that I find most interesting and perhaps wholly unique about this game. Put simply, it reminds me of chess. In fact, one of the final boss room types is a chess set, which you can see briefly in the trailer, but that's beside the point. All enemies have set actions (or perhaps reactions), and will always make them according to the rhythm and how you move. For instance, the red dragon will move once every two beats toward you unless you are any distance directly to the left or right of him, in which case he will shoot a row of fire. The goblins will run away if you approach them, but pursue if you move away from them.Now, normally, if you had all the time you needed, you could plan out a perfect attack and kill everything without taking damage, but in this game, you have to move with the beat. You have to think quickly if you want to work your way out of a tricky situation. When you die, you feel like it was your mistake and the game had not cheated you, which is generally the case (though there is a small chance of the game generating an absurdly difficult enemy encounter). Even so, due to the random generation, it is possible to find a good weapon or food early on, making giving you an advantage. I always hope for an awesome weapon, but sometimes find myself doing surprisingly well with just a standard dagger. It's action/strategy/cool music-y rhythm/rogue-like at its finest.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Rhythm games and dungeon crawlers seem like they'd be incompatible, but Crypt of the NecroDancer makes the two work together. You have to move and act to the beat of the music, so you must assess the enemies, traps, and walls around you and act very quickly. The enemies start out simple enough, with easy-to-tell movement patterns. However, subsequent zones become muh trickier, with things and foes that mess with your position or require you to be very attentive of your surroundings. Managing and understanding is key in reaching the end of the game.There are a fair amount of extras here. In your regular runs you collect diamonds, which you use to unlock new items to find in your runs, upgrades like more life or a higher money multiplier, the opportunity to practice against bosses, and more. There are several different characters to play as, who all change the game in some manner, which can be as simple as requiring you to act in double time or as substantial as restricting your weaponry to bombs.The music is fantastic. As you may expect from the title, it's all very dancable stuff. I seriously would listen to this at a party. Perhaps the best part is the various ways it's mixed when you enter certain areas. The graphics are in a pixel style and it looks and animates well enough.In summary, Crypt of the NecroDancer takes rhythm and dungeon crawling elements together and brings out the best of both of them. Combine that with a great soundtrack, and the end result is a game that comes highly recommended.Also, NecroDancer is a superb pun. I mean, it's simple and thematically appropriate!

Early Access Review
								Holy Jeezus phuuuck, this is an amazing game. I highly recommend getting the soundtrack when purchasing, because if you don't you'll wish you had after playing.A rhythm-game dungeon-crawler rougelike? What about that phrase doesn't spell the word "awesome?" Nothing! There are only the movement buttons: they cover moveing, attacks, items, spells, etc. and it works all so well. You can only move on the beat, and that's what makes the game what it is, and what makes it so fun.It's a very well executed take on a unique combination of genres. It is HARD, like Nintendo-hard, which is refreshing. When you think you finally get it, the game will hit you with a curve ball. And then you'll think you got it again, and you've re-learned how it *really* works, but NOPE it's shaken things up again.I'd like to see this ported to consoles, the dev deserves money. Hell, buy it even if you're not going to play it. This was obviously an act of love, and this behaviour should be encouraged.

content:

Early Access Review
								One of the best games I've played in a long time. It's a mix of Spelunky and Binding of Isaac's zone and random item mechanics, all smushed in with a dungeon crawler and a rhythm game. It's fairly unforgiving but not deathly hard (unless you do hardcore mode or above, but that's expected).It's definitely worth a play if you're a fan of rhythm games or dungeon crawlers regardless. The soundtrack is probably one of the most solid soundtracks I've heard on a game in quite a while, and even after 16 hours I'm still not tired of it and want to keep playing (though trying to resist due to waiting for missing content to be finished).The game's in Early Access but you wouldn't notice it if it weren't for zone 4 being unfinished, so it's definitely in a fun playable state already and the only places it can go is up. There's a lot more content on it's way but there's no harm picking it up now, you'll definitely get your money's worth if you enjoy any of the genres within.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												This game is easily my favorite game of 2016.  The soundtrack is amazing which is important since you'll be using the audio cues for movement.  When buying the game, I assumed I would want to play with my own mp3s.  That is absolutely not the case (I cannot stress enough how well crafted the music is).  The four zone bosses are awesome and unique with their own soundtrack that matches their theme.  The difficulty curve is perfect.  Once you start to master a zone, you move to the next zone and are immediately given a healthy dose of humility as the basic enemies brutalize you and it's time to learn brand new enemy patterns all over again.  Because of the diamond upgrade system you don't feel bad for dying and it keeps the items you find in chests less complex until you master them and are ready for shiny new spells/weapons/stuff.  Because the levels are random, they never get boring or predictable.  And here's the real kicker.  Each different character you unlock has a different playstyle which changes how you play the levels completely.  I recently found out that some characters have different remixes of the standard songs too which is amazing.Honestly, I cannot recommend this game enough.  If you enjoy a challange and like dungeon exploration games that require you to think rather than level stats, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Absolutely amazing. I never thought there would ever be a roguelike-rythm game, but here we are, and it's executed in such a way that this will probably end up being my favorite game of the year. The game is played using just arrow keys for movement and item usage, and it works really well.The game appears as a standard roguelike dungeon crawler; you make tactical choices in turn-based style battles, find equipment and try to battle your way through dungeons. The difference is that the game focuses on forcing the player to keep in step with the beat of the song for movement and actions (traditionally what you'd consider to be "turns"), giving the player a bonus in gold which can be used to buy equipment if done without flaw. Failing to move with the beat will result in a missed action while all the enemies take a turn and losing this bonus.I don't think I've ever played an RPG so easy to get into, yet challenging on many levels. It has a fun plot that works with the premise of the mechanics and the voice acting is actually very good. The music is superb, and if it's not your thing you can use your own music to power the gameplay. I don't even think I have anything I could say needs improving. It supports controllers and even dance pads. There's a slightly less difficult mode meant specifically for playing with dance pads. They already have a character that doesn't need to move in time, turning the game into a traditional roguelike dungeon crawler if you want to get used to the game or want to take a break from the rythm aspects of the game. I mean, they thought of everything and the game is super polished, all that seems to be missing is four characters and the last zone (which I haven't even reached yet). This is seriously a game I wish I had helped made.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is a cross of both rhythm game and turned based  RPG in where you have to move along to the beat of the song and keep a steady rhythm to get a higher combo count. Every note counts as a turn and missing a note resets your combo as well as costs you a turn. This is a game in where you must have must both quick reflexes and foresight since you don't have much time to think. Your enemies also move along to the beat of the song so you can estimate how long it will take them to reach you and plan accordingly. Movement is grid based so you move square by square and the only buttons you will need during the game are the arrow keys. You attack by moving next to an enemy and hitting the arrow direction they are in and stranger still is that you use your bombs by holding the down and left arrow. There are also spells and other items that are activated by holding the up and right keys. As you can no doubt tell this is a rather strange control scheme and it does take some time to get used to. It is a strange gameplay concept to explain properly and there is nothing else like it on the market so I would suggest looking up some gameplay videos to see if this is your cup of tea. The levels are split up into 4 zones accessible via the hub-world where you can also purchase new items and weaponry that randomly spawns in the level once purchased. To purchase these items you will need diamonds which are semi rare collectibles scattered around the levels. Once you either die or pass that zone you will be tossed to the hub-world and will be able to spend your diamonds. Be wary though as entering any level will reset your diamonds back to zero so always make sure to spend them before heading back into the action. Another important collectible found in levels is gold which can be used to purchase unlocked weapons and items from shops. If you don't have any gold when you find a shop you can also blow up the golden walls of the shop to collect the debris and buy your items that way, the shopkeeper won't mind his walls being blown up funnily enough. One of the really neat things about this game is that the levels are destructible and you start off with a shovel that allows you to create your own paths through them and search for hidden goodies. There is a time limit for each level however, so if the song finishes you are immediately dropped down to the next level via a trapdoor. Each zone  has three levels that lead to a boss fight and you will want to be well equipped when you face one of them.  Bosses are randomly generated so you will not face the same boss each attempt but all of them will take quite a bit of skill to defeat. One of the easier ways to handle bosses is to pick up a spear if you are lucky enough to find one as it can attack from two blocks away meaning you can attack it from a safe place. That is easier said than done however since missing a beat will cost you a turn which can have dire consequences. You need to have a good rhythm at all times and that is very hard to do when you have to press two keys at the same time to use an item or spell. Keeping an unbroken rhythm also makes any gold you collect be worth much more, so the better you are at doing that the higher your chances of survival. If you find a key and save someone from a cage you will unlock a new character which play differently from our original heroine. One of them fights by only using bombs, another character can't attack but all exits are unlocked and one of the characters even gets rid of the rhythm part of the game entirely, allowing you to move whenever you want and take your time. There are quite major changes to the gameplay from character to character which makes this game's replayablity really high.  Crypt of the Necrodancer is brutal and you will be dying a lot until you unlock some better gear with diamonds. It has randomly generated levels so learned the pattern of them is not an option and it is more than happy to toss out a bunch of enemies. Learning how to fight each enemy is integral to be able to hold your own as some will roll toward you on sight leaving you with little time to move but hitting it on time will send it spiraling back to whence it came. Weapons also have their own quirks to them such as crossbows having to be reloaded but give you great range and rapiers will cause your character to rush in to attack an enemy two blocks away. Finding armor will lower the amount of damage you take and a torch will increase your view distance. This game is much more complex than it may appear and knowledge will be your greatest strength in these funky crypts. On the hubworld, the Beastmaster’s area allows you to pick any enemy you like and practice against them to your hearts content. It is not unlocked from the beginning as he is locked in a cage and must be freed in order to show up in the hubworld. There is a story but it is very forgettable and unimportant.  As is expected of a rhythm game the music is very catchy and fit the tongue in cheek feel of the game very well. Each stage has its own unique song and if you ever get tired of them there are a few other remixed soundtracks you can choose from, such as a Metal version. You can even use your own music but the notes don't match up at all to the songs making it very hard to keep a steady rhythm. It is an extra option so I can't really knock it but I can't imagine too many people wanting to use it. Crypt of the Necrodancer supports Steam Workshop and there are quite a bit of mods to keep you entertained such as one that changes your character into Hatsune Miku and even one that overhauls the whole game to have a Mario Bros aesthetic. There is plenty of content in the base game and the levels being randomly generated insures that you will have a different experience each playthrough. What it ultimately comes down to is if you like the strange gameplay on offer here and would like to once again suggest looking up a gameplay video. I'd imagine it would be much more fun to use a dancepad and a large TV to play this but using the keyboard works well enough too. Crypt of the Necrodancer is a unique experience you can't get anywhere else and tons of fun to boot.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												I am GoingTo the CryptOF THE NECRODANCER!I did not know what to expect. A Hardcore Rythm based Roguelike? So I watched the trailer and got hooked. Then I got it and I am absolutely amazed.the basic priciple is like a turn based roguelike - when you move the enemies move according to their pattern. You crawl through randomly generated floors, try to find a boss monster, kill it and find the exit to the next floor. But what sets this apart is the rythm component. Because you can only move on a beat of the background music. And every beat makes the enemies move as well.The Pixel art, albeit simple looks amazing. the Music gets you pumped and theres allways something new to discover.the Gameplay and Action itself is tight. As in, you could take it slow, but if you so much as miss a beat, your multiplicator gets reset. Which means less gold and probably less equipment in turn, so you have to keep the rythm, move every beat and make quick decisions. And if the song runs out, the floor is over. the music, Kick♥♥♥♥♥ The way it should be for any rythm based game. But if you dont like it, you can use your own library to fill the floors with life.the geme itself keeps you frustrated enough to make you wanna try again, because every enemy behaves in a certain way and you can train combat against them pretty early on - so if you die its because you got careless.oh, and the shopkeepers voice is divine. Get the Soundtrach edition if you can.10/10[1.0 Update]HO-LY-CRAP! I literally mean, Holy Crap! What they did with this is Divine.I mean before the game was a 10/10 but now. Wow. just Wow.new characters each with their own feel. Bard for easy Mode, other chars for extra challenges (like one that can lay infinite bombs and can kick them a few spaces ahead. Another one can only move in 2 space intervals.The 3 main chars, Aria, Melody and Cadence now have little cutscenes after each Level, Bosses enter with an awesome Intro screen and announcement. the remastered Metal and Electro OST, that will play for Melody and aria are just Eargasmic.If the Early access version was 10/10, this version is a 12/10.I would love to give this two thumbs up, if possible

												Game is good.Please stop sending me death threats nowYeah okay what do you exect to read here? Everyone is saying this game is good so what can my review bring to the table that is missing from all the glowing praise?I'll tell you.Crypt of the Necrodancer should be hauled up on a pedestal for the whole world (of gaming) to see for one, very simple reason.replays on leaderboard!I could gripe and complain all day but if you play ANY steam game with a leaderboard then their is one thing you will see over and over again and that is hackers and hacked scores.Now I don't hate hackers but when I look at leaderboards I want to know how that person got that score and how I can improve my own gameplay.See, the score itself is the result and while a good result is impressive seeing all the crazy stuff you people get upto is just as good, so if you own this game I urge you to check out some replays.They taught me to blow up the shopkeeper.I wish I had more to say about the game but I would just be mimicking everything that every other review has had to say about the game at this point.Also even when I didn't initially recommend the game, I still stand by the fact that the music is great and the ability to import your own music is also great so that hasn't changed (which is good).If you struggle with the timing system, switch to bard and you can still enjoy the game as a traditional Rogue-Like game. Isn't that neat?I will be watching 'Brace yourself games' very closely because they really went all out in making the game accessible, which is a rarity.Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

												I picked this up in early access, had a great time and set it aside to see how much better it could get.  Now I've got a rogue-light that's beautifully animated, brutally difficult with a boisterous soundtrack on my hands. number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Initially I had a really negative vibe from this game. I was frustrated because I found the rhythm aspect of the game overwhelmingly difficult, not because it is necessarily, but more likely it’s my lack of ability to time my movements right, and I found it hard to watch the in-game metronome while doing everything else. This is more of a personal problem though, and it doesn’t really reflect on the game.However, I learned that there is another class called bard available from the start of the game. The bard can move freely without the concern of coordinating with the beat, and the monsters move when the player moves; more akin to a traditional roguelike. Playing bard has made the game enjoyable to me, and I look forward to possibly taking on the challenge of playing with the other characters later. The game is well designed, and I’m impressed with the level it’s at for still being in development. The soundtrack is worth noting, it’s really good, and the pixel art is also very nostalgic, and in my opinion, it fits the game perfect. Everything you would expect from a roguelike is there too, but with a spin, and I respect the developers creativity coming up with something so unique. The play style may not be appealing to everyone, but the game will (and should) still be recognised as a good game.Everything considered Crypt of the Necrodancer is a pretty cool game for alpha. I sincerely hope that development continues, and the game is finished. A successful pre-release all to often results in games being abandoned and pretty much just left in their current state.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								There hasn't been a game like this one before, or at least not to my knowledge. There are plenty of games in which the player displays their ability to comprehend music and beat, and there are a fair number of games where the player explores a dungeon, travelling deeper and deeper, growing in strength as their enemies become tougher and tougher, where any misstep will result in a "game over" screen and the option to start over from square one. I don't think mixing these kinds of games has ever been done before, and I'm in love with the result!Crypt of the Necrodancer isn't just a groovy music game, nor is it just a dungeon-crawling roguelike - it's both. It's a very demanding game, as it requires quick thinking and decision-making, and throughout the whole experience you will absolutely want to groove in place, getting as deep into those juicy tunes as you can. Play it with a keyboard or a dance mat; you'll have extreme fun no matter which way you play.I have nothing but praise for this game, and it isn't even finished yet. Even when I began playing in advance of the early access hitting steam, I never once felt like my money was misplaced. Even if this game were never finished, it'd still be worth every penny I spent on it.Are you even slightly interested in what this game has to offer? No need to wonder any longer; snag this one and lose yourself in it for a while.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Finally the Full Release is here for NecroDancer! I got it in Early Acces a few months ago and could see the evolution of this game into the great game that we have now. But what is Crypt of the NecroDancer exactly?Well, it calls itself a Roguelike  Rhythm game - and what that means is, that as opposed to your usual Roguelike game, you will have to follow the beat of the music (the Standard soundtrack is produced by Danny B., and trust me, it's possibly his most awesome work). There are also 2 greatly done remixes of the Soundtrack that you can select, in addition to that you can also choose your own custom music.The main difficulty comes from learning the patterns of the enemies, weapons, what items and shrines do and how to manage all of this while keeping the rhythmn. Now that might sound overwhelming at first but the game has a beat system that is fairly lenient, which means that you can be half a beat off without losing your multiplayer and screwing up. Which is good since the monsters will make you sweat bullets later on. Patterns in the beginning are fairly easy though, so don't worry about getting stuck from the beginning.The Lobby system of NecroDancer allows you to train against monsters, bosses and practice with different weapons, so that you can find out why that red bat utterly destroyed you last time. Aside from that you can earn Diamonds when you play the separate zones to unlock items to find in the same mode. The All zones mode has everything unlocked item wise from the beginning, but it is advisable that you learn the ropes by starting with just Zone 1. Generally it is a good idea to practice with Zones separately if you have problems with them. Once you are familiar, you will probably stick with going trough all Zones, similar to how Spelunky works, to build up good equipment over the run.Every run is different, as the layouts get randomly generated. There is a fair variety of items, from weapons to rings, weapons, spells, potions that give you an extra life to boots that make you light as a feather (advised for escaping from fire and ice!). Generally speaking, and that is the second comparison to Spelunky, you should be able to get through even with your base equipment, since Crypt of the NecroDancer is mostly skill and Rhythm based. However, getting a Bow, Spear, Long Sword or other weapons will give you more range and/or different attack patterns which you can use to get an advantage over your fellow Golems, Goblins, Slimes, Bats and many, many more monsters. The variety of enemies is huge and you will learn to love and hate most of them.Each Zone is separated in three level Levels with a mini boss at the end (you will love Red Dragons) and one Boss Level. For the first three Zones, you will face a random Boss, the fourth has a special one. The boss fights have unique songs and all very well done, reaching from playing a well paced Chess game to keeping the beat against a Death Metal Skeleton Master.The is also a roster of different characters with varying difficulty to them. Your standard character is Cadence and she is pretty straight forward, while other characters have some unique movement patterns or restrictions attached to them. If you feel like playing a classic roguelike game, you can choose the Bard. With him, you don't have to follow the beat. You make a move and then the monsters move afterwards. He is best used for learning patterns but be warned: it`s possible that you will struggle a bit with normal characters when you switch back to them. Another noteworthy character is Adria, if you screw up with the beat than you will face the fate of instant Death. Best used to either challenge yourself or to practice performing well under the positive stress of the beat ^^The game also offers a Daily Challenge, a seeded run that is the same for all players. You can also play in local co-op (the mode is a bit easier) with your buddies. And if you feel like it, you can also use a Dance Pad for it.All in all, I can recommend this game completely. It has been my go-to example of well done Early Access games and now that it is released, it's as of now my game of the year 2015. What is left to be said is me wishing you fun with it and thanking the awesome developers for listening to community feedback and polishing their game up to this gem that we have now.Since I reviewed this game, it also got some free, well done soundtracks added. Good to see such great long term support for a game.

												Crypt of the Necrodancer has very good art direction, an amazing soundtrack and a stunning and innovative new mechanism, which forces you to dance through the dungeon to the beat of the soundtrack.I think the game concept is brilliant and really well executed. The soundtrack is worth buying on its own.However, I did not enjoy the game for much more than an hour.I pretty much have a non-existing feeling for rhythm and as such, the game was quite frustrating for me, as I was not able to make any progress.There is a character available from the start to redemy this, which does not require dancing to the soundtrack, but without it this central mechanism there are many more dungeon crawlers suited for that kind of playstyle.Verdict: Awesome, if you have rhythm, mediocre if you have none!

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												With 92 hours at the time of this review, I think its finally time I sat down and wrote a good review for this game. This review is going to be in a pro-con format so yah. Review Time! Pros -The story is very well made and interesting, and a good motivator to keep trying to beat the first character (Cadence)-Rhythm and Roguelike mashups that works perfectly-Nice difficulty curve-Lots of variety in runs and characters, so as to not feel repetitive (which it doesn't)-Amazing soundtrack with now 4 different variants (2 of them you can only get through workshop mods)-Every death is your fault, not the games-The gameplay is spot on, with each weapon feeling really fun to play-Local Co-op is very fun to play and is executed well-Amazing community-Practically infinite replayability with all the achievements and things to unlock-Steam Achievements/Steam trading cards-And so much more Neutral -The game is very difficult to get the hang of, considering its very different from other roguelikes (this isn't a bad thing, it's just a thing I thought I'd point out-Some of the characters are pretty difficult (Once again, not a bad thing, just something I thought I would point out.) Cons -Part of the story is unlocked by Aria, who is a VERY difficult character to beat, or even get anywhere with (luckily youtube exists)-Coda-That's it reallyOverall I give this game a 10/10. This game is honestly the best roguelike Ive ever played, with its awesome replayability, cool characters and a very interesting story, and its gameplay is spot onVery much recommend!

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the NeroDancer is a very well executed game. The genre is a mix between rhythm and a dungeon crawler in which leaves the game with a new feeling I've never experienced. There is a lot to learn and a lot experience due to the random generation system that it features. The game is another one of those games where you must learn the tricks and rules that the game has laid out for you. Cause of this you feel like it is your fault when you make a mistake, and you will learn from them constantly. Crypt of the NecroDancer features one of the best OSTs I have ever heard, the rhythm and styles of the songs are varied (Note you can also add your own music. This system works quite well I found and it picks up the beat well.) . There are many unlocks (Items, spells, character upgrades, etc.) for it being in an early stage such as it is. This allows for variety in the way you dance your way through dungeons. This game also features unlockable characters that have their own gimmicks which change gameplay. I personally found myself playing as the main protagonist the most, but it is nice to have the option. Another feature in which I like is the ability to face against different mobs and bosses in a controlled environment. This will allow you to learn their patterns and figure out what works best against them. Recently added is the level editor in which allows a player to construct massive complex dungeons. Either that or try out different weapons and scenarios. Overall Crypt of the NecroDancer is a fantastic game in which will more than likely produce more than enough fun and frustration. I'd give this game a 9/10

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												"No. This is a joke. This has to be a joke."Said everyone ever when they first saw this game.I didn't come in expecting much. "Oh, it's a 8-bit 'rythm based rogue-like'. Bet the devs made this on their coffee break at Starbucks."My expectations were blown out of the water.First of all, it's hard. Like, actually hard. Yes, a ton of challenge comes from keeping the beat. And yes, the musically-challenged will suffer with this game. (Assuming you don't pick The Bard, who isn't affected by the music at all.)But the real challenge comes from all the enemies. They all have different patters that you have to memorize learn. It never felt like memorization. You can see every enemy well in advance, and the paths aren't too complex outside of the bosses.Secondly, it has a ton of depth.There are dozens of items. Nothing out of The Binding of Isaac or Risk of Rain, but enough to make the average indie rogue-like feel scared. They all fit into specific item slots: Head, Chest, Feet, Ring, Bag, Item, Magic, Weapon, and I'm probably forgetting something. Not only that, but all the weapons have specific types that alter in power and fighting style. No spoilers as to all the different weapons, but you will very quickly discover the strengths and weaknesses of all the weapons.And lastly, it's fun!The story is surprisingly strong. All the enemies are fun to fight. All the items feel unique. The music is great...Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game I'd highly suggest at least checking out. It might not be worth buying for those who aren't interested in Rogue-Likes or aren't very musically tallented, but I'd beg you to at the very least watch some gameplay footage of it.

								I can't get over how good the music is in this game. The gameplay itself is really simple, but incredibly difficult to get the hang of though. You need to constantly have a sense of rythmn to bop and tap along to. Once you understand what to do, its then time to worry about the endless items, chess games, conga lines, seemingly unkillable dragons, creepy- yet weirdly funky skellingtons, fake chests, fake walls, hot coals of death, combo-braking ice, rip-off shopkeeper, secret rooms, poisonous mushrooms and massive annoying trolls. Then theres the different playstyles of each character that you can play. Then there's the permadeath hardcore mode to try and master where you have to do all zones and conga-line bosses (God I hate the conga lines), or chessboard bosses in one run.Overall a neat little game worth getting.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												My first serious review.  This game has changed my opinion so much from the first time I played it I wanted to write this incase I can convince at least one other person who may have had similiar feelings as me when I first played it.I tried playing this game a few times as Cadence when I first got it.It was somewhat fun, although not enough to keep my attention.Then I tried playing as the Bard.  It was fun not having to worry about the beat of music, and instead just learning enemy movement and attack patterns.When you play as the Bard the whole game becomes turn-based.  Each move you make causes the enemies to do one movement.A solid rogue-like.  You basically play over and over until you get familiar with all the enemies, each time you feel yourself getting better and better at this game.I was in zone 2.  Just doing another run, when it hit me.  Even as the Bard I found myself moving to the beat of the music.  I was using my shovel to dig through dirt which added its own sound to the music playing.  I was realizing that some of the movements I was making when fighting a particular enemy was almost like doing dance moves.It hit me.  This game is freaking genius.  Playing through a few times as the Bard is almost a necessity and I wish the game developers would have somehow made it more obvious that this should be a first step.Binding of Isaac used to be my favorite Rogue-Like, now I can say without a doubt this is my new favorite.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Steam is full of many indie greats. Brilliant, inventively crafted games that spring out of nowhere, and create gameplay formulas so well refined they earn themselves a place within the halls of all the greatest classic.Whether its the addictive simplicity of One Finger Death Punch, the relaxing, almost zen like experience of playingE uro Truck simulator, or the stylish assassinating that makes Mark of the Ninja so great, there are countless titles on this services whose quality is very difficult dispute.Crypt of the Necrodancer is one of those games.The game hits you right from the get go with its gorgeously bright pixel art, which serve far more purpose than simply creating being a retro aesthetic.The sharp, bright visuals bring the levels to life in a way that serves the gameplay perfectly, the vibrantly animated enemies movement (and dancing) to the beat in beautiful detailed fashion. The distinctively detailed enemy sprites don't just look great  - they serve to help you plan your attacks, always allowing you to quickly figure out what is going on, even when the hectic beat of the game's brilliant music threatens to eclipse your hand eye coordination.The bosses especially are a treat, but I don't want to spoil those here. You'll just have to buy the game and discover what they are like for yourself!Don't be at all surprise if you lose track of time playing this game. Progress is undeniably challenging but it has the "one more go" feeling down to perfection. The more you play, the more you learn the important strategies needed to beat the dozens of different enemies you encounter, the best items to help you progress, and the endless number of secrets. Then you unlock a new character, and the cycle beings all over again.There is nothing else like this game on the market, and there may never be again. On the surface it is like many rogue-likes, challenging and requiring plenty of time, patient and skill on your behalf, but its rhythmic beat is an addiction that completely changes the way you explore, the way you fight, and the way you win. If you have no sense of rhythm, this is not the game for you.This game deserves you attention.Did I mention Crypt of the Necrodancer's music is amazing? I did? Well, I'm telling you again. The music is amazing. The game is worth it for the music alone.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												A music game and a unforgiving dungeon crawler with heavy roguelike elements, all in one game. And it's not just a dungeon crawler with music game elements, or a music game with a dungeon crawl attached, it's a near seamless hybrid of both in a way that I never could have thought would work. But it does, so very well.A soundtrack by Danny Baranowsky means it's going to be good, and the tunes go well with the rapid, split-second pace you need to keep in order to stay ahead of the game. I'm not sure if it's extremely difficult or I just plain suck, but I still have yet to get overly far in it and consistently blunder into enemies as I try to stay on time to the beat so as not to lose my combo. It's embarrassing, really. But my own suckitude aside, this is a game that's just so much fun, especially once you start getting into the zone and responding to things before your brain can really process them. It strangely reminds me of Hotline Miami in that sense, but with less ultraviolence and more dancing skeletons. It is also now out of early access, and features a whole campaign, tons of unlockables and player characters with different playstyles, and daily challenges to keep you coming back. I must have rage quit this game a dozen times already but I keep wanting more, and it probably has something to do with those infectious beats. Nothing else is like it, and nothing else could do what it does as well as it does.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Boy, This gameI love it, Moving around to the beat is a cool concept, And with the release of all of these soundtracks, There's tons that it naturally offers music-wiseAnd even if you don't want to listen to any of the five base soundtracks, You can even play to your own music, Which it naturally picks up the beat forWhat problems do I have? Well I suppose there's that sometimes the difficulty ramps up Immensely, But that's fun in its own right, Relying on luck helps to give pretty much everyone a chanceIt's interesting how it originally arose from time-based turn-based dungeon crawling and now it's all this, This amazingly fun and slightly addicting roguelike rhythmic dungeon crawler that everyone's lovingNow, Some notes for those of you who are a little suspicious of what this game might have to offerIf you don't like following the beat of the music, Well actually you're already prepared for! The bard turns the game from fighting the clock to a straight up strategy game where you can move whenever you want, And everything moves after you doIf the game's too slow, Bolt has you covered, Bard does too really, Bolt semi-requires you to move at twice the speed you'd normally have to move, But if that's too fast just know you're not FORCED to move at double speed (like Coda does)Now if the game's too fast you're semi-♥♥♥♥edYou COULD set your own custom music at a pace you're capable of handling, But then you're not using the default music, In case you wanted to do that, But none of the characters allow for halved beats or anything except for the Bard who doesn't have beatsDoes the game have diverse foes and 'friends' (as in playable characters here)? Yes, Yes it does10 characters, Each with their own rules and abilities, And a Lot of enemies to learn and dance withZone 4's a really interesting zone to work with with what it gives, But I won't spoil anything for anyone who wants a fresh experienceDoes the game challenge you? Oh hell yes it doesThis game will beat you down a lot if you don't learn how to give those beatbound beatdowns (haha that almost rhymed)Remember what Eli taught you, "Every enemy has a predictable pattern, If you learn those patterns, You won't suffer so much as a single scratch", Very important words (Also ♥♥♥♥ the bats, They don't follow a pattern except for "every x beats, i will move some way", So just stay out of their way when necessary)Is it fun? Depends on what it decides to give you and what you do with those items, Or if you go for no items, And if you actually like the game itselfThere are a lot of items and a lot of enemies to contend with, Some of the items will reward you for taking risks, Like sticking to half a heart for immense damage, Some of them will rewards you for not missing a beat (however no items will reward you for missing beats, so keep that in mind)Other items require you to be strategic or to not rush ahead too much in certain areas, Like the whip, Which gives you a good sideways range, But can get you killed if you're trying to move off hot coals and there are things in just two corners around you, Same with the spear, longswords or bows in directly forwards directionsSomething that could make it really fun is challenging yourself in many ways, Including (a way in which it rewards you for doing with an achievement) Not grabbing any items besides coins in two different situationsNow if you don't like the game itself, You're fine to hate it, I'll accept you not liking how it works, Or even how it looks, Atleast you triedAll in all, I really like this game, The diversity in items, weapons, equipment and enemies really is worked in well here, And with it all based around moving to a set speed based on the beat of the music is a very new concept to the dungeon crawler/roguelike area

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the Necrodancer is a game with admirable paicing, even allowing players to choose their own pace with differing characters and custom music. Whilst still W.I.P. I have not noticed a single bug so far, that or my sense of immersion to the actual game in terms of the music and the battling of monsters is just that great that I miss those bugs. Either way, the game is looking great, players new to this game will quickly get punished by the games relentless dedication to movement/rythm based fighting, often meaning that anyone who jumps in unprepared will end up dying a lot.What does this say about the game? Maybe for the common, run of the mill gamer it might mean frustrating and unpreventable deaths. But to the dedicated gamer, those who use tutorials or at least have played a rythm game of some kind can grasp that everything requires key timing and a suprisingly large amount of strategy.Do I reccomend this game? Yes. As of this moment its £10.99 ($17.94, €13.85), if you have the money, I fully reccomend buying and trying this game to anyone who is interested in it. More importantly I reccomend it as a backing to this genre of gaming as it is not often you see Rythm based games being produced. I know right now that more and more companies are making music based rythm games, but there needs to be a larger supply of them. With the people who made this game I do hope they make more like this as this genre is genrally underated, undersold and the variety of game titles is just too small.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												I bought this game on sale and figured I'd get around to playing it eventually. Later that day, I sat down to play a different game, but decided to start Crypt of the NecroDancer up just to check it out.The next thing I knew, two hours had passed and it was time to get ready to leave to go to my in-laws for Christmas. I grabbed my laptop and installed it real quick so I could play it while I was out of town (the system requirements are really low, so it ran just fine).It might be one of the most addictive games I've ever played. I don't know how many times I've told myself, "Just one more round," only to spend another hour with it.It's also very challenging in a Dark Souls kind of way. If you die, it's probably your fault. Instead of becoming frustrated, I only felt encouraged to try again and pay more attention to the movement patters of the enemies.Also, the soundtrack is fantastic. So many of the songs get stuck in my head, which just makes me want to play it more.It's my game of the year for 2015, hands down.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
Early Access Review
Crypt of the NecroDancer is IncredibleI got this game expecting to have a few hours of fun and then get bored. 20 hours of play time later, this is still not the case.This game is almost therapeutic to me. I have a lot of anxiety issues, and this game is such a great way to get my mind off of things. Just go with the flow and listen to some great music by Danny Baranowsky.Also, the customizability in this game is great. I do a lot of sprite work, so I've already sprited one of my original characters into the game. You can add your own music as well, but I have not explored this feature yet, so I cannot vouch for it.This game is also a great way to get some fun exercise if you have a dance pad. I bought a dance pad just to use it with this game.Even though this game is still in Alpha, I cannot recommend Crypt of the NecroDancer enough. The art style is great, the music is by Danny B so it's amazing by default, and it is fun to play. Get this game. Throw your money at this game. If you like rougelike games and have a good sense of rhythm, you will not regret your purchase.

												Picked up on sale.  Another rogue-like game to enjoy.  The idea of movement based on the beat makes this game require some quick thinking. Fun game for sure and pretty cool when you start to add your own songs into each of the levels.  Worth the pickup, but dont expect to be spending 100+ hours unless you have an extensive music library.

Early Access Review
								YES.I never knew how much I needed a blend of roguelike and rhythm but this is all I wanted and all I never knew I wanted.Yes. This is exactly it. I love dungeoncrawlers. I love randomly-generated dungeoncrawlers. But there have always been something missing. Yes, the difficult combat, the constantly changing experience, making strategies against specialized enemies, those are all great, but there have always been something missing. Now I know what that is.Good God, that is dancing. W-wouldn't Recettear have been even better if you had to dancefight? Dungeons of Dredmor? Chocobo's Dungeon? Nethack? Or the game that gave the genre its name, Rogue?Yes. Yes it would. Don't fight me on this or by God I will dance you to the ground.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
tl;dr -> Played this game, now I can't help but bob my head and bounce on my feet whenever I'm walking and hear an EDM beat. 11/10 disco dungeon dance-off simulator.NOTE: You can read my full review here[theroguereviews.com]I was fortunate enough to receive this as my first-ever review copy (yay!). Very, very excited to try this game because I adore the rogue-like genre and enjoy beatmatching when I mix my electronic dance music (EDM) at home. Crypt hit on many of the themes and concepts that I’ve always loved, and I thoroughly enjoyed my gameplay experience. This is easily one of the best staples available in the rogue-like genre.If you like rogue-likes, rhythm mechanics, dungeon crawling, electronic music (Danny Baranowsky’s score), and constantly unlocking new things, then you will really love this game.The aesthetics are great – the amount of detail in the different levels and characters is well-done. The retro, pixel graphics combine with the electronic musical score to provide a very fun, fast-paced experience reminiscent of old-school arcade games (including the high difficulty that usually accompanied them). Danny Baranowsky’s music is critical to the gameplay – since you have to time your movements with the beat – and fits well with the heavy rogue-like elements found in the game. If you are partial to electronic music, then you will enjoy the great soundtrack. If you don’t, however, like EDM and/or Danny’s style, then you can always use your own music (MP3 format). There is a unique track for each level, and you have the option of loading your own playlist for each level. Note, I have a very wide taste in music, so I tried an assortment of genres – EDM tracks work very well with the rhythm mechanics (because of the consistent beats per minute), but Ariana Grande (I love her) songs DO NOT work very well. That being said, Danny’s composition is fantastic, and I don’t mind replaying levels over and over again, listening to the same tracks every time. Another advantage of using EDM tracks in a custom playlist is the length – the levels end in line with the track playing, so EDM’s lengthier (on average) playtime gives you more opportunity to explore the floor. The story involves you falling into a dungeon, your heart being magically tied to an ominous beat that you must dance to.The controls are fairly easy to learn – a tutorial is offered that teaches you the basics of gameplay. I personally prefer using a controller over the keyboard, and I suggest you use that instead. The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with rogue-likes and/or rhythm games. Before you start playing, you will have to do a latency test for visual (the heartbeats and beat prompts) and auditory (the actual beat) cues; you can redo the test whenever you want. There is an “easy” mode that you can play, however, I sincerely think you will find a fair challenge playing the regular difficulty. Also, if you want a break from the beatmatching, you can play as a character (Bard) who does not have to move in time with the beat.Difficulty is something this game does very well, especially for a rogue-like. Characters you unlock will usually have harder playing conditions (ex: cannot kill enemies, die when you pick up gold), ramping up the challenge factor. To combat this, you can unlock a character/room that allows you to practice against the different enemies you may encounter – this allows you to recognize their movement/attack patterns and how to best deal with them. A character/room also exists that allows you to train against mini- and regular bosses. I highly recommend you at least check these out once you have them available, especially if you are having difficulty progressing through the levels. There is even a room that provides levels where you can learn advanced tactics, like how to kill the shopkeeper in different ways. I appreciate this approach to difficulty because it provides you with the tools to improve your playstyle, should you so choose.Gameplay involves you moving around a grid-based dungeon floor, most times in synchrony with the beat (unless you are playing as the Bard). Monsters on the floor also move in time with the beat, and they attack based on a chess/checkers-style pattern – if you move onto a tile that a monster was about to move to, you will take damage. Also, if you move into the attack range (varies based on the monster) of a monster, you will take damage if it is ready to attack – they usually have an animation cue (ex: skeletons raise their arms) to let you know an attack is incoming. To take advantage of monster movements (all units have to move each beat, or “turn.”), you can do things like backtrack or hit a wall (which will keep you on the same tile). As you progress through the level, monsters will drop gold. To increase the amount of gold dropped, you will have to build up your gold multiplier by hitting all track beats (when you move/attack) within a small window. Every time you miss a beat or take damage, your multiplier will decrease by an increment. Picking up armor will decrease how much damage you take, but will not affect your multiplier. Gold is used to purchase items from the large variety of stores available. Multipliers are especially effective when paired with multiplier-based equipment (ex: damage dealt is based on your current multiplier).Overall, the game is an immense amount of fun and always a fair, interesting challenge.If you are any bit interested in the rogue-like series or rhythm gameplay, then I implore you to give this game a try. It definitely is one of the best rogue-like titles available today.ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue ReviewsMy Website[theroguereviews.com]

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
Early Access Review
Unexpectedly Brilliant!I had been browsing Steam for at least an hour, looking for something that might hold my interest for more than a few minutes. By the time this game turned up, I was not very hopeful. The gloomy title conjured up images of a tedious slog through yet another Tolkein knock-off world. The screenshots reminded me of a hundred junk titles that bill themselves as "retro" and "8-bit" to lure long-time gamers into parting with their money in a quest to recapture good memories from their childhood. The description, touting the unlikely fusion of roguelike and rhythm genres, left me almost certain that this was nothing more than a concept gimmick that would fail to meet even the lowest of expectations.I could not have been more wrong.Crypt of the NecroDancer is the most inspired, refreshing contribution to gaming that I have encountered in years. This game blends the simplest and most predictable mechanics with enough variety to be challenging and so much creativity that even casual players will have a whole lot of goofy fun. I've played countless times over the past few weeks, died in most of them, and found myself smiling anyway, because it was almost always my own fault rather than the result of an impossible situation or bad user interface, and because it's easy to jump right back in.Each creature has a specific pattern of movement with consistent restrictions, and is easily identifiable on sight, so you can usually predict what it will do next. It will always move on the beat of the music. Press one of the four direction buttons, and you'll move, interact with an obstacle, or attack an enemy in that direction. Do it on the beat, or you'll be sorry. Use items from your inventory by pressing two buttons at once. Following these rules, you'll find yourself learning the patterns of movement (or dances) required to subdue each monster and make your way deeper into the dungeon.On top of that solid foundation sits a cast of unique bosses, playable characters with different abilities, unlockable upgrades, training areas, cooperative mode, instant replays, a level editor, gamepad and dance mat support, cross-platform compatibility, a surprisingly good chiptune-style soundtrack, and the ability to import whatever music your dungeon-crawling heart desires.And it's still only an alpha.Outstanding work, Brace Yourself Games. You shattered the preconceptions of this linux-using nethack fan. Now take my money.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Fun, original, and imaginative take on the Gauntlet-styled dungeon-crawler. As you can guess from the trailers (and title), NecroDancer is a brilliant twist on the "keep-the-beat" music games such as Guitar Hero, Elite Beat, and Dance Dance. The graphics are nice and clean. Enemies are well-designed. Levels are procedurally generated ala Diablo, but are small enough that you don't ever feel frustrated or lost. The game has a very gradual difficulty curve that starts out easy but can become quite challenging. There are many different characters to unlock with their own playstyles and challenges, including a class that doesn't even have to keep the beat at all, for those of you who would like to just play at your own tempo (or have a poor sense of musical timing.)The highlight of the game is of course the absolutely fantastic soundtrack, but even if you're not a fan of the music itself, you can just set up your own playlist and play along with whatever music you like.I very strongly recommend this game at any price point!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Crypt of the NecroDancer has ruined my life. I hear its catchy tunes in my head while I eat. I tap out the rhythm of dungeons in my car. And my children keep asking me what that funky song I'm humming all the time is. I can't stop thinking about this game, despite the fact it is deceptively hard and I may never actually get past Zone 3. So let me tell you why you should suffer the same fate.In classic roguelike tradition, Crypt is an adventure through randomly-generated dungeons with randomly-generated loot to find and use on randomly-generated monsters. It's all laid out in a pleasing grid of pixel art, controlled solely with the arrow keys. Special items are used by pressing two directions at once, and attacks are as simple as pushing towards an enemy in range. Unlike other roguelikes, there's no random element to attacks. Everything has a set number of hearts, and if you hit it (or it hits you), you take the prescribed amount of damage. Monsters have set patterns to their attacks, meaning there are really no surprises to combat.The catch here is that everything is set to the music, and you have to move on the beat. Enemies won't wait for your turn, either, because they're jamming to the same rhythm. Miss a beat and you effectively lose your turn. Suddenly this otherwise simple, predictable game becomes one of concentration and quick thinking. You need to be moving or attacking with every beat, and if you're focusing on keeping cadence, you're not focusing on strategy. Fortunately the game is desgined with this in mind, offering a robust tutorial, multiple practice modes, and even a second character unlocked from the start that can ignore the beat. There are four zones to conquer, each three levels and a boss. Beating the previous one unlocks the next, allowing you to skip ahead. You can also collect diamonds to purchase upgrades and new items to add to the random pool.There's a terrible secret behind this welcoming facade, though. All of this is essentially an elaborate, extended tutorial for All Zones mode, which challenges you to beat all four zones in order, starting with the full item pool unlocked but no upgrades to your character. This is the proper roguelike mode for the game, and it is incredibly difficult to get through. Missed beats and damaging mistakes mount up fast enough to make beating individual zones a challenge, and starting essentially from scratch means your strategies have to be second nature. Unless the rhythm is in your blood, mastering Crypt is going to take a lot of time and a lot of practice.Don't let that dissuade you from trying the game, of course. There's plenty to see and do even if you never touch All Zones mode. The many characters to unlock play like entirely different games, and you can access quite a few just by playing the individual zones. As expected from a rhythm-based game, the soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal and is sure to get permanently stuck in your head. Even if you keep getting mauled by mambo'ing skeletons, you're sure to come back for more. I really may never get past Zone 3 but I'm having too much fun to stop now.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												This game is pretty fun for a while, until the novelty fades. But as some others have pointed out, it's not just really difficult, it's just flat out unfair at times. After countless deaths, and getting nowhere with certain characters (which you need to finish the game with to unlock others) such as the Monk that DIES when he touches gold, the game just becomes a frustration and it's obvious the insane difficulty is being used to pad the game which has quite a lack of content. There are only four levels (with four stages each) and if you are able to complete the game you can do so in about 30 minutes or less. Now, I could understand the Monk being harmed for touching gold, but dying just for touching it seems a bit ridiculous to me. Then there's Eli, who can kick bombs (of which he has an infinite supply). Sound badass? He's not. That's his only weapon and when you come across the enemies that push you around the map it's almost impossible to kill them without hurting yourself first. To make matters worse, instead of having several completely different sounding songs to play on each level, there are only a few (you need to turn them on by yourself) that are more like remixes. You have the option to add your own music to the game, but no random option for that. This has apparently been in the works for 2 years. Unless you have a lot of patience to lose over and over, playing for hours and accomplishing nothing, I wouldn't recommend this game. Once again, it was fun for a while, but I think I will quit before I break another keyboard.

								What a phenomenal game, I just played it for 40 minutes as of writing this review and I am addicted, I can hear the beat in my ear and it won't go away, GOD HELP MECrypt of the NecroDancer is a must get for any roguelikes fan, if you are not a fan of rougelikes then it depends, but you still gotta try it if the price allows, it is a standard roguelike that follows a gradual upgrade system, you get to slowly expand your library of items by purhasing item upgrades and also permanent hp upgrades and whatnot, what makes this SO special is the twist of music, basically its a game with aweosme music playing in the background and you are required to play by the beat of the music, with every beat you get to perform one action, move, attack, move, attack,move,move,move,move,attack all following the beat of the music,with each enemy having a unique moving pattern, shops and whatnot, this game is beautiful in its very unique and brilliant way, as of right now it is still in early access but it has every right to be full released because right now its just slowly being updated with new stuffs, the gameplay is already 10/10 solid

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is an amazing take on the Dungeon Crawler genre while also putting in a spice of rhythm making the game enjoyable and better to listen to. Every rhythm game needs a decent soundtrack to succeed. Not only did Danny B. (Also known for his music in BoI and Super Meat Boy) fill this quota but Rival (known for his Electro Dubstep type music) and FamilyJules (Creator of several Metal Covers on OSTs.) made this game's soundtrack amazing. Not only that, but the characters are rememberable and make you actually feel for them, giving you different gameplay for each character, which is where Crypt of the Necrodancer gets it's replayability. These are the reasons why I still come back every day to this game. The art looks fresh and actually makes you wanna stop and see how your character moves to the beat of the music. This game also supports Steam Workshop, giving you the ability to play as a jiggling piece of bread if you wanted to. All of this for the decent price of $14.99 makes me believe that ANYONE, whether you enjoy Roguelike Dungeon Crawlers or the Music Lover that listens to game soundtracks in their daily lives can enjoy Crypt of the Necrodancer.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm having great fun with this game.  More than that, I'm fully loving it!It's a unique and wonderful idea to combine a rhythm dancing game with true rogue-like gameplay.  The game has a great range of pickups, gameplay options, different playable characters, etc.  It just feels so well made.Necrodancer has a brilliant soundtrack by Danny Baronowsky, who also did the music for Super Meat Boy.  I'll buy any game with his name on it, no questions asked!  (and the soundtrack too)They've made the game cross-platform for Linux / Mac / Windows.  I do 99% of my gaming on Linux and I really appreciate the Linux support.You can play with keyboard or a controller, or real dance pads.  I've ordered a pair of dance pads to play it the hard way.  I might even get fit.  There's a two-player co-op option, so I can play with my wife or kids and use both the pads.  The game is challenging enough with plenty of variety to keep me playing while I lose some weight necrodancing like a fool!Although this is an early access game, it already has more options and features than most "full release" games:  training halls to practice battling different monsters and bosses (if you can pay the entry fee!), a huge variety of pickups and upgrades, hardcode mode, local co-op, daily challenge...  I don't recall another game with so many great options.  The procedural generation gives a great variety of levels, on a par with Spelunky.In short, buy this game already!

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												There's lots of ways to define a good game, none of which are necessarily wrong. Instead of saying what makes this game good, I'll say what makes playing it more enjoyable.When a game has nice gameplay, you can typically tell. When a soundtrack was made to compliment said gameplay, you can also tell. The music in NecroDancer was more than made to compliment the gameplay; it was made to be a key part of gameplay, as well as to simply enjoy - whether that be in-game or on it's own. You can even implement your own music if you so choose, furthering the possibilities.Now, as for the overall gameplay, I'll make this simple:- Do you like dungeon crawlers?- Do you like Rougelikes?- Do you like pixelated graphics?- Do you like kick♥♥♥♥♥soundtracks?- Do you like Metal or EDM?If you said yes to any of these, I suggest giving NecroDancer a try.If you said yes to a 2 or more of these, I HIGHLY recommend giving NecroDancer a try.If you said yes to all of these, why the hell haven't you played it yet?! This game was made for you!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								With only three hours in this game, it's already my third favorite indie game of all time (behind Bastion and To the Moon). An extremely difficult permadeath game, Crypt Of The Necrodancer is one of the few difficult games I have that manages to be difficult, but not ragequit material. Every death feels fair- you died because you have something else to learn about that enemy, or you weren't prepared enough. It's rather frustrating for a little after you're thrown into a new zone to relearn different strategies for the new monsters, but the moment you manage to finally figure out what to do it's a wave of power unlike anything. And then you die to another monster and try again- but you don't care because now you're one step closer. The music is fantastic (though the shopkeeper's voice is slightly annoying) and moving to it becomes very simple because of how well written the music is. I haven't tried with custom music yet, but I'm looking forward to it and continuing to play the game.

Early Access Review
								This game is the best rhythm game I have ever played. The game is not finished but it is still really good. If you like games where you kill monsters in classic pixel lands, then you should play this. Be wary of a steep learning curve though, it takes time to get used to moving to the rhythm and slaying beasts. While you can change the music on this game I have yet to do so. The music is good enough to listen to for hours on end. The music is made by Danny Baranowsky the creator of many amazing game sound tracks such as Super Meat Boy. There is also a hardcore mode where you get no upgrades and have to start from the ground up each death. You can also do this as a daily challenge to see how you stack up to other players traversing the same dungeon layout as you.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm having great fun with this game.  More than that, I'm fully loving it!It's a unique and wonderful idea to combine a rhythm dancing game with true rogue-like gameplay.  The game has a great range of pickups, gameplay options, different playable characters, etc.  It just feels so well made.Necrodancer has a brilliant soundtrack by Danny Baronowsky, who also did the music for Super Meat Boy.  I'll buy any game with his name on it, no questions asked!  (and the soundtrack too)They've made the game cross-platform for Linux / Mac / Windows.  I do 99% of my gaming on Linux and I really appreciate the Linux support.You can play with keyboard or a controller, or real dance pads.  I've ordered a pair of dance pads to play it the hard way.  I might even get fit.  There's a two-player co-op option, so I can play with my wife or kids and use both the pads.  The game is challenging enough with plenty of variety to keep me playing while I lose some weight necrodancing like a fool!Although this is an early access game, it already has more options and features than most "full release" games:  training halls to practice battling different monsters and bosses (if you can pay the entry fee!), a huge variety of pickups and upgrades, hardcode mode, local co-op, daily challenge...  I don't recall another game with so many great options.  The procedural generation gives a great variety of levels, on a par with Spelunky.In short, buy this game already!

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is hands down one of the best examples of why Early Access should be a thing. Amongst the piles of early access games that are slow to update, have uncommunicative developers, and don't strives for self-improvement, Crypt of the NecroDancer continues to add more content and build upon itself.And it is ALREADY worth its price.A clever blend of rhythm game and rogue-like, Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fun challenge that urges your every move to be carefully thought out and chosen...in the length of a beat. The music is incredibly catchy, the bosses and characters are charming, the design is delightfully elegant, and the different playstyles made available always keep things fresh. And there's still more characters, zones, and content to come!I've yet to try out the importing of custom music, nor have I used the custom level editor to its fullest potential. But I honestly can't say I'm missing out; I'm still addicted to the game's levels as they are!Do yourself a favor. Buy it. Support the developers. And bide your time until you can confront the NecroDancer in a lethal tango.

								Highly recommended.Plays like a full release - though content is still being added and refined all the time.Terribly fun, and perhaps addicting. Don't loose the beat. You have very limtied health, and really the game is not very forgiving. You get hit, and it's a serious thing. Best part is that you have only yourself to blame. Except for red bats. Screw red bats. If you can get someone for local co-op, that's quite fun as well.Since the levels are procedural, and you never really get good enough that you never die, and you can even play your own songs (thought theirs are really good anyway), the games has tons of playability and hours in it. Another good thing is that it doesn't take long to play. It's not like an rpg or something where you'll waste away playing it. 3 minutes of this game feels like 30 minutes of most other games. So sure, you won't waste time playing it, but you also won't waste time playing it.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												Since its alpha phase, Crypt of the NecroDancer has held a ton of promise.  As it's grown into its full release, Crypt has added multiple characters, an expansive monster bestiary, and not one, but two extra arrangements of the already-amazing soundtrack.This game is a rhythm-based roguelike dungeon-crawling game, but rather than carefully planning each move, you're given a time limit of a single beat of music.  Everything moves one turn on each beat, whether or not you offer an input, which means that you're constantly faced with split-second decisions which will make or break your run through each zone.Crypt offers a wide variety of play styles.  Cadence, the first playable character, is a pretty standard roguelike experience.  You take on a dungeon, probably die, and return to the lobby for some purchasable persistent upgrades.  You return to the dungeon, and the cycle continues on.  Later, you'll unlock Bard, a character whose actions are not limited by the beat of the music, and enemies only move on player actions.  And for the perfectionist, Aria offers a frustrating challenge in which missing a single beat or taking any damage is instant death.The soundtrack, which I mentioned earlier, is absolutely amazing.  Danny Baranowski (of Super Meat Boy and Binding of Isaac fame) takes center stage with the primary soundtrack.  Two other musicians -- A_Rival and FamilyJules7x -- also offer their talents to mix the game's music into heavy techno and metal arrangements, respectively.  Each of these remixed soundtracks is available to play in the game as well.  And, if you should ever get bored of that music, the game allows you to use your own music for any stage you please.I could go on for paragraphs about how great this game is, but suffice to say, it is absolutely worth experiencing for yourself.  It's well-made, it's challenging, and above all else it's just a really fun time.  Absolutely pick this game up if you have any interest in rhythm-based gameplay, roguelike dungeon-crawlers, or just generally challenging gameplay.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is an amazing take on the Dungeon Crawler genre while also putting in a spice of rhythm making the game enjoyable and better to listen to. Every rhythm game needs a decent soundtrack to succeed. Not only did Danny B. (Also known for his music in BoI and Super Meat Boy) fill this quota but Rival (known for his Electro Dubstep type music) and FamilyJules (Creator of several Metal Covers on OSTs.) made this game's soundtrack amazing. Not only that, but the characters are rememberable and make you actually feel for them, giving you different gameplay for each character, which is where Crypt of the Necrodancer gets it's replayability. These are the reasons why I still come back every day to this game. The art looks fresh and actually makes you wanna stop and see how your character moves to the beat of the music. This game also supports Steam Workshop, giving you the ability to play as a jiggling piece of bread if you wanted to. All of this for the decent price of $14.99 makes me believe that ANYONE, whether you enjoy Roguelike Dungeon Crawlers or the Music Lover that listens to game soundtracks in their daily lives can enjoy Crypt of the Necrodancer.
