number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I love games that make sense of old gaming tropes and conventions; in this case, how about the old idea that enemies in roguelikes only move when you do? The answer is, they're just moving to a beat, same as you!This idea has serious gameplay implications as well. Roguelikes were always about positioning and strategy, but let you take as much time as you wanted in between turns. The rhythm nature of this game melds it into an action game with the best of tile turn-based. Fighting enemies is an absolute joy: every time you walk into a room you have to think fast, what enemy do I prioritize and how do I position myself to attack them while keeping myself out of harm from other enemies. There are a few mechanics that really help facilitate this; for one, the control scheme is exclusively arrow keys or WASD, which means that attacking is done by pressing in the direction of an enemy, overriding a movement in that direction. This can play to your advantage or disadvantage depending on your weapon and circumstance, which just increases the layers of things to think about. It also means you can play the game on a dance pad if you want to, with no compromises. The one downside is that using subitems like consumables and spells is done by pressing combinations of those direction keys, which doesn't really feel great and you'll often forget which thing is bound to which button combo. It can screw you up in a frantic moment.The other element really strengthens the rhythm game connection: a multiplier. If you can keep landing enemy kills without straying off beat, you'll earn a coin multiplier, which is cool because coins serves as both currency and as points or high score. What makes it interesting is you lose the multiplier for using a wait command essentially, which means you have to constantly keep moving. This not only changes the tone of the game, but it makes approaching enemies interesting too, as you'll have to find another way to stay in the same spot without losing the multiplier.Then you have different items and weapon types, and what's great is that even though the very basic "attack up" weapons will change how you fight enemies, there are a lot of different types that change properties and completely change how you approach combat.Another big mechanic is that each floor is timed, and you'll be sent to the next when time runs out. This is probably an improvement over other roguelikes that give you as much time as you want; at the same time, it along with the multiplier makes the game feel really frantic. While it's a cool feeling you don't really have the chance to learn what an enemy's all about in the middle of a run, you'll have to utilize the in-game beastmaster mode to learn enemy strategies. Same goes with items, you won't have a lot of time to experiment like in something like Binding of Isaac, which makes learning new items with no descriptions even more difficult than in that game. At the same time, it's better than just giving it away with a description.I guess the other big thing is that because you can't move freely, because you are forced to move at the pace the game dictates, the game doesn't give you the same sense of control as something like Binding of Isaac, at least not initially. Initially you'll be a little frustrated that you can't move at your own pace in the lobby, and even when you're having an OP run you're still at the whim of the game's pacing. This feeling diminishes over time; eventually as you master each of the beats you'll get that control you were looking for, it just takes awhile.The game has a really smart progression system early on; basically it splits each of the zones of a full length run into its own adventure, and gives you incentives to play and learn them with the diamond system which gives you permanent upgrades to your character, or new secrets in the runs. It's a really good way to learn the game but the meat and potatoes is still hardcore mode, which takes away all of those permanent upgrades and plays like a true roguelike. My problem right now is that after beating hardcore mode and unlocking the other characters there's very little incentive to continue; the new characters represent a significant jump in difficulty, and while I could dive back into each individual zone with the characters to train there's no in-game unlockables or achievements to be earned right now. I feel kind of done with it until Zone 4 rolls out.It's also not as replayable as something like Binding of Isaac, most of the nuances in the gameplay have to do with combat. There's not as much detail optimization as BoI, aside from a few things like how to find hidden passages without a torch and what to do with excess bombs.The game is ridiculously fully featured for an early access game by the way, with multiple characters, dance pad mode, daily challenge, seeded runs, custom music, and even a co-op mode which is a ton of fun.Oh and the soundtrack is what I play videogames for, I <3 Danny B.tl;dr Combat nuances and music make this game well worth buying in its current state, only problems I have with it right now are lack of progression after unlocking all the characters, less replayability than other roguelikes, and the difficulty with learning new things and feeling in control early on.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the NecroDancer is exactly what it is described as: a rogue-like rhythm game.This game is all about patterns. Each type of enemy moves to the beat in a specific way, and you need to learn these patterns to effectively defeat them.The simplistic controls are what really drive this game home. You only use four buttons to perform all of the moves in the game - up, down, left, and right, to be precise. The game's control scheme is so simple, in fact, that you can play it with a USB-enabled dance pad, like the kind used for DDR-esque games. Personally I have not tried this, though I definitely want to!Even though this game is in alpha, it is still jam-packed with features to entertain you for hours of playtime. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												This is one of the best games I've ever played and it's easily my favorite indie game to ever come out. 10/10Necrodancer follows the roguelike genre, the mechanics are simple in themselves, a tile based roguelike in which you only only move to the beat of the music. That is where the simplicity ends.In addition, each enemy has their own movement pattern, following the beats of the music. There are traps laying on the ground that control movement, send you down to the next level and ones that flat out damage you. All of this mixed together creates complex and rewarding gameplay that keeps you coming back.Being a rythm based roguelike, music is key and the game delivers in its soundtrack. The music was composed by Danny B, known for composing games such as Super Meat Boy and Binding of Issac. The tracks are perfectly suited to the style of game and will keep your head bobbing as you move to the beat. In addition, there are remixed versions of the game's soundtrack done by A_Rival and FamilyJules7x, which allow for more variety and they sound fantastic as well.But what if you get sick of the music? There is an option to import your own MP3 files into the game so you can tap along to your favorite songs as your progress through the game.The art style, while another pixel art type of deal, looks great. The enemies are unique, it's easy to distinguish them apart and easily identify what you're going to be going up against. Even after you play the game with the default character Candence, there are many more characters availible to mix up the gameplay and keep you coming back. If that wasn't enough, there is a daily challenge mode to compete in everyday to hone your skills and try to climb to the top of the leadboards; or you could just compete with your friends.I can go on and on about this game, I adore it, the gameplay, the visuals and the soundtrack amaze me, and it all blends into this perfect package of a game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
 The ingenious combo of a dungeon crawler and rhythm game. GAMEPLAYIt's a dungeon crawler rhythm game. Your movements are timed to the beat of the song, and you can't just spam movements all the time. It's simple, but is executed so well and so satisfyingly that it's become my favorite dungeon crawler (which isn't saying much as i've only played 2 at the time of this review and only have 9 hours in the other one) Since everything is timed to the beat, you're retreating with the beat. You're killing to the beat. You're flanking to the beat. You are living with the beat. This makes the game incredibly satisfying to play.Enemies play by their own rules also on the beat, which becomes incredibly complicated in the later zones where the screen gets cluttered frequently, with enemies that play by their own rules, or the same rules on different beats. Enemies can in later zones also potentially move diagonally, something you can't do, and even through walls, which never felt fair when you die to those things.There are different character types, all of whom have different styles of play. Some may be incredibly satisfying and fun, others will leave you begging for mercy and crying face down on your keyboard. A very good replay value.SOUNDTRACKKick♥♥♥♥♥ You get 3 different soundtracksDannyB-The creator of the game's original soundtrackA_Rival-The creator of the game's EDM soundtrackFamilyJules7X-The creator of the game's metal soundtrack.As well as custom .mp3 support, which is incredibly satisfying and adds even more replay value. Problem is, the beat detection can be a little off for songs with a large amount going on or different pacings (I'm looking at you, PAYDAY 2 songs)OTHERMod support, as well as a very simple to modify game.CONCLUSIONI was never a really big fan of dungeon crawlers. I always felt that, while they each did their own thing, they were pretty much the same thing in general and gameplay-wise. Crypt of the necrodancer is not "pretty much the same thing in general and gameplay-wise." It's a game that takes roots from rhythm games and dungeon crawler games to create it's own thing which is a very satisfying and fun to play game.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												~~UPDATED FOR FULL RELEASE~~Rhythm-based Rogue-Like Dungeon Crawler. Yes. Please.Everything you do is to the beat of the music, you move to the beat, attack to the beat and die to the beat. And the enemies do too. Every enemies has an attack pattern so if you can feel the beat, you can avoid taking damage, but it's not always that easy when you have a limited amount to time to react (IE. the beat) The music is the first thing you'll notice, composed by the indie game music GOD Danny B. who did the soundtracks for Binding of Isaac and Super Meat Boy (He's done many other games as well, but those two are the other two that I've played and can personally vouch for the music) so you know that the music in Necrodancer is top-notch...which is good considering that's the prime game mechanic.You'll groove your way through 4 zones, beating monsters, collecting gold, buying items and beating bosses until you reach the final boss which is sometimes different if you play the different characters. All the different characters are truly different and all play very differently and some even have limitations as to what items they can get. All the different characters ensure that you never get bored with the game and always provide a new challenge if you're feeling up for it. Played too much Cadance lately? Switch it up with Melody. Don't like how Melody plays? Try out Eli. Feeling strong with Eli? Now try Dorian. There are 10 different characters to play, including one final, truly insane challenge character that literally nobody has beaten yet so there is always something new to aim for with this game. And even if you can't play some of the harder characters like Aria, Bolt or Monk, you can always lay beatdowns to the beat with all the other characters.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Crypt of the Necrodancer delivers an innovative, challenging, fast-paced dungeon crawl experience. I was very hesitant about the concept of a "rhythm roguelike" but the game completely managed to win me over. What this title may lack in complexity compared to a more "traditional" roguelike such as Nethack or ADOM, it more than makes up for with the fresh take on roguelike gameplay that it brings to the table by limiting each turn to the length of a quarter note in the accompanying music.I highly recommend a controller/gamepad for this game. The control scheme is very general, should adapt well to any pad, and using my thumbs felt more natural and ergonomic than using the keyboard.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												Crypt of the Nercodancer is a Dungeon Crawler game mixed in with a Rythem Movement system, as in you have to move to the beat of the song.the game itself is pretty simple and Really easy to understand, The artstyle is really nice and pretty clean looking aswell and the soundtrack is easily one of the best, all 3 of them, original, EDM and Metal. Edit: 2 more were added a while ago! A chiptune soundtrack by the same person who made the shovel knight soundtrack & a Synthwave Soundtrack by Girlfriend records, Never fail to amaze with the different styles of remixes!There are 10 Characters total, Each every different things, like bolt who moves at double the speed, or Aria who can't get hit or miss a beat (as in dies in 1 hit or missing a single beat.)There are a bunch of different enemies, which also move to the beat with different patterns which are easy to understand, Each as moving every 2 beats or lunging forward after being hit once or even teleporting the player. Even if you're someone who isn't great with hearing/listening, there's a guideline sort of thing at the buttom of the screen, which you could use to learn the beat.Its a great game and i'm amazed the Devs Created this unique game. Easily Recommedable to friends, Especially with the OSTs.

								Inventive mashup of the roguelike/rythm game genres. Most innovative game I have played in a long time. If you think you will enjoy this game, I would definitely recommend it.Amazing soundtrack!Heaps of replay valueChallenging gameplay which rewards skillful execution & game knowledgeItems are really well balanced and there are very few (if any) totally useless itemsThe different weapons are varied and fun to useThere aren't many items that radically change how you approach the game from a tactical standpoint more of a mechanical/execution standpoint Balanced learning curveRange of characters that vary in difficulty/playstylePixel art may seem a little over-done in the indie genre but it is very well executed in this game and suits the tone/atmosphereDevs are adding a lot of content during early accessMinor issuesIf you are looking to play the game with your own music, the interface for adding your own music is not well suited for exploring a large music directoryThe default controller mapping is not great but it does support custom control mapping for controllers

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Give this review a reed, it will only take a minuet. Whatever expectations you have for this game are going to fall flat. The idea behind it is just so clef-er, and even in it's alpha I don't even C any minor flaws. Much less any major ones! It's especially fun if keeping a beat is your forte, and if it's giving you treble don't fret about it, you'll get it. I am no lyre, this game is amazing!Real ReviewI have to say it now, this is my new favorite rougelike game. It is  amazing ! Once you start you are not going to want to put it down. The visuals are great and apealing to look at, and all the enemies dance! How awesome is that!? And the music- OOOOH THE MUSIC -it just works...so well. I actually started typing this review before, and when I typed, "And the soundtrac-" I immediately went and bought it without realizing it would erase what I had typed! It's that good. I completely recommend buying it. And then there's the shopkeeper. His voice is the most beautiful thing you can hear while fending off skeletons that have their hands in the air like they just don't care! One thing that is terrible great about it is that when you die, it's your fault. It's because you weren't paying close enough attention, or because you didn't react fast enough. There are some times when I die that I just have to take rest...sorry, and mourn my own stupidity. The game almost never cheats you. Unless there's a red dragon. I'm sorry, that's fate, it's going to kill you. There are some enemies that seem like they do, but maybe I just don't understand them. *cough* bats *cough*[EDIT] I do have a give a fair warning though, the difficulty spikes between levels 1 and 2, and I can't even imagine 3.After playing some more, I have a few things I would like to see improved:*I think the shield skeletons need an "arms up"-like frame in their animation, it can sometimes be unclear whether they will attack or not*The red dragon is way too hard. Maybe I just suck*The ability to go from Level 1 to level 2 and so on in one run, like in daily challenges. The later levels are just way too hard to start from scratch and hope you get lucky. **More permanent upgrades, the dungeon master is hardly used after the first hour**A option/item that makes the shopkeeper always singing (perhaps if it's an item, you can see him or the music notes all the time)See, not even very many :)I haven't completed it, so maybe some things I just haven't found yet. Improvements marked ** are something I'd see coming into player after the full release

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Brace Yourself Games has developed easily one of the most creative games I've played recently.  Crypt of the Necrodancer combines the roguelike/rhythm genres to produce a dungeon crawler that summons memories of Michael Jackson's Thriller. The skeletons dance, the zombies hop, and the shopkeepers sing as you navigate through the floors of the cryptIt plays similarly to classic turn based style roguelikes, except that the turns happen on the beat of the music.  You will find yourself hopping back and forth to the beat, dodging enemy attacks, and waiting for the perfect moment to strike.  The soundtrack is great, but you can play using your own music instead if you wish.  There is also an easier difficulty setting specifically for playing the game on a dance pad.  It makes me wish I still had a DDR pad lying around, I'd love to give it a try.The parallels with classic roguelikes do not end with the turn based combat/movement system.  The floors, the contents of treasure chests, shop items, and even boss order are all randomly generated.  The game is also very challenging, quite possibly challenging enough that some players won't enjoy it if they don't like difficult games.  There are several features available to the player to mitigate the challenge.  As you play you will unlock the ability to start at each zone, buy items before entering a zone, and practice against enemies in a risk free environment.The only criticism that comes to mind about the game is the small number of zones.  There are four zones, and each zone has three stages.  The amount of content reminds me of some NES games.  Many old NES titles could be completed in less than an hour, but took much longer due to the learning required to play successfully.  While I don't feel like there are as many zones as there could have been, they did include ten playable characters.  The characters all have very different styles of play and allow for a solid level of replay value.Crypt of the Necrodancer is a lot of fun, but I think many players should be wary.  Prospective buyers may be lured in by the cute visuals and awesome soundtrack but miss an important fact about the game.  Necrodancer, at its heart, is a challenging turn based roguelike.  I've played through and finished quite a few games that most would consider to be hard.  This one is tough.  According to  Steam's global gameplay stats, 7.2% of players manage to finish the fourth zone as the main character.  If you're down for a challenge though, you'll have a great time.  I've certainly had a lot of fun with it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
EVERYBODY DO THE FLOP!After the unfair atrocity against humanity that is Spelunky, I jumped away from the rouge-lite bandwagon and started to avoid this kind of games entirely. You cannot imagine the frustration which that cursed game gave me with its extreme unpredictability of annoying enemies, dirt-poor and mostly useless item pool, random stuff blowing up in your face without your fault etc.Good thing that Crypt of the Necrodancer fixes nearly everything I listed above. Listening to the Overwhelmingly Positive rating on Steam apparently is sometimes a good idea!You can imagine the game as a mix of classic dungeon-crawling games, generic rouge-lite games, chess and DanceDance Revolution. During the proper gameplay player makes moves on tiled dungeons, trying to move, attack, defend, explore and explode to the bounce of the sickest beats. You can consider beats as a split-second turns when everybody on the level makes their action and the outcome is immediately apparent. Either you move into enemy-infested tile and attack it or they move into yours, dealing damage etc. Every action in the game is bound to the beat of boogey-man looking Necrodancer who is the main villain of this really barebones and after-thought of the story.CotN fixes EVERYTHING Spelunky screwed up. Aside of non-common bat types, every enemy has a predicable pattern you can exploit. Items you acquire throughout your adventure are varied, allowing different playstyles and strategies. There is not nigh-required Jet-Pack and Shotgun combo you need in Spelunky because in Necrodancer many combinations of items can ease the difficulty significantly. Game also doesn't screw you up unfairly too often. Most of the time you lose because of your own mistakes and not because somebody else angered the shopkeeper or that Yeti made a bouncing ping-pong ball of you, sapping your whole life in the process. You are still fragile in the game, but healing is much less a pain-in-the-butt process andit's much more reliable. Crypt still has some fair share of annoying enemies but those are much more manageable than in the other rouge-lites. There are also single-level modes (allows story progression with checkpoints between zones) and additional, harder characters, so both less-hardcores and harder that hard-hardcores are welcomed here.As for problems of the NecroDancer: bats still exist. Enemies sometimes come in crowds, making difficulty in tackling them safely. Item descriptions are vague and show up only when you approach them from tile away, from which you need to jump off immediately, forcing you to needless experimentation until you memorize the effects. Level themes are extremely generic (Mine/Forest/Ice-Fire World/Temple) which is a missed opportunity in comparison to the rest of the game (like enemies which are really imaginative with bouncy and enjoyable animations and charm).In short, Crypt of the Necrodancer in an enchanting game, full of enjoyable gameplay, good inventive ideas and incredible music (which really goes without saying that loud. Bought the soundtracks... All of them). It's must-have on the nearest occasion for everybody who isn't tone-deaf, without the sense of rhythm or satisfaction from fair challenge.Also, f*** Spelunky.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												This game fooled me, but in a good way. I was expecting a cute gimmick - a music game disguised as a rogue-like. Instead, I got a solid dungeon crawler with a musical twist.Crypt of the Necrodancer is the first game to combine two of my favorite things; EDM and The Undead. The style is cute, cohesive and somehow works without jumping the shark, which is hard to do for such an odd mix.+'s * Gameplay is solid and difficult, but not because of the musical aspect. "Spinning Plates" and managing many simple enemy patterns together takes awareness, practice and planning.* The beat is there as a turn-timer of sorts. By forcing the decisions to be quick, there's opportunities for mistakes (and therefore mastery/learning!) * Several characters with different styles, rogue-like style.* TLC put into the production value, even considering a more throwback/pixel art style.* Soundtrack is fantastic.-'s* While there's a variety of characters, the game's core gameplay has to eliminate a lot of the dungeon options and items that make the full-run version fun, meaning many of the alternate characters are less interesting than the default.* It's said before, but Aria is extremely punishing to play. This is where it truely becomes a rhythm game, but it also has the problems listed above. Not a deal-breaker, but a sore spot.Highly recommend this if you're a fan of strange mash-ups that work, or want a dungeon delver with its own unique feel and flavor. The game holds up without the music, but is greatly enhanced by having it. :)

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												You'll like this if :You are a fan of rogue likesLike SpelunkyAppreciate good game soundtracksYou'll hate this is :You have no rhythm and things like DDR drive you nutsGet bored with casual quick gamesThink old school graphics are horribleCrypt of the Necrodancer is a light rogue like game that owes a lot of its design philosophy to Spelunky. It does away with the depth of most roguelikes and instead concentrates on serving up a bite size piece of dungeon crawling in a challenging cute form, with many of the game design elements from Spelunky directly converted into its top down view point.So far, so similar.But CotND has a gimmick up its sleeve. The soundtrack. Everything in the game moves to the beat of the soundtrack, animations, movement, attacks - even your own input has to move to the beat of the soundtrack, like some mad version of Dance Dance Revolution where each step lets you explore further into the dungeon.Move out of step with the beat and you will be punished - losing bonus and also potentially missing your chance to move or attack. Learn to step with the beat, learn how the monsters move with the beat, and suddenly you will be popping along to this fiendishly addictive game.If the idea of playing a roguelike to the sound of a beat sounds weird - it kind of is. And I'll admit I wasn't entirely sure if this would turn out to be a flop or a cool idea. But once you play it, it just makes sense, and adds a very unique aspect to the game - that of timing. Where you have to move to the beat - staying still just isn't an option, and yet a move will push you into the path of a deadly foe, or out of striking range of a target. A new dimension of just how to "wait" or move in such a way as to hit an enemy becomes part of the game.The soundtrack itself that supports the main gimmick of the game is absolutely top notch, and there are a few great touches to the game - such as the singing shopkeepers - that just make this game work really very well indeed.An all round excellent experiment in combining the winning formula of Spelunky with a top down roguelike all to the beat of a soundtrack. Don't be put off because this game is kind of... left field. It manages to weld everything together beautifully, and is definitely a game where you will just want One More Try, because This Time, I've Got It.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												No joke, this was one of my favourite games of 2014.In theory, this is a really simple game.  Grid-based roguelikes have been done before.  The real seller of Crypt, however, is the impact of the game being set to music and moving rhythmically.Unlike a lot of similar games, Crypt forces you to learn and memorize patterns and react fast and skillfully, instead of spending forever mulling through cluttered inventories for the exact item to get you out of your situation.  It's about speed, snap decisions, and learning, and above all is completely fair - everything in the game could be handled flawlessly with just your starting equipment.There's a lot of other aspects that are strengths to it.  Mechanically, the game reaches an incredible level of play diversity, not just from the vastly different playable characters.  It also comes from the fact the massive pool of items are rarely just a straight upgrade over one another, and instead have different strengths, weaknesses, and benefits.  Presentation wise the game's super slick, charmingly animated, and the music is bloody amazing too.Do the thing.  Get the game.  It's amazing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is about delving into a dungeon, but you're doing so in synch with the current's level music : every action you take must be on the beat, any missed beat is slightly penalized, and enemies also move on the beat.Yet, to call Crypt of the Necrodancer "dungeon delving with music" would be to sell it short. A far better description would be "tactical turn-based game, except the turns happen on the beat". Crypt of the Necrodancer has you dancing around monsters in order to kill everything while taking as little damage as possible. You know all the monsters' patterns, there is no luck involved, it's just a matter of perfecting your counter patterns. Even the music aspect has been toned down a bit to ensure you focus more on the tactical aspect: the game doesn't require pinpoint accuracy to hit the beat, there is a fair beat of leaway, contrary to games that are purely about hitting beats (such as Dance Dance Revolution, Osu, etc...).The best example of how the game isn't just a "game with a music gimmick" is the "Bard" character. Once you've played a bit, you will unlock new characters, which are new modes of play. And Bard's mode is actually being able to play without having to worry about the beat: whenever you take an action, the ennemies do too, which mean you can play as fast or as slow as you want. And yet, despite not being time-pressured, it's still a fair and interesting challenge to play and finish a Bard's playthrough.The game is hard, but is also very fair. As I said, everything is known, and the game lobby offers several ways to train yourself and gather informations on enemies in a stressless manner. So after that, once you think you've learned everything you needed, you can delve into the musical dungeon, and then all hell break loose. You know skeletons raise theirs arms before moving, and yet, in the stress of having to move constantly, you keep moving towards skeletons with raised arms, and then getting damaged. It's going to take a lot of practice to become good and finish the game.But well, practicing is so much fun in this game. The graphics are great, with cute zombies dancing around, skeletons swaying their hips while moving towards you, etc. All the characters have very nicely done animations and attention to details. It also has good replayability, thanks to the randomly generated dungeons and items. Each weapon has its own strenghs and weaknesses and really change how you're going to approach each ennemy. And finally the last, but greatest element...the music.The OST for this game has been done by none other than Danny Baranowsky, one of the most famous guy in the small world of indie video game music. If you've played Super Meat Boy, Desktop Dungeons, Canabalt, or the Binding of Isaac, you already know how awesome his music is. If you don't i highly recommend checking its music on Bandcamp. I actually bought Crypt of the Necrodancer's OST months before actually buying the game. Each track is a marvel, each world has its own music soundscape, and there is a lot of music-related surprise to find while playing the game.TLDR : This game is awesome, if you like hard tactical games, buy it, and also buy the soundtrack on Bandcamp :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the NecroDancer is a rhythm roguelike dungeon crawler. What to say. This game is 100% fantastic. A great challenge while also being incredibly fun. Moving on the beat and hitting monsters along with the flow of the music is an incredibly satisfying feeling, especially on enemies like dragons, following the pattern of hit-move-hit-move until they're dead. Every enemy design is great in its own way, as well as every character sprite. Cadence's animations are flat-out adorable. The music, integral as it is to the gameplay, is incredible, and easy to listen to over and over again. Which is kind of common, in a game as difficult as NecroDancer. My only problem with the game is very, VERY minor. It's about the beat bars at the bottom of the screen, near the image of the beating heart. They kept throwing me off the beat ever so slightly. Thankfully, the devs put in the ability to turn off the beat bars. Thank you.Verdict: 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the Necrodancer is the game where you think you're good at beating down monsters to the beat... then you unlock hardcore mode. You think of this as impossible as Zone 3 is one giant zerg rush of skeleton horses and elemental enemies. Nonetheless you try it anyway and manage to get some decent gear. Then a red dragon comes along and says "♥♥♥♥ you!" and you get one shot by a fireball because you can't do the sacred red dragon dance at that moment. (That's my life, i cri evertim ;;) But seriously, this game is amazing in many aspects. It's hard to find a game where a particular character dies from picking up GOLD, of all things! Since the levels are randomly generated there is no true pattern to the game and permanent death is indeed a thing. So that guy that dies from picking up gold? He's no exception, better watch your step! Oh yeah, and the only way you can move/attack/dig/open chests is by hitting the arrow key in the direction that you want to go on the beat of the song that's playing. There's a nice little tutorial in-game for that, though. However, there is one thing that bugs me about Crypt of the Necrodancer. That is, the diamonds that are used to purchase items to be put into the item pool for non-hardcore runs. It would make more sense to have everything unlocked already, like hardcore does, but you are forced to buy it using diamonds you find during non-hardcore runs. It's a bit more harmful than helpful and everything should just be unlocked for you to use when it's found. Despite that, this game is well worth your time. I've got 60+ hours and counting clocked into Crypt of the Necrodancer and it's not like I'll be stopping anytime soon. If you like challenging games, get this game. If you like rogue-likes, get this game. If you like rhythm based games, get this game. The point is, just buy the freaking game! What're you waiting for? Scroll back up and click that "Add to cart" button!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is definitely one of the most unique roguelike games I’ve ever played, with the added bonus of actually resembling rogue instead of using roguelike as another term for “permadeath without saves”.  You play a family of musicians (or a motley crew of side-characters) determined to unlock the mystery of the magical lute and defeat the Necrodancer, a cursed necromantic bard.True to its name, you “dance” around each level by moving in tune to the rhythm meter at the bottom of the screen. Each level has its own tune and rhythm and the game steadily increases the pace as you progress. Keeping in tune with the music while vanquishing enemies will net you a higher multiplier which increases the amount of gold you find, in addition to enhancing certain special items found throughout the crypt. Failing to keep to the beat will cause your multiplier to go down and may also prevent you from moving. Since the monsters in the game also move to the beat, they will eventually close in on you to attack and you cannot stand still to “pause” the action (unless you’re playing the bard character). I found the soundtrack for CotN to be excellent and very diverse. Each level’s song fits its theme pretty well and there are a few tracks that are instantly catchy. The shopkeeper in each level will also sing along with the music, giving a clue to his location, and all of the monsters are either music-themed or have a name alluding to some musical term or instrument, adding an extra layer of detail to this thoroughly polished game.There really aren’t any faults with this game that would prevent any fan of rogues from picking it up (playing as Aria is extremely hard though) and, even if you’re not normally into games in this genre, the learning curve is very fair. This game is worth picking up even at its original cost, though if you can catch it at the average sale price of $5 it’s quite a steal!

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												This is easily the game of the year for me. It looks pretty innocent and silly, but it's extremely addicting and quite difficult. It's like the perfect mix of Guitar Hero and your favourite roguelike/dungeon RPG. Your mission is to build a character with powerful items and bring him/her through multiple terrifying zones and well-designed bossfights. All of this without breaks, because you'll be moving to the beat of the (honestly beautiful and catchy) soundtrack. So you'd best learn every enemy and every item in order to maximize your chances of survival, and even then it's hard. Not only that, but there are more characters to choose from which provide different (read: insane) challenges.I know 15 bucks is quite a lot for an indie game these days, but definitely buy it, it'll be so worth it. It's also one of the most unique games you'll ever play.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very fun game, 100% worth buying even at full price. (And as a notorious cheapskate, that's not something I say lightly.) Don't be discouraged by the early access tag; this game is very well polished already, and recieves regular updates. Even if they never updated it again, it would still be worth buying. You will have a blast playing this single player, and if you have someone to play with the local co-op is great as well.Pros:Refreshing concept, executed wonderfullyNice tight gameplayGREAT soundtrackLovely pixel graphics and animationsGood amount of content/replayabilitySteam workshopCons:Custom song importing doesn't work as well as you'd hope (beats are off/weird sometimes, but maybe I'm picking the wrong kind of songs)Very unforgiving of mistakes (but it's a roguelike so that's to be expected)You have to be good at memorization (Hey, it's a con for some people)I'm sure there were other things I wanted to mention so I'll probably edit this review at some point. But all-in-all very nice game, quickly becoming one of my favorites. Definitely recommend.

content:

Early Access Review
								Great music, and the ability to import your own songs makes it where you're unlikely to get bored of the sounds.  While each enemy tends to be pretty easy to take down, a horde is a challenge, and can be overwhelming at first.  Thankfully, for those of us who are always off-beat or are overwhelmed, an alternate character (the Bard) allows the game to act more like a traditional rogue-like (with fantastic music), where the enemies take their turn after your character moves.Give the awesome variety of items, shrines, and teleporters already in the game, I'm really looking forward to see what they add during the remainder of development.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Brilliant. I was glad i instantly bought this game after hearing so many good things about it. For a while i've watched few people play this game and from what i could gather, it really held up to all it's promises.I bought this game and figured since it has Co op, i could try it out with a friend of mine, and we had a blast.The music is amazing and the whole Roguelike feel mixed with Rhytm was an excellent mixture.The graphics are pleasent for the eyes and keeps a retro feel while having upbeat chiptune esque sounds compossed by the brilliant artist Danny Baranowsky who is also known for doing music for Binding of Isaac and Super meat boy.Alright, let me get into the details of what you're getting yourself into.This game feels rewarding even when you die there will always be upgrades which adds to your progress.There are items to buy and bunch of stuff to unlock to add even more replayabillity including a hardcore mode.Co Op is twice the fun and there were no issues to be had since the screen pans out the further apart both players are.Enemies have patterns which are easily memorized by repeating the game through trail and errors and the same goes for all of the traps and mini bosses and main bosses of the game.But here comes minor nitpicks since no game in this universe is flawless, so don't take this the wrong way.This game can be unforgiving to people who have a hard time adjusting to the sense of beats and rhytms but there is a steady learning curve which seems to work.The controllers input works fine but i can't seem to get the ''start'' button to work at times so i have to use Keyboard whenever i wan't to continue in a zone when i can't use my diamonds.Like i said, this game is amazing and i'm glad that it exists, don't let these minor faults ruin the experience for you.I'm rating it a solid 9/10 and recomend it, especially for Roguelike/Rhytm game fans or Binding of Isaac fans.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Litterally the first words I thought to myself after quitting my first stint of this game? "Wow, that was actually really good."Perhaps not the most insightful of comments, but I MEANT it, and this was a surprising fact. Looking at the game on steam, you may think "So a rogue-like with music. Right" And technically, you'd be right. But that's like calling a burger "cows backside with month old milk covered on top"It just doesn't do it justice. The gameplay is what you'd expect from the genre, constant paranoia of the simplest mobs knowing they could end your playthrough merely by invading your personal space. However, the twist is, they are all 100% predictable. Green slimes don't move. Blue ones bounce in a grid, one square per beat. Minotaurs charge in a straight line until they hit a wall, dragons...well, I still have yet to work that one out. But dragons hurt, and I don't like them anymore.You yourself are 'constrained' by the rules as well. If YOU don't move to the beat (which I have to admit, is catchy) you'll lose your coin multiplier bonus. That's it, nothing 'life ending' but...it makes it harder, thus worthwhile. *This is only valid if you don't play the bard character, who has different rules I won't go into*The rest? Eh, the graphics are bright, but still suit the 'dark' theme. Sort of like a Scooby Doo episode. The sound I was shocked with (In a good way) and the gameplay...well, I'm eager to go back for more. Once I forget about the dragons, that is.8.5/10, with only the 'promise for more' alpha state on it preventing it from getting higher (Can you rate an unfinished game as perfect?)Would highly recommend to any fans of the genre.

												Honestly, I'm not a huge fan of roguelikes... I never seemed to grasp the concept of "good" or "bad" items, and I found the everchanging map layouts kinda disorienting.When I picked this game up, I expected the same cookie-cutter gameplay style. I'm very glad I was proven wrong. CotN is a fast-paced and quick-witted game based around completing actions based on the beat of the music playing in the background, and I found it quite amazing. It has a ton of replay value, it keeps you on edge and requires split-second reactions. Also, the music is really f*ckin' good. Maybe I'm biased, maybe I'm not. It's up to you if you wanna pick this game up for yourself. No regrets.

content:

Early Access Review
								Great music, and the ability to import your own songs makes it where you're unlikely to get bored of the sounds.  While each enemy tends to be pretty easy to take down, a horde is a challenge, and can be overwhelming at first.  Thankfully, for those of us who are always off-beat or are overwhelmed, an alternate character (the Bard) allows the game to act more like a traditional rogue-like (with fantastic music), where the enemies take their turn after your character moves.Give the awesome variety of items, shrines, and teleporters already in the game, I'm really looking forward to see what they add during the remainder of development.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Brilliant. I was glad i instantly bought this game after hearing so many good things about it. For a while i've watched few people play this game and from what i could gather, it really held up to all it's promises.I bought this game and figured since it has Co op, i could try it out with a friend of mine, and we had a blast.The music is amazing and the whole Roguelike feel mixed with Rhytm was an excellent mixture.The graphics are pleasent for the eyes and keeps a retro feel while having upbeat chiptune esque sounds compossed by the brilliant artist Danny Baranowsky who is also known for doing music for Binding of Isaac and Super meat boy.Alright, let me get into the details of what you're getting yourself into.This game feels rewarding even when you die there will always be upgrades which adds to your progress.There are items to buy and bunch of stuff to unlock to add even more replayabillity including a hardcore mode.Co Op is twice the fun and there were no issues to be had since the screen pans out the further apart both players are.Enemies have patterns which are easily memorized by repeating the game through trail and errors and the same goes for all of the traps and mini bosses and main bosses of the game.But here comes minor nitpicks since no game in this universe is flawless, so don't take this the wrong way.This game can be unforgiving to people who have a hard time adjusting to the sense of beats and rhytms but there is a steady learning curve which seems to work.The controllers input works fine but i can't seem to get the ''start'' button to work at times so i have to use Keyboard whenever i wan't to continue in a zone when i can't use my diamonds.Like i said, this game is amazing and i'm glad that it exists, don't let these minor faults ruin the experience for you.I'm rating it a solid 9/10 and recomend it, especially for Roguelike/Rhytm game fans or Binding of Isaac fans.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												This is my first review.  Seriously I love this game.  I'm a bit bit of rouge-like games, and this is the best.  Beautiful graphics, great music, and the magic items and monsters have nicely thought out and interacting moves and features.  The different levels are beautifully themed.  And there's different characters that have individual traits that make the game easier or harder.  It's not too difficult to get through the levels and it's certainly not impossible to complete, (at least with the easier characters).  Right now I am trying to speedrun the game (complete in less than 15 minutes), a lot of fun as finding the right item can really change your strategy.  My only complaints might be that some of the text overlaps and is hard to read, and the difficulty level rises dramatically with some of the later characters you unlock.  But a great game, I can't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very fun game, 100% worth buying even at full price. (And as a notorious cheapskate, that's not something I say lightly.) Don't be discouraged by the early access tag; this game is very well polished already, and recieves regular updates. Even if they never updated it again, it would still be worth buying. You will have a blast playing this single player, and if you have someone to play with the local co-op is great as well.Pros:Refreshing concept, executed wonderfullyNice tight gameplayGREAT soundtrackLovely pixel graphics and animationsGood amount of content/replayabilitySteam workshopCons:Custom song importing doesn't work as well as you'd hope (beats are off/weird sometimes, but maybe I'm picking the wrong kind of songs)Very unforgiving of mistakes (but it's a roguelike so that's to be expected)You have to be good at memorization (Hey, it's a con for some people)I'm sure there were other things I wanted to mention so I'll probably edit this review at some point. But all-in-all very nice game, quickly becoming one of my favorites. Definitely recommend.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Necrodancer is an enjoyable mashup of rhythm based and rouge-lite elements that end up working surprisingly well together. The game suffers from the same problems that most indie rogue-lites do and that is that it becomes fairly repetitive after a few hours of play due to a general lack of enemy variety. Still, the game does have 10 playable characters, each with their own gimmick to help diversify time spent playing the game. The game also comes with 3 soundtracks as well as the ability to use your own mp3s so that you don't have to listen to the same soundtrack over and over if you are having trouble getting past a particular zone. It's the kind of game I pick up and play a little of everyday and overtime has really grown on me.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								An absolutely fantastic combination of roguelike dungeoneering and rhythm game. That darn Necromancer has your heart and is forcing you to move to the beat. Of course, you can skip the beat, but we really suggest you don't. Every enemy has its pattern, every item has its individual use and every run is sure to be completely different and enjoyable.Devs are very active and frequently adding new things, you can put your own custom music in and it's fairly good at recognising the beat (I highly recommend Hotline Miami's soundtrack). Several characters to pick from, a few more when you beat the 'hardcore' mode (a straight run through all the levels, a feat I've yet to accomplish at time of writing). Every death will have been avoidable and will leave you asking yourself why you did that, rather than blaming the game or enemies.A very satisfying game to play, could not recommend it any more strongly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												Easily one of the best rhythm games to come out EVER. CoTND is a procedurally generated dungeon crawler with the difficulty and addictiveness of Binding of Isaac, with, imo, a killer soundtrack. This is probably because the music was made by the same guy but, I digress. And if for some reason you hate the music (or you get sick of dying and hearing the same bloody song from level 1 over and over again like I do (inb4 'git good')) you can substitute the level songs with your own music. You play at Cadence, one of several musically-named individuals who must make their way through the titular Crypt for their each individual reasons, which is fun but the true awesomeness lies in the music-related combat and sweet pixel art visuals. That being said the game is hard. It's really hard. The good news is with a few proper upgrades you can become veritably unstoppable in any of the worlds. The learning curve drops into a cliff about the time you meet the Red Dragon, who can take you out with a single well-timed fire breath from across the map, and he'll show up every now and again in Zone 1.Easy to learn and hard to master are how I would describe this game, and would definitely recommend it unless you're known to break things if you get easily frustrated. Mice and keyboards are expensive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I'm going to compress things in a manner that I would like them to be if I were the one looking for more info about the game (coming from someone that loved Spelunky)...The Standard InfoCrypt of the Necrodancer is a rogue-lite game (and I don't say that for lack of difficulty) merging together aspects of Spelunky and Rogue.There are 4 different zones, each with their own characteristics (monsters, bosses, layout etc) much like the different zones in Spelunky(caves, jungle, ice, temple).You can choose to play any zone individually after unlocking it for the first time or play through all them consecutively (the standard game mode.)The levels are procedurally generated, technically never allowing for there to be an impossible one.There's items which you can buy from the shopkeeper, and unlock to buy from the shopkeeper as you progress through the game. There's also different characters you can play as, each with their own quirks (some much more difficult than others.)The differencesThe game is isometric and turn based with the "turns" simply being movements (much like Rogue.)But here's the catch: The turns are just beats (each level has a different song to dan.. I mean move to.) Successfully moving to the beat rewards you with a multiplier, increasing any gold you find. Mess up the beat, and the multiplier starts over.This not only provides an immensely satisfying experience when you nail zombies and skeletons to the flashing neon lights reminiscent of Hotline Miami, but it also effectively gives you a time limit to move and complete the level. You have to do SOMETHING on each beat and if you don't defeat the mini boss and finish the level by the end of the song: PENALTIES (and sometimes death.)Each enemy has a move set that you can learn, anticipate and counter. Combine that with the different characters you can play as, the items that change the way you fight and the endless potential of procedural levels and you get a game as addictive as breaking it down any other rogue-lite out there and better.If that wasn't enough to satisfy your craving for the never-ending cycle of die and repeat then there's also the level editor, allowing you to create and share your own dancefloors levels as well as play other user-created chambers of torment.If that's STILL not enough, there's the daily challenge. This is basically a series of zones that is exactly the same to everyone. This provides an opportunity to play and compare high scores fairly until the end of the day, when a new one is generated.This game is an example of what happens when you incorporate an interesting gimmick into a core gameplay mechanic and polish it until it shines brighter than the punch-myself-in-the-jugular-with-a-fistfull-of-glitter dancefloor it does the boogie on.And if for some reason you actually dislike the music in the game, or grow tired of dying to it constantly... YOU CAN DANC... PLAY TO YOUR OWN SONGS.142857/142857

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I've been addicted to this game since I started playing it. I am not a big fan of rogue-likes in general, but this game is among few rare exceptions. You have 4 zones to beat, each one contains 3 floors and a boss fight. Every zone has its own theme and enemies. But wait, there's more. The enemies each move to the beat in their own unique pattern, and you have to recognize it and adapt quickly. For example, some enemies might be moving along a scripted path, others try to go for you specifically, some might stay still for 2 beats and then move on the 3rd one, others might move on every beat, and so on. It's all very well done. During your dungeon crawling you'll also come across a lot of items of varying degrees of helpfulness. You have healing items, weapons, armour, rings, spells, and even some unusual items. Some can spawn from the start, others require unlocking via collectible diamonds. You can even remove the less useful items from the dungeons via the janitor, so that there's more chances instead for chests to contain the items you find more useful. There is of course a fair bit of luck involved, as is pretty common with rogue-like games. At times you'll be lucky to find a nice weapon and other useful items early on, other times you'll just be spawning with enemies all around you. It is a very challenging game. You will die a lot. But you do learn to recognize the enemy movement patterns and eventually overcome them. I also really like the whole light-hearted theme the game is going for. I think the devs pulled it off perfectly. The music is also amazing and will just drag you in to the beat. In addition to the regular mode with the main character, you also get to unlock several other characters, which seem to have their own unique abilities (for example one of them can only confuse enemies but not kill, another is only able to use bombs, and so on). It all adds an extra challenge for those who want it. You can even go and practice fighting against specific enemies and bosses if you wish. Great game in general. Highly recommended.

												This is my first review.  Seriously I love this game.  I'm a bit bit of rouge-like games, and this is the best.  Beautiful graphics, great music, and the magic items and monsters have nicely thought out and interacting moves and features.  The different levels are beautifully themed.  And there's different characters that have individual traits that make the game easier or harder.  It's not too difficult to get through the levels and it's certainly not impossible to complete, (at least with the easier characters).  Right now I am trying to speedrun the game (complete in less than 15 minutes), a lot of fun as finding the right item can really change your strategy.  My only complaints might be that some of the text overlaps and is hard to read, and the difficulty level rises dramatically with some of the later characters you unlock.  But a great game, I can't recommend it enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Brilliant. I was glad i instantly bought this game after hearing so many good things about it. For a while i've watched few people play this game and from what i could gather, it really held up to all it's promises.I bought this game and figured since it has Co op, i could try it out with a friend of mine, and we had a blast.The music is amazing and the whole Roguelike feel mixed with Rhytm was an excellent mixture.The graphics are pleasent for the eyes and keeps a retro feel while having upbeat chiptune esque sounds compossed by the brilliant artist Danny Baranowsky who is also known for doing music for Binding of Isaac and Super meat boy.Alright, let me get into the details of what you're getting yourself into.This game feels rewarding even when you die there will always be upgrades which adds to your progress.There are items to buy and bunch of stuff to unlock to add even more replayabillity including a hardcore mode.Co Op is twice the fun and there were no issues to be had since the screen pans out the further apart both players are.Enemies have patterns which are easily memorized by repeating the game through trail and errors and the same goes for all of the traps and mini bosses and main bosses of the game.But here comes minor nitpicks since no game in this universe is flawless, so don't take this the wrong way.This game can be unforgiving to people who have a hard time adjusting to the sense of beats and rhytms but there is a steady learning curve which seems to work.The controllers input works fine but i can't seem to get the ''start'' button to work at times so i have to use Keyboard whenever i wan't to continue in a zone when i can't use my diamonds.Like i said, this game is amazing and i'm glad that it exists, don't let these minor faults ruin the experience for you.I'm rating it a solid 9/10 and recomend it, especially for Roguelike/Rhytm game fans or Binding of Isaac fans.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												No joke, this was one of my favourite games of 2014.In theory, this is a really simple game.  Grid-based roguelikes have been done before.  The real seller of Crypt, however, is the impact of the game being set to music and moving rhythmically.Unlike a lot of similar games, Crypt forces you to learn and memorize patterns and react fast and skillfully, instead of spending forever mulling through cluttered inventories for the exact item to get you out of your situation.  It's about speed, snap decisions, and learning, and above all is completely fair - everything in the game could be handled flawlessly with just your starting equipment.There's a lot of other aspects that are strengths to it.  Mechanically, the game reaches an incredible level of play diversity, not just from the vastly different playable characters.  It also comes from the fact the massive pool of items are rarely just a straight upgrade over one another, and instead have different strengths, weaknesses, and benefits.  Presentation wise the game's super slick, charmingly animated, and the music is bloody amazing too.Do the thing.  Get the game.  It's amazing.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the NecroDancer is a clever, addictive rhythm game and dungeon crawler mash-up, refreshing and definitely worth more than what I ended up paying for it during this Winter Sale. I am ecstatic to see such creative, inspired titles earn the love and respect (and business) of the Steam community. It deserves it and then some.Is this my first review? I think it is. Definitely worth the effort.My girlfriend doesn't care for this game, but she's has a severe aversion to rhythm games. With that said, this is the kind of game that forming an opinion about simply requires watching some gameplay - you'll know once you see it. It has a good heart, a good beat and a good future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												One, two, three, four, aah, AAAH, AARGH! ♥♥♥♥!Crypt of the Necrodancer is a beautifully crafted mix between a rhythm game and a tile-based roguelike. You play as one of several characters who are forced to move to the beat of a catchy soundtrack, each with their own quirk to make the game frustrating, painful, and gloriously addictive. Everything can be done using a single set of four context-sensitive buttons. Just press a direction to move, attack, or dig in that direction, and the game will pick the action most conducive to progress. That, of course, doesn't mean you're not going to die. Through the pressure of moving to the beat, you're going to make stupid decisions, and they will be entirely your fault. Every enemy telegraphs their moves and attacks in a predictable pattern, and if you end up cornered by three enemies and your back to a wall, you only have yourself to blame.Every zone has three floors and a boss. The stairs to the next floor are only opened by defeating the miniboss, but you can fall through a trapdoor at the song's end to get to the next floor, if you don't mind the miniboss and several other monsters following you down, forcing you to kill it before you can actually explore the floor.Each boss has their own quirks. King Conga skips the eigth beat, and if you miss a step he'll get off his throne and charge at you. Deep Blues is a literal chessboard, swarming you with pieces that you must clear out before the King stops running away. Coral Riff floods the area, creating water tiles that stop you from moving if you step in them. Death Metal works through several phases at the pace of the fastest song in the game.And, of course, there are the story bosses in the last zone if you're playing as Cadence, Melody, or Aria. Fight the Necrodancer and reclaim your freedom!You can choose to start at any zone after the furthest you've finished, at the cost of not being able to complete more than one zone at a time, or take a top-to-bottom all zones run that starts you with no character upgrades. Completing and exploring individual zones rewards you with diamonds, which allow you to upgrade your character, unlock equipment, spells, and weapons, or buy items to start with in your next zone run.Of course, unlocking items just means you can find them in your next runs! This is a roguelike after all, and every sword, armor, ring, and spell has to be found in the Crypt itself for you to use them.Play as Melody and only attack when moving! Don't get cornered!Play as Eli and blast your enemies to bits... if you don't blow yourself up first!Play as Dove and friendship the monsters away... for a while before they mob you!Play as Monk and find even more ways to die, since you can't touch money!Play as Dorian and realize that moving two spaces at once is more frustrating than helpful!Play as Bolt and learn that double speed is somehow both faster and slower than you expect!Play as Aria and discover that perfect rhythm is even harder when you gotta stay alive too!Play as Bard and move to your own beat... coward.And, once you've done all that, play as Coda, the Monk-Bolt-Aria hybrid. That's all the description you need. Good luck!Overall rating: 4/4 time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Completionists, stay away.  There are things that are practically impossible to obtain.Roguelike purists, also stay away.  The game mechanics aren't extremely deep.Otherwise?  As long as you can tap to a metronome (or at least learn to) and do enjoy action, I highly recommend this game.Crypt of the NecroDancer, at its core, is a rhythm-based action with roguelite and dungeon crawler elements.  People have compared this game to games such as Faster Than Light and Spelunky; I really enjoyed the former and felt iffy about the latter, and after 350+ hours, I don't know if I can really stop playing NecroDancer just yet.It's very easy to pick up and understand the core gameplay; one or two local players act to the beat (with only the arrow keys), and everything else responds to your movements on the same beat, allowing you to plan for the next beat.  Getting dropped into the first zone after the tutorial level, you're introduced to a small variety of items, learning about this and that, buying and picking up things to figure out what your favorites are, and dealing with a small variety of enemies.  Items definitely make things easier, but it's absolutely possible to finish everything and low% a run with only default gear.(By the way, if you want to have a sense of genuine curiosity, go into the options and disable "show item hints".)And once you inevitably die, it's not so bad.  There's almost always a way out of whatever predicament you managed to get yourself into, and you sensibly chuckle at it and figure you'll do better next time.You slowly progress, saving a few unfortunate NPCs from cages, buying new things with diamonds and slowly expanding the pool of items you get to find and use during runs.  You finally manage to get the boss down, start to learn why Cadence is in this dungeon of dance, and then you're back to square one, figuring out the patterns in the completely new world that is Zone 2.  And you work through it, because holy crap is that Danny Baranowsky soundtrack fantastic and motivating.And you keep at it.  Some things change completely, some things don't, and some things get flipped upside-down and force you to change tactics.Occasionally, you take a break from Cadence and pick up a different character.  Oh yeah, there's other ways to play the game in Zone 1 again, and some new strategies for enemies you've seen before.  All the normal characters are interesting to work with in their own way.Once you feel that you've finished the important stuff, a variety of things open up.  Score runs?  Speedruns?  Sure thing, try to see how well you can do on the boards and in the daily challenge runs.  Low%?  Go for that, if you want to.  In terms of replayability, you get about as much as Spelunky -- everything generally stays the same, but for some reason the variations between runs always gets you coming back for more.Mods are a thing, to some extent.  At the very least, many resources can be replaced and custom levels are supported and supported through Steam Workshop.  That's about it, though; there's no way to add in completely new items and content just yet.Remember what I said about completionists?  Yeah, if you want to 100% this game legitimately, forget about it.  The developers added in a character that even they think is impossible.  There's absolutely nothing except bragging rights and an achievement to gain from completing a run as said character (unlike in, say, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth), so you're not missing out on too much otherwise.It's been great watching this game only get better from Early Access; Brace Yourself Games has been nothing less than incredible with regular development and responsive to the community.  If you haven't been driven away from reading this yet, it's absolutely worth more than the $15 that it's listed for.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Necrodancer delivers the electronic beats and a horde of monsters to defeat. Our unlikely herione, Cadance, boldly foregoes the suggested years of dance training and rushes in to save her own heart and vanquish a legendary foe.Roommate 1: "What are you playing, Legend of Zelda?"Roommate 2: "That actually looks like a decent rhythm game."Brace Yourself Games has successfully combined a couple of genres into something you won't expect to be fun into something outright addictive. Every level is randomly generated and challenging in its own right, but there is always a bunch of orderly and easy to learn patterns to every enemy you will encounter. This isn't a game for everyone, but it's a game worth trying despite the fact that it isn't fully developed yet.Sure, the game is a bunch of pixels and the learning curve is a bit harsh. But the satisfaction of beating a single level keeps me coming back for another beating, the default music is awesome, and the game never ceases to be interesting. I don't know if I'll ever get good at it, but it inspires me to no end as a game-designer-in-training. I would regret never having played this game more than I regret a lot of other things.

												The game is only part of it. Holy crap, this soundtrack... Sometimes, something comes along with a gimmick that you love. I love Freddie Merchantry. I sing along with him.ProsGenuinely unique rhythm based roguelike.Amazing soundtrack (Jules tracks aren't my fav but they're still good)You can use a dance pad. A freaking dance pad.Base game has lots of options to change gameplay (upgrades, janitor, characters), workshop content goes even farther.Great artwork and sound.ConsDifficulty ramps up to 11 after completing the majority of the story, Aria is quite difficult.Sometimes you want to play a game, but you're distracted or feeling out of it so your rhythm or skill is off. This is one of those games you can't really play in those times.The initial difficulty curve of playing a roguelike to rhythm may put off some players. (Bard is here to help! Play him to the beat, stop moving when you need to think about your movement.)I fully recommend getting this game and its soundtracks for full price or discount. It's completely worth it, discounted or not, fan of rhythm games or roguelikes or not, player of indie games or not. I have 27 hours played, but by now well over 200 hours listening to the music from this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Let me just say, I didn't really know what I was getting into when I first bought the game. I thought "oh, it's just going to be a fun little rythem game that I could easily beat". I was so wrong. It was a game that was easy to learn and hard to master. The first zone was actually more difficult then I expected, but I beat it without troble. By the time zone 3 came, I was just about to throw my controller. But, I kept going, kept persisting and eventually I beat all of the zones. But, the replability comes in with new characters with differnt atributes that kept me coming back to play again. This game is harder then I thought, but it was definitly worth my money.Pros:-Fun, simple rythem game.-Ability to use custom music. (Just hearing Weird Al sing Bukingham Blues on the Deep Blues boss was sooooooooooooooo satisfying.)-Tons of differnt characters to unlock.-All zones mode to dare the experanced players.-Clean, pixel graphics.-Awsome music. (There are three versions too!)Cons:-Needs more weapons/items to unlock, I basicly got them all once I reached zone 3 with my first character.-Needs an online co-op (Local feels like multiplayer in the 90's)-Needs a better interface on the level creator. (I found it slightly annoying actually, you have to use the arrow keys, enter and delete and it quickly got tedious.)Overall I give this game 9/10. I had a lot of fun with it and it has the potential to pack in a ton more hours.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												Necrodancer is an enjoyable mashup of rhythm based and rouge-lite elements that end up working surprisingly well together. The game suffers from the same problems that most indie rogue-lites do and that is that it becomes fairly repetitive after a few hours of play due to a general lack of enemy variety. Still, the game does have 10 playable characters, each with their own gimmick to help diversify time spent playing the game. The game also comes with 3 soundtracks as well as the ability to use your own mp3s so that you don't have to listen to the same soundtrack over and over if you are having trouble getting past a particular zone. It's the kind of game I pick up and play a little of everyday and overtime has really grown on me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												Easily one of the best rhythm games to come out EVER. CoTND is a procedurally generated dungeon crawler with the difficulty and addictiveness of Binding of Isaac, with, imo, a killer soundtrack. This is probably because the music was made by the same guy but, I digress. And if for some reason you hate the music (or you get sick of dying and hearing the same bloody song from level 1 over and over again like I do (inb4 'git good')) you can substitute the level songs with your own music. You play at Cadence, one of several musically-named individuals who must make their way through the titular Crypt for their each individual reasons, which is fun but the true awesomeness lies in the music-related combat and sweet pixel art visuals. That being said the game is hard. It's really hard. The good news is with a few proper upgrades you can become veritably unstoppable in any of the worlds. The learning curve drops into a cliff about the time you meet the Red Dragon, who can take you out with a single well-timed fire breath from across the map, and he'll show up every now and again in Zone 1.Easy to learn and hard to master are how I would describe this game, and would definitely recommend it unless you're known to break things if you get easily frustrated. Mice and keyboards are expensive.

content:

Early Access Review
								Don't think of this as a dance game or a rhythm game. Think of it as a roguelike that forces you to make 100-150 actions per minute. It takes some of the best parts of Spelunky and refines them. The "real" game is doing a hardcore run from 1-1 to the end, but you'll play for 20 hours just unlocking the "tutorial" content via the gem system, which goes a long way to evening out the difficulty curve issues that prevent most people getting very far / enjoying Spelunky.Honestly can't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the Necrodancer is the game where you think you're good at beating down monsters to the beat... then you unlock hardcore mode. You think of this as impossible as Zone 3 is one giant zerg rush of skeleton horses and elemental enemies. Nonetheless you try it anyway and manage to get some decent gear. Then a red dragon comes along and says "♥♥♥♥ you!" and you get one shot by a fireball because you can't do the sacred red dragon dance at that moment. (That's my life, i cri evertim ;;) But seriously, this game is amazing in many aspects. It's hard to find a game where a particular character dies from picking up GOLD, of all things! Since the levels are randomly generated there is no true pattern to the game and permanent death is indeed a thing. So that guy that dies from picking up gold? He's no exception, better watch your step! Oh yeah, and the only way you can move/attack/dig/open chests is by hitting the arrow key in the direction that you want to go on the beat of the song that's playing. There's a nice little tutorial in-game for that, though. However, there is one thing that bugs me about Crypt of the Necrodancer. That is, the diamonds that are used to purchase items to be put into the item pool for non-hardcore runs. It would make more sense to have everything unlocked already, like hardcore does, but you are forced to buy it using diamonds you find during non-hardcore runs. It's a bit more harmful than helpful and everything should just be unlocked for you to use when it's found. Despite that, this game is well worth your time. I've got 60+ hours and counting clocked into Crypt of the Necrodancer and it's not like I'll be stopping anytime soon. If you like challenging games, get this game. If you like rogue-likes, get this game. If you like rhythm based games, get this game. The point is, just buy the freaking game! What're you waiting for? Scroll back up and click that "Add to cart" button!
