(And for the people who are a bit tight when it comes to pecuniary measures, don't worry, this game has been on sale a lot these past few days!) I'd recommend this to any friend or family member who wants to have a great, grooving time! I'm extremely glad I can be a part of this community too. I honestly need to start a real life group that's filled with people who love the game as much as I do, because Crypt of the NecroDancer is one of my favorite games due to the amount of detail the sound crew, pixel artists, and everyone else had done (I also have to thank the person who made the puns for everyone of the enemy names personally, they're amazing without a doubt)! Although I only have around 50 hours of playing the game, you can bet on the shopkeeper's amazing voice that you'll love it too. And if the wide variety of characters, weapons, etc. aren't enough for you, you can even download mods! A personal favorite of my being the Captain Falcon reskins with sound, truly amazing.) With a great community and even greater team, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a must have. And now, after the real review is over, I must now make a musical pun to balance out the silliness (and to show respect for the beautiful, beautiful man/woman/team who came up with the puns.). Let's see... oh, I have one! If you do not like this game for whatever reason, then you can kindly and respectfully kiss my brass! Heh, I don't mean to toot my own horn or anything, but musical puns are the 'key' to success! (But back to seriousness, 10 out of 10, would recommend to everyone who plays video games and/or loves music.)

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is definitely one of the most unique roguelike games I’ve ever played, with the added bonus of actually resembling rogue instead of using roguelike as another term for “permadeath without saves”.  You play a family of musicians (or a motley crew of side-characters) determined to unlock the mystery of the magical lute and defeat the Necrodancer, a cursed necromantic bard.True to its name, you “dance” around each level by moving in tune to the rhythm meter at the bottom of the screen. Each level has its own tune and rhythm and the game steadily increases the pace as you progress. Keeping in tune with the music while vanquishing enemies will net you a higher multiplier which increases the amount of gold you find, in addition to enhancing certain special items found throughout the crypt. Failing to keep to the beat will cause your multiplier to go down and may also prevent you from moving. Since the monsters in the game also move to the beat, they will eventually close in on you to attack and you cannot stand still to “pause” the action (unless you’re playing the bard character). I found the soundtrack for CotN to be excellent and very diverse. Each level’s song fits its theme pretty well and there are a few tracks that are instantly catchy. The shopkeeper in each level will also sing along with the music, giving a clue to his location, and all of the monsters are either music-themed or have a name alluding to some musical term or instrument, adding an extra layer of detail to this thoroughly polished game.There really aren’t any faults with this game that would prevent any fan of rogues from picking it up (playing as Aria is extremely hard though) and, even if you’re not normally into games in this genre, the learning curve is very fair. This game is worth picking up even at its original cost, though if you can catch it at the average sale price of $5 it’s quite a steal!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I'm going to compress things in a manner that I would like them to be if I were the one looking for more info about the game (coming from someone that loved Spelunky)...The Standard InfoCrypt of the Necrodancer is a rogue-lite game (and I don't say that for lack of difficulty) merging together aspects of Spelunky and Rogue.There are 4 different zones, each with their own characteristics (monsters, bosses, layout etc) much like the different zones in Spelunky(caves, jungle, ice, temple).You can choose to play any zone individually after unlocking it for the first time or play through all them consecutively (the standard game mode.)The levels are procedurally generated, technically never allowing for there to be an impossible one.There's items which you can buy from the shopkeeper, and unlock to buy from the shopkeeper as you progress through the game. There's also different characters you can play as, each with their own quirks (some much more difficult than others.)The differencesThe game is isometric and turn based with the "turns" simply being movements (much like Rogue.)But here's the catch: The turns are just beats (each level has a different song to dan.. I mean move to.) Successfully moving to the beat rewards you with a multiplier, increasing any gold you find. Mess up the beat, and the multiplier starts over.This not only provides an immensely satisfying experience when you nail zombies and skeletons to the flashing neon lights reminiscent of Hotline Miami, but it also effectively gives you a time limit to move and complete the level. You have to do SOMETHING on each beat and if you don't defeat the mini boss and finish the level by the end of the song: PENALTIES (and sometimes death.)Each enemy has a move set that you can learn, anticipate and counter. Combine that with the different characters you can play as, the items that change the way you fight and the endless potential of procedural levels and you get a game as addictive as breaking it down any other rogue-lite out there and better.If that wasn't enough to satisfy your craving for the never-ending cycle of die and repeat then there's also the level editor, allowing you to create and share your own dancefloors levels as well as play other user-created chambers of torment.If that's STILL not enough, there's the daily challenge. This is basically a series of zones that is exactly the same to everyone. This provides an opportunity to play and compare high scores fairly until the end of the day, when a new one is generated.This game is an example of what happens when you incorporate an interesting gimmick into a core gameplay mechanic and polish it until it shines brighter than the punch-myself-in-the-jugular-with-a-fistfull-of-glitter dancefloor it does the boogie on.And if for some reason you actually dislike the music in the game, or grow tired of dying to it constantly... YOU CAN DANC... PLAY TO YOUR OWN SONGS.142857/142857

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I've been addicted to this game since I started playing it. I am not a big fan of rogue-likes in general, but this game is among few rare exceptions. You have 4 zones to beat, each one contains 3 floors and a boss fight. Every zone has its own theme and enemies. But wait, there's more. The enemies each move to the beat in their own unique pattern, and you have to recognize it and adapt quickly. For example, some enemies might be moving along a scripted path, others try to go for you specifically, some might stay still for 2 beats and then move on the 3rd one, others might move on every beat, and so on. It's all very well done. During your dungeon crawling you'll also come across a lot of items of varying degrees of helpfulness. You have healing items, weapons, armour, rings, spells, and even some unusual items. Some can spawn from the start, others require unlocking via collectible diamonds. You can even remove the less useful items from the dungeons via the janitor, so that there's more chances instead for chests to contain the items you find more useful. There is of course a fair bit of luck involved, as is pretty common with rogue-like games. At times you'll be lucky to find a nice weapon and other useful items early on, other times you'll just be spawning with enemies all around you. It is a very challenging game. You will die a lot. But you do learn to recognize the enemy movement patterns and eventually overcome them. I also really like the whole light-hearted theme the game is going for. I think the devs pulled it off perfectly. The music is also amazing and will just drag you in to the beat. In addition to the regular mode with the main character, you also get to unlock several other characters, which seem to have their own unique abilities (for example one of them can only confuse enemies but not kill, another is only able to use bombs, and so on). It all adds an extra challenge for those who want it. You can even go and practice fighting against specific enemies and bosses if you wish. Great game in general. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												You buy it now! I mean it.This is a concept game, and an incredibly good idea!Four keys are required to play, the arrows, nothing else. And with these four keys, you will "dance" on the music toward victory! or a quick death... Every step you take is a move, an attack, or a special action. On a slow music, you have about one move per second, a lots of time to think and make the best choice... but on a fast music, your reflexes will be challenged because the smallest error can kill you.The game offers many different items, all offering different advantages. The strategical value here is to know when to buy or not an item depending on your situation. Every game feels different with the random dungeons and you will never get bored playing.The game also displays many different monsters, all with a unique AI. Some are easy, you will love them; some are nasty, and you will hate them. The game doesn't force you to kill all ennemies of course, only one : the boss... but killing ennemies give you gold, and gold give you better objects. You will have to decide all the time if you risk it or not... quick! You have one music beat to decide! Oh too late... :)

Early Access Review
								When it comes to Early Access games, it can be hit or miss, most are bare bones and can be left unfinished, but others can be real gems that show the quality and talent indie games are known for, this is one of them, a game that already feels complete and plays very well, but hats off to the developers who wish to improve this game more to the best that it can be.High Points:  The controls are tight and responsive. The level design is always different, and yet the levels overall are kept rather short and rather straightforward, which is a big plus for these kinds of games. The variety of items and unlockables to get help encourage you to continue playing over and over again. The music, no doubt the highlight of the game, the music is addicting, enjoyable and will get stuck in your head for hours.Critique: As it stands at the moment, the game is pretty solid, but there is always room for improvment.1. More variety in items - If there is one thing Binding of Isaac has shown, is that with a large variety of items that all work differently, it helps make every playthrough different, with different items everytime, so it'd be nice to have something new other then rings, boots and such.2. Floor gimmicks - It'd be interesting if on all floors of other then the boss floor, there was a chance of a gimmick happening that can change the whole experience, like being chased by an invincible enemy, having no map to use, line of sight restricted, or even having a larger level the normal.3. More traps - I think some more traps might be needed to spice up the gameplay, like spin tiles to mess up the controls, moving traps that follow a set path, and perhaps traps that trigger if you move into their line of sight.Overall: I feel overall this game is looking really good, and I know when it finally comes out, it'll be a big hit.8.5/10

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												I LOVE this game. Take NetHack, add cute pixel graphics and a charming story, make the turns happen to the beat of music, and compress the whole experience down to a bite size morsel you can consume in 30 minutes - and you have this little gem. I bought the game for $7US, and then promptly bought the soundtrack for $15US which is the only music I’ve listened to for the past 5 weeks.This game starts off hard, and then gets brutally hard as you unlock the more advanced characters. But I’ve never felt the game cheated me, despite dozens of deaths. Each one was my fault, and mine alone. I wasn’t fast enough, I zigged when I should have zagged, I didn’t prioritise the right enemy, I didn’t control a boss’s movement. There is an element of RNGesus, but your skill and experience is the biggest factor in your success, or failure, by far. Did I mention I love this game?

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Really great game. Just totally solid from every vantage point. Any review that places this game below at least a 90 in score on Metacritic is either using a 5 star system and doesn't grant half stars or doesn't appreciate the nuances of the gameplay / the difficulty of the game.There is a large breadth of mechanics (there are tons of aspects of play like exploration, timing, resource management, risk/reward, etc) but all of which are approachable. The real startling thing is they have incredible depth and learning the nuances of each one give a decent advantage to the player (spotting loot in wall tiles, having perfect rhythm/decision making while swarmed in constant fractions of seconds, learning to love glass items, when to use a long-hit vs wide-hit weapon, etc). I love roguelikes but rarely find the types that I REALLY love, particularly those that emulate a style of gameplay similar to NetHack while not having any one aspect be broken. The amazing soundtracks on top of a game which is already very easy to appreciate on its own merits is just icing on top of the cake.The difficulty is fine, in spite of a few claims otherwise. Dancepad mode is available for those who need slightly easier play. Altering the music can also allow for slower gameplay too. Hell, there's a character where you can avoid the beat mechanic entirely and which is very obviously there for players to train and get better, get a purer roguelike experience, or just clear the zones as quickly as possible. ANY review that bashes the game for not being easy in the main mode despite the many attempts by the devs to give easier options is just feeding into the mindset that games with hard base difficulty are bad. It's not only not fair but it's also greatly hindering games with permadeath and large death penalties from being developed. Hell, even I can't beat clear the second zone of Spelunky but I can still appreciate it.The only criticism of this game that I found fair was that unlocking the full story requires beating all four zones with three different characters, the last of which is a hardcore player character (one missed beat or any damage and you die and have to restart the zone). With vanilla gameplay, even knowing the game VERY well it borders on being a slight bit unreasonable. Bottom line: if you're not the kind of person who complains about how hard and punishing a /ROGUELIKE/ can be and if you're willing to put in enough time to appreciate the depth of mechanics then you'll love Necrodancer.Get the game. Love it and be a casual player if you'd like. It's perfectly made for that too. But hopefully you'll join in the more competitive scene and see how far the rabbit hole really goes. It could certainly use some action and the game can absolutely support it.Best of luck unlocking Coda.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Oh this game. Simple, difficult, and incredibly addictive. Even in it's incomplete form I have been pouring hours in every day. Necrodancer's art style is charming and beautiful, the soundtrack is earwormy and wonderful, and the gameplay is tough as nails but fair. Play through each zone seperately and aquire gems to unlock new equipment and expand your health or magic, and then attempt Hardcore Mode where the game really begins. Completion of hardcore modes takes skill and concentration, but the feeling of actually doing well at it is quite rewarding. Unlike many other roguelikes, this game is NOT gear dependant. You CAN beat it with nothing but the starting equipment. It's just extremely hard. My only complaint at this point is I WANT MORE STUFF. EXPAND EXPAND EXPAND! |hugs game|

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Crypt of the NecroDancer is a dungeon-crawler game set to the beat of music. The game is divided into 4 zones with several levels in each zone. In each level you must use your arrow keys to move your character in time beat of the music, the longer you can keep in time, the larger bonsues you can get which result in increased gold drops from enemies you defeat. At the end of the song, you are automatically dropped to the next level (or zone boss if you're on the last level of the zone) or you can procede to the next level by finding the stairs which may need to be opened by defeating a tougher enemy, such as a dragon.There are numerous items and weapons you can find and buy which aid you against the foes  you may encounter, from items that heal you, torches which increase your visability and charms which may freeze enemies, as well as many more. Some of these you use by using different key combinations such as down + left or up + right. Different types of weapons may have increased range, heal you if you get a certain number of kills or attack multiple enemies at once (including those positioned diagonally to you). The levels are randomly generated so there is lots of replayability, this does mean you can be screwed over on occasion depending on how certain items and enemies are spawned or not spawned, but that just adds to the fun. The soundtrack from what I've heard so far (still on Zone 1) is good, the music seems to be a kind of funky techno/trance thing, however you can set any of your own music for one or more levels. This can potentially make the game harder or easier. Enya was quite hard, but slaying enemies to the sounds of Werewolves of London by Warren Zevon was fun. As mentioned before, the level ends when the song ends so I would not recommend selecting any of the short tracks that make up the Abbey Road medley by the Beatles for example.  Crypt of the NecroDancer is quite a difficult game, especially if you don't have the greatest sense of rythmn. It can be quite easy to die especially if a dragon appears and you're just armed with the starting dagger, but despite dying often, this does not give me the desire to rage quit but rather just to try again and I still find it fun. So despite being hard, for me personally this isn't a bad thing.TLDR:I recommend this game+ Fun, easy to understand which you can+ Funky music as well as the ability to use your own + Randomly generated levels so you can repeat the same levels time and time again and each time it'll be different+ A good number of characters you can unlock+ Lots of items and weapons you can find and buy, as well as upgrades- Quite hard, I must say *dies again*- There doesn't seem to be a huge number of levels in total

												I'm usually not that into roguelikes but this game really hooked me in in the first few minutes I played it. The rhythmic aspect of the game makes it constantly challenging  but rarely unfair (because let's be real, it's not a roguelike if you don't have the occasional "holy christ what is happening the floor is suddenly monsters" moment) and the enemies are well designed and are all individually easy to understand, but collectively challenging to play around.The second major selling point here is the music, which is great and super catchy. There's also the option to use your own custom music for each level.And the shopkeeper sings too.10/10

 Crypt of the NecroDancer review 	After 200 hours of playtime I think it is finally the time to do a review of Crypt of the NecroDancer... so lets get startedCrypt of the NecroDancer is a Rythm based Rouge-like, so If you like the awesome soundtrack and don`t mind restarting from the beginning, then this would be the perfect game for you.+Great Soundtrack by DannyB (Also did music for Meatboy etc.), A_Rival and FamilyJules7x+Graphics - They fit the game really good (Dancing skeletons too)+Easy contols (You only have to use 4 arrow keys, but you can bind the button combos to other buttons too)+Contoller/Dancepad support+Highly skill based (You can beat the game without picking up any items)+Awesome Shopkeeper+++ Finally beating that boss you never beaten before-Getting into the game, as you have to learn the enemy pattern, get into the beat etc.Crypt of the Necrodancer gets a solid 9.5/10 from me :Pbtw... only game you can play with 1 hand  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Do you like rougelikes, rhythm games, adventure games, top down dungeon crawlers, and/or cryptic (Neh heh heh) feeling games, play it. The gameplay consists of moving to the beat of your heart (or music) and only to the beat and figuring out the enemy’s attack patterns. It will take some learning but you'll enjoy dancing while being tortured by this game.Note: Only play this game if you like a challenge and rougelikes. This is rather forgiving for its genre (you can buy upgrades that never go away and only have to redo the stage, not the entire game) and can be appealing to lots of people. Pick it up and give it a try.

As mentioned before, the level ends when the song ends so I would not recommend selecting any of the short tracks that make up the Abbey Road medley by the Beatles for example.  Crypt of the NecroDancer is quite a difficult game, especially if you don't have the greatest sense of rythmn. It can be quite easy to die especially if a dragon appears and you're just armed with the starting dagger, but despite dying often, this does not give me the desire to rage quit but rather just to try again and I still find it fun. So despite being hard, for me personally this isn't a bad thing.TLDR:I recommend this game+ Fun, easy to understand which you can+ Funky music as well as the ability to use your own + Randomly generated levels so you can repeat the same levels time and time again and each time it'll be different+ A good number of characters you can unlock+ Lots of items and weapons you can find and buy, as well as upgrades- Quite hard, I must say *dies again*- There doesn't seem to be a huge number of levels in total

It's Dangerous to Dance AloneRouge-Lite games have been done to death within the past couple of years. Retro Aestetic? CheckPermadeath? CheckGenerated Dungeon? CheckWhat makes Crypt of the Necrodancer stand out in my opinion?well..It's rhythm based. I love rhythm based games which was the main reason for me buying this.It's also harder than it looks. In order to move you gotta hit the arrow keys (or whatever button you wish to map to) along with the beat. Unlike some Rouge-Lite's: losing doesnt feel like a waste of time. You just want to return and try to nail the rythm with your finger tips. If you collect enough Diamonds you can buy loot in your lobby and the diamondsremain in your inventory until you restart a new zone.If you somehow are a genius and have perfect rythm and beat the game there's always daily challenges to back once a day to further up your skills.Also if you like the idea of a DDR dance pad then there's a dance pad mode to improve your cardio and dance if you want to be the Patrick Swayze of Crypt of the Nectrodancer.

 Crypt of the NecroDancer review 	After 200 hours of playtime I think it is finally the time to do a review of Crypt of the NecroDancer... so lets get startedCrypt of the NecroDancer is a Rythm based Rouge-like, so If you like the awesome soundtrack and don`t mind restarting from the beginning, then this would be the perfect game for you.+Great Soundtrack by DannyB (Also did music for Meatboy etc.), A_Rival and FamilyJules7x+Graphics - They fit the game really good (Dancing skeletons too)+Easy contols (You only have to use 4 arrow keys, but you can bind the button combos to other buttons too)+Contoller/Dancepad support+Highly skill based (You can beat the game without picking up any items)+Awesome Shopkeeper+++ Finally beating that boss you never beaten before-Getting into the game, as you have to learn the enemy pattern, get into the beat etc.Crypt of the Necrodancer gets a solid 9.5/10 from me :Pbtw... only game you can play with 1 hand  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Crypt of the NecroDancer is a dungeon-crawler game set to the beat of music. The game is divided into 4 zones with several levels in each zone. In each level you must use your arrow keys to move your character in time beat of the music, the longer you can keep in time, the larger bonsues you can get which result in increased gold drops from enemies you defeat. At the end of the song, you are automatically dropped to the next level (or zone boss if you're on the last level of the zone) or you can procede to the next level by finding the stairs which may need to be opened by defeating a tougher enemy, such as a dragon.There are numerous items and weapons you can find and buy which aid you against the foes  you may encounter, from items that heal you, torches which increase your visability and charms which may freeze enemies, as well as many more. Some of these you use by using different key combinations such as down + left or up + right. Different types of weapons may have increased range, heal you if you get a certain number of kills or attack multiple enemies at once (including those positioned diagonally to you). The levels are randomly generated so there is lots of replayability, this does mean you can be screwed over on occasion depending on how certain items and enemies are spawned or not spawned, but that just adds to the fun. The soundtrack from what I've heard so far (still on Zone 1) is good, the music seems to be a kind of funky techno/trance thing, however you can set any of your own music for one or more levels. This can potentially make the game harder or easier. Enya was quite hard, but slaying enemies to the sounds of Werewolves of London by Warren Zevon was fun. As mentioned before, the level ends when the song ends so I would not recommend selecting any of the short tracks that make up the Abbey Road medley by the Beatles for example.  Crypt of the NecroDancer is quite a difficult game, especially if you don't have the greatest sense of rythmn. It can be quite easy to die especially if a dragon appears and you're just armed with the starting dagger, but despite dying often, this does not give me the desire to rage quit but rather just to try again and I still find it fun. So despite being hard, for me personally this isn't a bad thing.TLDR:I recommend this game+ Fun, easy to understand which you can+ Funky music as well as the ability to use your own + Randomly generated levels so you can repeat the same levels time and time again and each time it'll be different+ A good number of characters you can unlock+ Lots of items and weapons you can find and buy, as well as upgrades- Quite hard, I must say *dies again*- There doesn't seem to be a huge number of levels in total

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game that intrigued me from the first moment I heard about it.Just about everything in this game is absolutly charming; from the overall visual design, to smaller details like the singing shopkeep, you can realy feel the love and passion that went in to this project. However the thing that truly sets NecroDancer apart from any other game is how it brilliantly blends the dungeon crawler and rhythm game genres into something new, and in my opinion, something greater than the sum of its parts.As a part of the Steam Awards, Valve featured The “We Didn’t Think Of Everything” Award, which allows us the chance to nominate the games that might not fit into an existing category. As such, I would like to nominate Crypt of the NecroDancer for The “Most Innovative Gameplay Mechanics” Award 2016. I have certainly loved playing this game, and I hope that you will enjoy it too!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Disclaimer. Do not get this game if you like your fancy 100% game completion rate, as this game's achievements will tear it to shreds. They are not glitched or anything, but some are unbelievably hard.But regardless it is one of the best games I ever played. It is almost perfect, though there are a few flaws here and there, mostly minor.The biggest thing is that playing one of the hardest characters is a decent part of the game's story, most of the characters aren't "easy" per say, but dying in one hit to anything, including missing a beat is a little extreme to have to go through to progress the story, even if you don't take the hardcore route and do it by playing the zones individually.I heard that you can do it co-op with Bard as your partner to make getting the last bits of the story more reasonable, but I haven't tried it and even if it helps, you're still in for hell of a ride. (I decided against playing that character until I get a few more achievements)Another thing is how one of the challenge characters work, the one where you have to play twice as fast, but the speed of the music stays the same, which is odd surprising that this is a game where you have to play along with the beats of the song and it doesn't quite work right in that case, but apparently there's a mod for that.And the last nitpick being how the singing shopkeeper vocals clash with the metal version of the soundtrack.But regardless it's a great game with good music and providing a unique and fun experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												I LOVE this game. Take NetHack, add cute pixel graphics and a charming story, make the turns happen to the beat of music, and compress the whole experience down to a bite size morsel you can consume in 30 minutes - and you have this little gem. I bought the game for $7US, and then promptly bought the soundtrack for $15US which is the only music I’ve listened to for the past 5 weeks.This game starts off hard, and then gets brutally hard as you unlock the more advanced characters. But I’ve never felt the game cheated me, despite dozens of deaths. Each one was my fault, and mine alone. I wasn’t fast enough, I zigged when I should have zagged, I didn’t prioritise the right enemy, I didn’t control a boss’s movement. There is an element of RNGesus, but your skill and experience is the biggest factor in your success, or failure, by far. Did I mention I love this game?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Warning to all who dare to enter the Crypt - If you have no internal metronome, turn back now. Seriously, you need to be able to hold a beat to even consider playing this game in full. And yes, this is an important distinction - I've seen several attempted runs from someone who didn't, they were very short lived. Another warning - If you have any music preferences, they're about to be formatted.Anyways, Crypt of the Necrodancer is a roguelike rhythm game. The roguelike takes precedence for the most part, but it's good to keep a rhythm-game mentality. The gameplay can be a bit tricky at first, but superb once you get the hang of it. The actual progression is a bit basic (not uncommon for roguelikes), but that's not too major a problem. The biggest issue most people have with the game is that the rhythm-based controls are a bit gimmicky or unwieldy, but I had very little problems with them and they didn't get in my way too much.But enough about the gameplay. I'm writing this review to commend the SOUNDTRACK. This game's BGM alone is worth the $15 admission fee, and that's a bargain. I've been known to listen to the soundtrack on repeat for hours on end, and am working on burning the soundtrack onto a CD as I type this. And if the planets align and someone is born who doesn't like the music - you can set your own too.So in summary: If you think you can manage the gameplay, get the full game. If you don't think you can manage it, already have the game, or need a new soundtrack to listen to in your spare time, buy the soundtrack. And if by some strange coincidence you neither want this game's gameplay nor it's soundtrack, then and ONLY then will I permit you to not touch this game.What are you waiting for... pick up the beat!

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								A creative take on the roguelike genre which replaces most of the RPG-elements traditionally seen in roguelike games with a rhythm "gimmick". In the strict sense it is not however a roguelike because of the lack of actual permadeath. Throughout your runthrough you will encounter diamonds which you can pick up and unlock permanent powerups in the hub-area.Before buying the game keep in mind that it is an Early-Access game, meaning certain features you enjoy might be changed or removed entirely (Rust comes to mind). The game is also farily expensive at 15 euros/15 dollars.The soundtrack is mainly composed of "chiptune electronica", an easy way of describing it would be to think about "8-Bit" music and traditional electronica, This genre of music fits the artstyle and gameplay and is one of the best things about the gameThe game has tremendous replay value if you're a completionist. Similarly to other Rogue-Likes the fun lies in losing repeteadly and learning from your mistakes, only to come back stronger each time and eventually beat the game. There are several game-modes including a  hardcore mode which takes away all afformentioned permanent powerups to provide a true roguelike experience, and a co-op mode If you're a fan of rhythm games like guitar hero, osu! and DDR or roguelike games like Binding of Isaac, Dungeons of Dredmor or Risk of Rain it will more than likely be a good game for you, however if you're new to either genres i'd reccomend to check out Binding of Isaac which costs 1/3rd of what this game does before coming to your conclusion.They need to add steam Achievements and Worskshop to it eventually thoughsolid 8/10 for me

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												I waited to get this game for weeks and I was not disappointed. It's an absolute joy to play, balancing the strategy of roguelikes with the addictiveness of rhythm games. Even though the game itself is short, there's a surprising amount of content with several characters and dozens of items to unlock. Some characters even have their own alternate soundtracks, which constantly keeps the game fresh even after dozens of plays.Really, the only stain marring of this gem is the game's poorly-designed story mode. In order to see all of the game's cutscenes, bosses and songs, one must beat it from start to finish with three specific characters. The first two are fine, but the third is an insane leap in difficulty that requires weeks of practice and an incredible streak of luck to beat.Final verdict: If you pick up this game, expect to have a good time while it lasts. Try out all the characters, pick up some mods, get some achievements, but don't expect that you'll be able to finish it.

 Crypt of the NecroDancer review 	After 200 hours of playtime I think it is finally the time to do a review of Crypt of the NecroDancer... so lets get startedCrypt of the NecroDancer is a Rythm based Rouge-like, so If you like the awesome soundtrack and don`t mind restarting from the beginning, then this would be the perfect game for you.+Great Soundtrack by DannyB (Also did music for Meatboy etc.), A_Rival and FamilyJules7x+Graphics - They fit the game really good (Dancing skeletons too)+Easy contols (You only have to use 4 arrow keys, but you can bind the button combos to other buttons too)+Contoller/Dancepad support+Highly skill based (You can beat the game without picking up any items)+Awesome Shopkeeper+++ Finally beating that boss you never beaten before-Getting into the game, as you have to learn the enemy pattern, get into the beat etc.Crypt of the Necrodancer gets a solid 9.5/10 from me :Pbtw... only game you can play with 1 hand  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												With the surge in popularity of roguelikes, it was an eventuality that developers would need to do something other than merely make another punishing dungeon crawler like the original Rogue. While there have been many grand takes on the formula by entrants like Rogue Legacy, FTL, and Nuclear Throne, the last concept I was expecting was a roguelike crossed with a rhythm game. I wondered how this mashup would even work, but it turned out that the answer was quite simple; you just press the arrow keys in time with the music’s beat while traversing floors of a dungeon. Simple premise, but Necrodancer is deviously challenging because of its rhythmical movement, even if it can suffer from incredible roguelike luck.Dance Dance Revolution meets a dungeon crawler is the quickest and easiest way to define the game. Both the enemies and your movements are tied to the music’s beat, where trying to move on an offbeat will result in an awkward hop in place, and skipping a beat will act as a ‘passed turn’, both dropping your combo. Most enemies have a specific pattern or interaction with the beat, like how skeletons will raise their arms for one beat before moving forward on the following one, or how minotaurs will charge in a straight rhythmic line upon direct sight. Learning these patterns and quirks will let you dance around enemies, and pulling out deft, tactical evasions of enemy mobs never fails to be incredibly satisfying. Items and equipment are available to be discovered or purchased (via a rather vocal and potentially homicidal shopkeeper), including weaponry like longswords that supply an extra square of attack range, boots that let you walk across hazards without a care, rings that bestow various effects like increasing the amount of gold dropped by enemies, spectacles that will let you see what treasure you’ll get from chests and other containers, and other fun utilities. Some loadouts of equipment are more preferable than others, and gathering them becomes a priority in order to make later sections laughably easy. No need to worry about lava or ice when you can just float above the floor! No need to worry about health when you have a blood bow that lets you kill enemies from afar and replenish your health! There are trade-offs between items and gear of course and your ‘this is the run’ loadout will no doubt vary from my own, but once you get an optimal loadout, the game’s later challenging sections become trivial save for boss fights. On the flip side, poor luck resulting in less than ideal loadouts can also occur, and raw player skill can only go so far in some cases.The challenge in Necrodancer primarily comes from how the enemies never -ever- falter in their timing and movements with the music; The player however can (and will, on your first few attempts) make mistakes, thus making a missed beat punishing or potentially run-ending - Not to mention you lose your gold multiplier from being struck by an enemy. Many roguelikes require situational and environmental awareness in order to avoid losing a run, but Necrodancer demands auditory awareness on top of it all, what with how the music is your means of moving. Thankfully the developers included a visual aid of a heart that beats with every beat, as well as scales that close in on the heart to cue you on when movement or attacking is possible, which is both kind and intelligent on their part. I cannot list the number of times I’ve panicked and had to look at the heart beat in order to get back on rhythm. The music doesn’t last forever however, and if you’re still on the dungeon floor before the song ends and you don’t reach the exit, you’ll automatically be ejected to the next floor. Also as a kind gesture there’s a bestiary that lets you practice against encountered enemies to study their patterns and traits - Considering the later difficulty, these aids help balance the field. Necrodancer had more characters and modes of play added during its period in early access, like dance mat support, a cooperative mode, and even a custom track function to let you jive around dungeon floors with your own music. The core game doesn’t really change, it simply becomes modified with the various characters and different rules. There’s even a puzzle mode that gives you a floor to tackle using specific items and strategies that quickly becomes head scratching, and of course included is a daily seed that gives all players the same dungeon to take on and go for a high score. Once you get a solid grasp of the game and can get successful runs frequently, these various ways to play improve the longevity of a game that would’ve otherwise been rather short and easy to gleam over.Your purchase for Crypt of the Necrodancer will primarily rely on whether or not you enjoy the soundtrack; if you don’t, chances are you’re not going to have a good time. Rhythm games can only be so enjoyable if the soundtrack doesn’t sit well with the player, and in my case I’m a fan for most of Necrodancer’s tracks. Danny Baranowsky’s composition is full, vibrant and seldom with any musical downtime, which lends a very active listening experience to the game; for a game where the combat and movement is based on musical beats, having any song be boring or lacking instrumentation would result in dull gameplay. The backing synth for many of the tracks end up giving the soundtrack an almost gothic/horror feel but doing so within its techno/rocking manner. Of course, that’s when you discover later on that there are not one but -two- remixed soundtracks in later sections of the story mode, with the first striking chords of a laser disco and the second more grounded in reality with heavier, nastier rock. All three soundtracks have been uploaded to YouTube if you want to judge for yourself, which is advisable homework when it comes to purchasing rhythm games.Necrodancer’s strengths lie in its longevity, challenge and gimmick; like many roguelikes the difficulty does become somewhat trivial once you are knowledgeable of its components and mechanics. That said, the demands the game makes of the player ensures that you can know what items work well together and can dance around enemy patterns easily, but it all means nothing if you can’t execute tactfully. Back up this challenge with fantastic music and multiple ways to play, and you get a roguelike that is both satisfying and incredibly enjoyable.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
												A roguelike (i.e. a turn based game where you explore a dungeon, with a different layout every game, finding loot and slaying monsters), with the turns set to a musical beat. NecroDancer negates most of the genre's traditional flaws.NecroDancer has adorable pixel art in a style reminiscent of the good 2D Legend of Zelda games, but more colourful. Roguelikes traditionally have either ASCII art or crappy looking tiles.NecroDancer is fast paced and games typically last no more than 30 minutes. Roguelikes traditionally take hours to play.NecroDancer has wonderful music and sounds. Roguelikes traditionally have either nonexistent or very bad music and sound effects.NecroDancer has simple, predictable rules for enemies (albeit challenging because you have to act on them fast). Roguelikes traditionally make the dungeon monsters all behave erratically.NecroDancer has simple controls. You play with literally just the arrow keys, occasionally pressing 2 arrows together. Traditional roguelikes such as NetHack not only have a different action for every single character A through Z both with and without the shift key, but also have an "extended" set of commands that you have to type by name to use, because there just aren't enough keys on a keyboard for them.The main downside is that NecroDancer is really difficult to play if you have a massive hangover like I do right now. Traditional roguelikes are no more punishingly difficult than usual when you can barely see the screen and have to stare at each individual inch with one eye, because you can just take as long as you need to pray at the porcelain throne in between turns.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is a dungeon-crawler, rouge-like, rythm RPG with loot. You can only move and attack monsters along with the beat of the song playing, so you have to memorize the pattern of each monster's movements and attacks to kill them. It's not as hard as I made it sound, but can still be fairly difficult. If it gets too hard, which isn't likely, you can go into a training zone of the monster you struggle to defeat.Moving and attacking with the beat isn't hard, and deploying weapons and attacks you've aqcuired just takes a combo of two arrow keys.The story of the game is nothing special, and that's completely fine. The replayability is beautiful, and there is also a daily challenge to keep you playing.What I love about this game the most is that although it's hard, I've never rage quit. The fun outweighs the difficulty to keep you playing. You can add custom music from your computer's files, but it will disable achievements.It's a beautiful game with a great soundtrack, achievements, and Steam Workshop support to change the textures (Undertale, Megaman ect.) If you like retro RPGs and rythm based games, it's for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Game goes to BSOD when launching on my Windows XP DDR-Machine PC with two Cobalt Flux Dance Pads...The PC does meet and exceed the system requirements...I really want to play this... Please message me if there's a fix, but for now I can't fully enjoy this game as it doesn't work on my DDR Rig and I just can't have as much fun playing it with a keyboard...It is definitely a great idea, and lots of fun, but I cannot recommend it for the all the people out there like me that have a dedicated Stepmania build that hasn't been updated in a while. By all means the game should be able to run fine. I've commented on the forums and if I'm helped out, I will defintely play through the game and give it the review it deserves.EDIT: I've been using GlovePIE to play this game with Wiimotes with my friends on the huge TV and it's really great fun. I'll post my configuration on the forums. Still no DDR pads, though. Hopefully it'll get straightened out soon; the developers have been talking to me and trying to help out, and that's all I could ever ask for. Really a shame I got so many downvotes on my prior review, I wasn't trying to be an asshat or anything, but it's very frustrating when you buy a game and spend hours trying to get it to work with no success. I'm sure we've all been there.Anyway, tl;dr: AMAZING GAME, BUY IT IF YOU LOVE RHYTHM GAMES OR CLASSIC ROGUELIKES

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												If you haven't bought this already, buy it.Pros: The dungeons are different every time.Tons of characters with very different playstyles (ex the default character has to move to the beat, another one can move to his own beat, one more has infinite bombs, etc.)The music will get you. I literally cannot get the music out of my head.Pretty easy to understand. You only use the arrow keys.Daily Challenge (if that's your thing). Every day a random dungeon is set up and you get one run to score as high as possible. There's a global leaderboard.Pop in your own music and play to its beats.Cons:If you don't like rhythm games, well you won't like this. It is very VERY hard at first. You meet lots of enemies who each have their own movement and attack patterns. You will probably die a lot, and it can be frustrating. There are a lot of items that can make the game either a (relative) breeze or very hard if you don't have them.I don't really know if it's a con or not, but it was frustrating.End of list.TL;DRThis is my GOTY.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												(Previous reviews below are still accurate)Steam Awards Nomination re-reviewRogue-like rhythm game, that should be enough to sell this for anyone interested, but the music is really good, too, and the gameplay doesn't get stale. Even has local co-op. 9/10 for real, not exaggeration.Post-EA review:The game is now out of early-access, and I've been playing the crap out of it all along.  Some sort of magical undefined aspect giving it massive replayability.  I'm not even using custom MP3s because the built in songs are great (and well-balanced).  I did buy the dance pad (optional) for like $350 and haven't even had a chance to use it yet, but the game is amazing enough on the keyboard :)  I haven't beaten zone 4 yet, but it's tons of fun trying and dying, I'll get it eventually!  Buy it, play it, get good at it, and enjoy the crap out of it.  Best game in a long time.  My Original Early Access review:First impression: I played this for like 5 hours in a row, it's so sweet!  Now I wanna buy a dance pad for $300Rhythm based combat and gameplay with roguelike aspects and plenty of gear upgrading!  This game is already spectacular, and it's not even finished.  BUY IT NOW!  The .ogg music files are just sitting in your Steam directory, so don't buy the soundtrack unless you're doing it to give the devs more money/support :)

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is a competently executed Roguelike with a gimmick that you have to make all of your moves to the beat of some annoying techno music. This gimmick is cool for only a few minutes, then it gets annoying. Fortunately, there's a character you can unlock called "The Bard" who gets rid of that gimmick and lets you play it like a normal, non-musical roguelike, and that makes you realize that it is a solid, though unremarkable, roguelike experience underneath the gimmick. It's not life-changingly good, but it's not bad either.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												This game, just by hearing the type that it is, causes most people to doubt it or wrinkle their nose in confusion. You'd probably think that at first too, it's a dungeon crawler, a rhythm game, and a totally amazing rogue-like game. How does it work? We may never know, but one thing's for certain: a game of this difficulty that's this fun to play deserves more recognition. Like, a lot more. The soundtracks, all three of them, all provide something awesome to the game. I've only had it for a couple days now (yeah, I'm that guy who shows up three hours into the party and acts all cool about it) but that doesn't mean I don't know that this is a game far beyond amazing. Cheers to everyone at Brace Yourself Games, you've created a masterpiece of a game that lots of people will agree is easily one of the best rhythm games out there. I'd go on, but there are too many things that are awesome about this game that I'd probably end up breaking the character limit or something. Don't worry Rhythm Heaven, you've always got a special place in my heartBut seriously, get this game. It's more than worth the $15, no doubt about it.

Early Access Review
								Addictive, catchy, hard. I feel a "puzzle game" vibe from some of the things you have to do in this game.The ability to quickly restart a run makes this game incredibly difficult to stop playing, and the sound blending between the Hot and Cold area themes in Zone 3 makes it so that particular music never gets old, even as I try for the 50th time to beat the flipping first stage...Due to the amount of enemies you have to rapidly and strategically dispose of at some points, I feel like mastering this game will take me quite some time. That's a good thing in this case, because it's all due to simple concepts blending together to make something challenging. You know where you went wrong and why you died, and if you didn't, the deathcam is very helpful in pointing that out.The majority of the upgrades could probably do with some sort of price increase. I had no issue unlocking pretty much all of them pretty quickly, before I had even a chance to use 80% of them, and stat keeping would be cool too, but these are just balance suggestions rather than complaints and they barely put a scratch on the rock solid game that is CotN.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												Ever wanted to play Dance Dance Revolution but with a bit of action and narrative added to the mix? Well Crypt of the Necrodancer is a good waltz in the right direction! Crypt of the Necrodancer is a rhythm, rogue-like dungeon crawler that has you moving and attacking to the beat of the tune.The gameplay as stated above generally has you doing everything to the beat of the tune by using only the arrow keys, whether your in the main lobby or fighting your way through the next level. You can even set the game up to be played with a dance pad! In the main lobby you're able to buy permanent upgrades to weapons, armor, spells and trinkets found in the levels,  practice against certain enemies, read background about the game and choose which zones you'll be "dancing" through along with a few other options. In the zones themselves the overall objective is to find the stairwell to the next level, however that doesn't necessarily mean you should be racing for the stairwell with all due haste. Diamonds, your currency for permanent upgrades, can only be found while exploring these levels, and once you are done with a zone you will only have those diamonds in your next trip to the lobby. Once you decide to go back into a zone you will lose all the diamonds you collected on the previous trip! So finding enough diamonds to buy those ever increasingly costing upgrades can be well worth the exploration. Remember how I said those permanent upgrades to items only affect what you find in the levels and are not given to the characters themselves? Those items can either be found throughout said levels or in the shop in each level. Enemies drop gold in order for you to purchase these items from the store, and if you keep up with the beat, a coin multiplier is added when you kill enemies so you get more gold for your kills. With that being said the levels are on a time limit, can you guess what that time limit is? The music! If the music you are playing to finishes before you get to the stairs you are immediately dropped to the next level. On top of this each level has a boss, and not only will you lose your multiplier combo if the song ends but rather than being dropped into a relatively safe room at the beginning of the next level you will have to face that levels boss immediately if the previous levels boss wasn't defeated. The games uses pixel art and uses it's musical theme in some of the enemy designs. For example the Minotaur enemy's  horns are actually a harp and the reaper has a microphone attached to his scythe. This leads to a very visually pleasing themed art style that looks and plays it's part.The music is electronic and catchy, even making you want to stay on a level just to keep listening. In lower levels of each zone the beat is actually slower so that players adjust to the beat as it get faster with each level.Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fun and enchanting game and is well worth your time and if you have a love for rhythm and rogue-like games alike, this original gem will not disappoint you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												You ever been listening to music while walking down the street and subconsciously (or consciously, I don't judge) timed your steps to the beat of the music?Crypt of the Necrodancer is like that, except when you ♥♥♥♥ it up somebody stabs you and you lose your coin multiplier bonus. But that's okay, because there are about a dozen different weapons - not counting their materials modifiers, which multiplies that by six - that you can use to just stab them right back.Four zones, each with their own surprises and mechanics, enemies with varied movement patterns that make the game feel like chess on a really short timer, really ♥♥♥♥♥in' awesome music, and a shopkeeper who sings along to it! ON TOP OF THAT, there are a few reasons to try and replay the game, including more story and unlockable characters.  I mean, you know, if replaying it for the sake of playing it wasn't enough.Oh yeah, and if you get sick of the music (pfft) you can add your own music. Add some metal, give yourself a heart attack, it's great fun!Honestly, I'd recommend this game to anyone and everyone who would listen. It's that good. If you're on the fence, get it. If you like roguelikes, get it. If you like rhythm games, get it. If you like both roguelikes and rhythm games, for the love of god, GET IT.

Enemies drop gold in order for you to purchase these items from the store, and if you keep up with the beat, a coin multiplier is added when you kill enemies so you get more gold for your kills. With that being said the levels are on a time limit, can you guess what that time limit is? The music! If the music you are playing to finishes before you get to the stairs you are immediately dropped to the next level. On top of this each level has a boss, and not only will you lose your multiplier combo if the song ends but rather than being dropped into a relatively safe room at the beginning of the next level you will have to face that levels boss immediately if the previous levels boss wasn't defeated. The games uses pixel art and uses it's musical theme in some of the enemy designs. For example the Minotaur enemy's  horns are actually a harp and the reaper has a microphone attached to his scythe. This leads to a very visually pleasing themed art style that looks and plays it's part.The music is electronic and catchy, even making you want to stay on a level just to keep listening. In lower levels of each zone the beat is actually slower so that players adjust to the beat as it get faster with each level.Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fun and enchanting game and is well worth your time and if you have a love for rhythm and rogue-like games alike, this original gem will not disappoint you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												You ever been listening to music while walking down the street and subconsciously (or consciously, I don't judge) timed your steps to the beat of the music?Crypt of the Necrodancer is like that, except when you ♥♥♥♥ it up somebody stabs you and you lose your coin multiplier bonus. But that's okay, because there are about a dozen different weapons - not counting their materials modifiers, which multiplies that by six - that you can use to just stab them right back.Four zones, each with their own surprises and mechanics, enemies with varied movement patterns that make the game feel like chess on a really short timer, really ♥♥♥♥♥in' awesome music, and a shopkeeper who sings along to it! ON TOP OF THAT, there are a few reasons to try and replay the game, including more story and unlockable characters.  I mean, you know, if replaying it for the sake of playing it wasn't enough.Oh yeah, and if you get sick of the music (pfft) you can add your own music. Add some metal, give yourself a heart attack, it's great fun!Honestly, I'd recommend this game to anyone and everyone who would listen. It's that good. If you're on the fence, get it. If you like roguelikes, get it. If you like rhythm games, get it. If you like both roguelikes and rhythm games, for the love of god, GET IT.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												This game is an absolute delight! I'd heard good things about it before purchasing it, but I had no idea just how much I would come to enjoy it until finally playing it. I was unfamiliar with the roguelike genre until Crypt of the NecroDancer, but this game totally hooked me with the concept. It gives things an interesting replay value every time you pick it up, and the variety of items and playstyles/characters give it a lot of depth. The soundtrack alone hooked me when I first heard it, and if anything, I'd highly recommend it for the tunes at the very least. It's challenging, and the learning curve from the first zone to the others is steep at times, but you can try again immediately should you die so the frustration doesn't get too overwhelming. Be careful with this game, though--it's definitely addicting!100000/10, will necrodance to my own grave and beyond.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Crypt of the Necrodancer's a really inventive game. It takes two things that don't really go together--rhythm and dungeon crawling--and mixes them so beautifully. Playing a game like this to the rhythm of music makes it incredibly easy to get into a certain flow. Combat is smooth and challenging. The sound design and OST are phenomenal and really add to the overall atmosphere of the game. Having been keeping track of the game since early in its Early Access days, I was satisfied with the product back then and am even more so satisfied with it now. Crypt of the Necrodancer is truly worth all fifteen dollars you pay for it. I could not recommend this game more.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												I got this game a few months ago and it is really fun to play!The reason I keep coming back to this game are these reasons:   -Great soundtrack   -Decent story (after finishing the first character, Cadence)   -Great gameplay   -Isn't a game you will beat in a week or two   -5 different soundtracks   -Support for custom music   -Mod support (texture mods and music replacements)   -Level editor (You need to beat the game with one character first)That all may sound great, but this game is NOT for everyone!  This game requires a lot of patience and practice.  It's fairly straight forward to play, but extremely hard to master.  The game requires you to beat each zone (individually at least) without missing a beat of the song and perfect movements.  If you cannot keep tempo/rhythm, this will not be a game for you.  The game heavily relies on you to be able to keep up with fast tempos.  If you can't do that, this game may not be for you! This game, however could be good for you if you do want to practice keeping tempo.I would rate this game 9/10 for being ridiculously fun, but a bit infuriating when trying to beat the game with a harder character (like Aria or the monk)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												As an off-and-on fan of rogue-lite/like games, I am always torn determining the amount of skill and the amount of luck you will find in these games. Unseen probabilities within games are something I always am wary of complaining about when I could've had some really bad luck.However, Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game where I blamed myself more so when I made errors than blame the odds against me. This is the first rogue-LIKE where I could tell I was improving myself, and it's the first one in the genre where the demands on the player's skill were mandatory.Because with each failure through the familiarity of the controls and the coodrination of my fingers to the bass-line of the music I was reading the enemy telegraphed moves. Or adjusting myself to a new tempo-change. Or finding myself becoming at ease with the bizarre control-scheme. (Minus the DDR pad.)The Rogue-Like With A BeatThe novelty of this game is that it takes the game of Rogue and gives it a beat. Literally. The musical theme is not solely an aesthetic. The gameplay is interwoven into the music itself. From the way you move around/attack to the amount of time you have to explore the dungeons. Once the song ends, you are dropped to the next stage. (There are red-bars to show that the song is nearing its end.)Every movement/action you make is managed by moving in-time of the music. You and every enemy move according to that rule, which gives the game a charming tactical feel while sometimes relying on you thinking on the fly. Enemies attack in a specific manner which usually results in them having an "off-beat" to strike them. If you simply attack head-on with no regard, you'll die a lot.If that sounds too convulted about how the combat works, let me rephrase it like this: You are the metronome; the music is what you need to match (as the tempo can increase and decrease); and the enemies are the other instruments in play. The game plays more like reading a music sheet than another rogue-like game. The controls are the first major obstacle to get over, which you can play this game legitimately with either a controller or keyboard (or a DDR pad, which has an easier difficulty just for itself). To get the best experience, I would suggest you map your directional keys separate from your combo keys. There are too many moments towards Zone 2 and onwards that rely on twichy relfexes in-time with the music to coordinate your fingers in combinations.Thankfully, the game isn't too demanding on you maintaining a constant rhythm. If you're like me, I struggle to keep a rhythm going longer than a few seconds without going faster or slower than expected. The game is leniant on being perfect, but you cannot spam your movements. The game simply won't let you, and you won't be able to obtain the modifiers to your gold (and modified items) if you don't keep the beat.I was able to get past the first zone on my KB alone, but the second stage's music tripped me up when I had to make those split-second motions to drop a bomb or use an item. Switching out the combos to other keys fixed it for me, and I would strongly suggest that if you play the game with a controller you get the directional pad some love.Practice Makes PerfectionMany rogue-lites rely too much on probabilites of which you can and cannot control (FTL). Others rely on attention to details of your item and the levels to spot those small benefits to get you to the end (Binding of Isaac). Crypt of the NecroDancer is a part of the trend where they provide permanent progression across chunks of the game. (There is a story mode for purists who want to play a more traditional rogue-like experience. However, I chose the permanent item/stat increases as I am not the best at these type of games.)There are stat increases and new loot to give your next playthrough something to change it up as well as possibly improving your odds. None of which are mandatory--I wouldn't think of going without them--if you are good enough at the game to read your enemies' movements.Outside of the item/stat increases, you also have another means to improve your next game: Practice rooms.You have a training room for enemies and minibosses that unlocks with a certain amount of kills for every enemy, a boss pratice room (unlocked via currency you accumulate in every run, diamonds), and a weapon-training selection screen to practice in either room. These rooms are unlocked by finding trapped tradders within Zone 1 and 2 and unlocking them with the Golden Master Key.Having a story-mode option and a perma-progression system as choices is the best compromise as both the purists who prefer to learn the game on their own and everyone else has the means to finish the game. But it ain't so easy, nor free.The bosses cost in-game currency to unlock. And you can't simply practice on all the enemies from the get-go--you have to kill each enemy type several times to unlock them. Simply, you can't cheat yourself out of a challenge without investing first.(And if you don't like some items, you can discard them for diamonds with the Janitor).It Ain't No StepmaniaPerhaps the game's own lacking feature is the infamous difficulty of its genre. The game doesn't feel that hard.Make no mistake; the game is difficult for all the right reasons, and you will die a lot. But there are plenty of items to circumnavigate the game's difficulty, and some enemies that make me wonder how fair the game truly is.For example, blood items let you regain your health, slowly, with enough kills chained together. There are also magic spells that might stun enemies, blast horrizontally, or give you some buffs to become overpowered in some situations. I would chalk these up to limitations of making a novel game without all its polish.Some enemies also break the rules. There are some enemies that move in diagonal movements, which you are never allowed to do. The red-dragons also seem unfair without a "ranged" weapon (weapons that extend beyond one-tile, such as long-swords or broad-swords) to get around taking damage.Zone 2 seems to have a sharp difficulty spike because you start off with nothing (even if you finish Zone 1). So expect that you may still have some bad runs when you begin new zones.The only feature of this game I hadn't tried is adding your music into the game. This game's music was tailored for the game, and I am sure slow songs will break it while Megalovania will result in a very bad time.Shake Your Groove ThangThis is one of few rogue-likes I'll always come back to because it's a fun experience. It's not a brutal old-schooling, nor is it coddling to the new players. The game's sense of challenge makes an otherwirse creative deviation into a worthwhile game of its own.And how can you not have fun dancing on a plastic pad like an idiot?(Kudos to the devs who put this through Early Access and finished the game. As well as for adding new content to the game itself with no DLCs. If they have another product through Early Access, be sure to give them a second glance.)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												I've been addicted to this game since I started playing it. I am not a big fan of rogue-likes in general, but this game is among few rare exceptions.You have 4 zones to beat, each one contains 3 floors and a boss fight. Every zone has its own theme and enemies. But wait, there's more. The enemies each move to the beat in their own unique pattern, and you have to recognize it and adapt quickly. For example, some enemies might be moving along a scripted path, others try to go for you specifically, some might stay still for 2 beats and then move on the 3rd one, others might move on every beat, and so on. It's all very well done.During your dungeon crawling, you'll also come across a lot of items of varying degrees of helpfulness. You have healing items, weapons, armour, rings, spells, and even some unusual items. Some can spawn from the start, others require unlocking via collectible diamonds. You can even remove the less useful items from the dungeons via the janitor, so that there's more chances instead for chests to contain the items you find more useful.There is of course a fair bit of luck involved, as is pretty common with rogue-like games. At times you'll be lucky to find a nice weapon and other useful items early on, other times you'll just be spawning with enemies all around you. It is a very challenging game. You will die a lot. But you do learn to recognize the enemy movement patterns and eventually overcome them.I also really like the whole light-hearted theme the game is going for. I think the devs pulled it off perfectly. The music is also amazing and will just drag you in to the beat.In addition to the regular mode with the main character, you also get to unlock several other characters, which seem to have their own unique abilities (for example one of them can only confuse enemies but not kill, another is only able to use bombs, and so on). It all adds an extra challenge for those who want it. You can even go and practice fighting against specific enemies and bosses if you wish.Great game in general. Highly recommended.

								I might not have played this game that much, but I am absolutely in love with it. This game provides a fun and challenging experience for all players to enjoy. From the combat and movement system, to the wonderful and energetic music, this game is amazing, while not perfect, as it is in early alpha, it still keeps me entertained. Every enemy has a pattern to it, which means you need to memorize it to do good, there is no RNG nonsense. In the game you move and attack to a beat. Once you break the beat, or you lose your coin multiplier (for cadence at least, not sure about the other characters) which can make the game a lot harder on you. If you can keep a beat this game is for you. All in all I give it a 9/10 at the moment, rating subject to change as more updates come out.

												Excelent work! The Rhythm part isn't so precise as in Rhythm tengoku or similar games, but it does arise the need of thinking quickly, which makes it far better. Posted: March 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a rogue-like fan, I must admit that this game is really good despite being an early access game because you can't solely rely on your luck but you also really need to have the skills to complete a level.Pro(s): - Good gameplay by combining rhythm with dungeon crawler- Good design with cute pixel art graphics- High replayability because you can play with different modes and use different characters- An awesome soundtrack by Danny Baranowsky (I really enjoyed the music)- And a little bit tricky (like destroying walls with bomb to get a lot of money :P)Con(s):- The content is still not that much right now because it's still an early access but the workshop content from the community can fill the gap- The shortcut/hotkey for the items and spells is hard to be pressed using keyboard maybe it's different when using gamepad or dance pad since I don't have both- The enemies have fixed pattern and that makes the enemies predictable maybe the enemies need to have combination of patterns to make it unpredictableI highly recommend this game because it's challenging and fun and it has awesome soundtrack, you really need to buy the soundtrack as well

Posted: June 2, 2016
												Rhythm-based roguelike that has you move to the beat to kill and avoid monsters. Deceptively hard and good music. I was going to beat it to completion, but then Overwatch and The Witcher 3: Blood and Wine expansion came out. So take this recommendation for what it's worth: deserving of your time if you don't have the money or a good enough computer for other, better games. That's a back-handed compliment, but I'm not really a huge roguelike fan. That I played this long enough that I could no longer refund it is compliment enough. If you are the person who does not get easily convinced with positive reviews, better check this out, will keep it short.Crypt of the NecroDancer has an interesting concept and is quite unique among all the other rouge-like games. I agree with most of the positive reviews. Yet, this game lacks something essential which should keep your spark alive. To a certain extent it was okay, but then it feels like a mobile game you start with excitement and delete after a short while. If you like repetitive games (should also mention it has an unusual difficulty curve) you might give it a try. But I do not recommend it for the long term.

You might think that this just happened because your boss is an♥♥♥♥♥and while that part is also true, it's not the only truth behind it.In fact, he is afraid and he has to be afraid, because Crypt of the FreedomDancer is a lot more than just some indie book around music, it's actually a political concept that might open your eyes behind what you do and it might end up with you standing up, defending your democratic rights and take back what the sinister communist boss of yours took away from you a long time ago.Crypt of the LibertyDancer, or FREEDOM in short, is a political RTS shooting firefighter simulation in which you take the role of a supressed American worker that is enslaved by the liberal agenda of communists like Obama and Clinton. You have to dance in the rhythm that they dictate without congress approval and while doing that, you are trying to dismantle the system of injustice and slavery that they built up.Level by level you accomplish that by destroying their supression machine in form of evil monsters, skeletons and spiders that come down from your wall. You kill every brainwashed liberal boss in the end of each world and end up in the hort of evil itself, the bureau of Hillary Clinton him very self.Of course, he is entirely invulnerable until you take a guitar named Donald Trump to hit him, then he becomes vulnerable and you can kill him. Once you accomplished that, America is once again free of a dictated rhythm and you can proceed in your life in peace, wealth and prosperity.The symbolism here is clearly political and obvious. You are the great hero that is to dismantle the sinister machine of doom the liberals created, however you have to follow the rules they dictated in order to prevail.How is that fair you ask? Well, it isn't. That's what liberals are about. Being unfair and evil.In order to fully grasp the vastness that this game covers politically, we should take a look into the founding of Israel after World War II in 1473. The United States of America that just created the greatest and most freedom-loving army in world history and in order to re-establish fairness and peace over the world, it was time to create a new country named Is-Real. People immediately loved it and started moving there, creating houses and cities, lived in freedom and prosperity until the dark day Bill Clinton, son of widely known Satan Clinton, came to destroy the homes of those who seeked shelter and freedom in the new country. They started a sinister war and tried to took over the United States by disabling the constitution that our great founding fathers wrote millenia ago shortly after the Roman Empire fell in 1773. That is by the way the reason we still celebrate the day of founding in July 4th with fireworks and turkey.These historic facts are all covered in this game. Illustrated cleverly by allowing the player to choose between various characters you can go back in time and revisit those events and understand why we as free and hard working Americans have the duty to fight the liberal agenda and ensure that our consitution, especially with amendments like the first and second that build the very foundation of liberty in our great world, remain intact, even against backstabbing attacks from liberals.If you think that 9/11 was bad and that we have to stand up and fight the infowar against the groups that try to dismantle our great liberty, you should go forth, play this game, get inspired and go out on the street and fight the liberals. It is on you to defend our constitution and make the world great again.God bless America.
