Early Access Review
								This is one of those games that has a very clear understanding of what makes it special and commits to it hard. As a result, the game is an absolute joy to play and once you get the hang of it, you feel like a beast. Using your own songs seems to work really well (I've only tried three songs so far, but they all were great). The default music is thankfully really enjoyable, with the shopkeepers sort of "singing" the tunes when you're near. While the game is in early access, it feels pretty complete to me at this point, though I should point out that I only played it for about 2 hours and got as far the 5ish level, what I'm trying to say is, if you buy it now, you won't get a bug filled mess with no content. The game is great, and I expect more great things from devs in future.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have a soft spot for a well executed genre mashup, and Crypt of the NecroDancer hits the bullseye of that sweet spot. It's a smart, slick roguelike where a run takes little more than 10 minutes to play, but is engaging from the start. The inclusion of a rhythm-action mechanic, where you're rewarded for moving on the beat of the music is both novel and fun. It adds a sense of urgency (and sometimes panic), while also opening up a risk/reward mechanic of when it's smart to *not* move, lose your multiplier, but gain a tactical advantage in your approach to a given enemy. The enemy and powerup design is varied and interesting, allowing each run to play out very differently. There's  a very strong feeling of ongoing progressive mastery that happens, as you figure out the right way to defeat new monster types and the best way to utilize the items you pick up. Of particular note is that you can brush the dust off your old DDR dance pad, and use that to play the game. Any game that allows you use old ludicrous peripherals scores bonus points in my book. Now, who wants to play a couple of rounds of Streetfighter with a Dreamcast fishing rod controller? FIGHT!Note - while it's still notionally in Early Access at the time that this review is written, it very much feels like a finished game with free content coming down the pike.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												This game is so very awesome. Words can't even describe the amount of happiness this little title has given me. I think what I love the most is you can play this game one handed as you sit back and relax in your comfy reclining chair. It's definitely a challenging title, but not in a way that makes you think the game is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but rather usually a death is the result of a screw up from you, the player. It makes you question your own stupidity or lack of attention that sets you in a rage against yourself, rather than against the game.The music is perfect. Zone 2 is my least favorite of the bunch, but there's so many classic tracks during the gameplay - Tracks like King Conga and 3-2 or even 4-3 are just utter perfection. Danny B deserves more acclaim from this work than he's already received. A rhythm game needs good catchy music, and Necrodancer has that in spades.The daily challenges offer a chance to separate the good players from the players like me. It's a nice touch, offering every player the game challenge, so you and some friends can compete against each other. There's a nice variety of items and shrines you can use to build your necrodancer with. A rougelike with a twist! I wouldn't recommend this game if you're deaf... or blind. I mean, that should be a given. But if you have one good hand and you like bouncing to the beat of some catchy music, you should purchase this title. And then buy yourself a t-shirt and continue gushing about your praise over this game to your girlfriend unitl she asks you to leave her alone. I mean, that's what I did. It worked out for me.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												TL;DR: This game is good if you like games that are both challenging and fun. It also has good music.I will start out by saying that this game is one of my favorites. It is very fun, if you can handle the challenge.It's a quite odd game, if you think about it. A rhythm based roguelike? You probably haven't played anything like it.As I have said a few times already, it is very challenging. The game will likely smash you into a pulp a few times until you learn how to beat the enemies. Which, shouldn't actually take long, as they all have patterns that you can memorize, as well as animations that will give you a heads up when they are about to attack.Though, if you are still struggling, they have a special room where they will show you... Well, more like force you to learn, how to beat some of the tougher enemies.It also has tons of different items, randomly generated levels, (Or you can put in a seed, if you prefer.) and many different characters, each with different mechanics, so you will probably never get bored."So, you said that it's a rhythm based roguelike. Is the music any good?" You bet. It is really good.The default music is composed by Danny Baranowsky, who has made music for several other great games, including the Binding of Isaac, and Super Meat Boy, but there are also several remixes/remasters made by other artists, or if you really want, you can use any music you want!It is also VERY compatible with dance pads. XDIt also has a story, which is mainly told through cutscenes, which are few and far apart, but they do tell a pretty interesting story.So, overall, I definitely recommend this game. It is awesome, and very fun. It is a must have for your gaming arsenal.100/10

												WOW. This game is a lot more difficult than I expected. Watching videos and things, it seems like it would be simple once you memorize all the attack patterns and things, but with so many enemies doing different things all at once, it's so easy to make a mistake. The great thing about this game is that you totally get each success and failure. As in when you clear a room without taking damage you're like "yeah, totally nailed it", but when you walk right into enemies you immediately know what you did wrong, and the game never feels unfair for it. Also IT'S A RHYTHM BASED ROUGELIKE HOLY CRAP WHY DON'T YOU OWN THIS YET?!?!?!?!

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												With a lack of rhythm games in general, Crypt of the NecroDancer (or CotN) delivers with Grand Results. The controls only use the Arrow Keys, but it uses this limitation to its advanatge since some item can only be activated via 2 button press and forces you to not mess up, or it i'll cost you a heart or 2. Yes, it IS a simple rouge-like, but the game requires you to plan ahead, know the patterns of enemies, know what items do what, Etc. There are upgrades to the game, but it still requries the skill you had without said upgrade. the Co-Op mode feels weird with player 2 using WASD, but It still manages to work. The Game also offers different characters with differnet play styles, an online leaderboard via Daily Challenge, and Mod Support (lets hope we dont have to pay for these any time soon) The game gets VERY challenging after world 3, granted there are only 4 Worlds, and after beating the random boss at the end, you get a little cut-scene talking about the story of the game. Overall, this game can be enjoyed by most, if not all fans of Rouge-likes and Rhythm games, I give Crypt of the Necrodancer:9.8/10BUY IT, AND ENJOY IT (the 0.2 that isnt included is just some personal issuses)

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												Awesome soundtrack, challenging levels, great design, no bugs so far. Roguelike game which has an added gameplay element attached to it: you have to move, attack and destroy with the rythm of the music. And not only that, every foe you may encounter, every trap, every dungeon level has its own rythm as well. The learning process is fairly simple: trial and error, till you get to know how to act to counter that rythm. It's so much fun, and challenges the player in a way many would enjoy, that you could even compare to Dark Souls. The feeling of accomplishment when you finish a level, is indescribable. 100% recomend it, and at this price (currently on sale at less than 4€) you don't have to think twice.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
 Crypt of the NecroDancer Oh boy where do I begin?The gameplay is so Unique and Intelligent which is why it's one of my favorite games on Steam! EVER!It's a Rouge-like game that combines Rhythm and Dungeon Crawling, 2 completely different genres! And it works perfectly! How crazy is that!?You play with the rhythm and make a move at every beat, whether it's walking, attacking, using items, mining (technically it's shoveling 'cause you use a shovel but there is a pickaxe), etc.As easy as this may sound, it is a really and I mean a   really   difficult game, every enemy feels unique because they all have a unique pattern to memorize, and the only way to beat it is to learn them and be able to predict when they move and where.Still not convincied it's hard? Well try playing as one of the harder character such as  Aria , ON A DANCEPAD (this is an official thing by the way, check their site for details)The graphics are really neat too! It's really captures the "I'm underground" feeling really well, the sprites are so full of life, er well, they're kind of dead but they're still full of life, there are also Steam Workshop mods out there to change the sprites and sound effects to everything.The music, oh God, Is it beautiful? Yes. Is it addicting? Yes. Is Freddie Merchantry the best thing ever? Absolutly. I can't get enough of the soundtrack, ESPECIALLY Freddie Merchantary's voice, but if you want to, you can change the music to whatever you have on your computer, but then you won't hear the game's awesome soundtrack or Freddie Merchantary's voice, so are you sure you want to do that? Also the voice acting is top tier just wanna point that out, Fantastic work.Now if you look at the price tag and thought this was expensive well think again, because this game is going to stick with you for a long time, I usually move on from one game to another, but this is one of those games where I can't let go of because of how amazing it is.I don't hear much people talk about this but there is a level editor if that's your thing, I'm not particularly good at making levels but I sure as heck can try.In short, It's basically one of the most unique games I've played, sure you can say you played some unique games but I never saw anything quite like this, and while writing this review I couldn't really fully express how I feel about this game, it's so good that if it were a food, it's my favorite food that I can't get enough of. My brain created tactics automatically and is one of the only games where I get 100% focused on, despite playing for (as of this review) 30 hours I can still screw up really badly. I'm currently having difficultly playing as  Aria  in Zone 3, and I love it.I have high respect to everyone who worked on this game, it's a huge inspiration to game developers, musicians, and heck even the fans like myself, because I consider Crypt of the NecroDancer as one of the most innovative games of this generation and I'm sure many others do, so a big thank you to everyone who was involved with the creation of this game.Also I just wanna point out that this game was inspired from another Rouge-like game called Spelunky, which is also another game that I love. I think I'm gonna buy a Dancepad just for this game

content:

Early Access Review
								This is one of those games that has a very clear understanding of what makes it special and commits to it hard. As a result, the game is an absolute joy to play and once you get the hang of it, you feel like a beast. Using your own songs seems to work really well (I've only tried three songs so far, but they all were great). The default music is thankfully really enjoyable, with the shopkeepers sort of "singing" the tunes when you're near. While the game is in early access, it feels pretty complete to me at this point, though I should point out that I only played it for about 2 hours and got as far the 5ish level, what I'm trying to say is, if you buy it now, you won't get a bug filled mess with no content. The game is great, and I expect more great things from devs in future.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												TL;DR: This game is good if you like games that are both challenging and fun. It also has good music.I will start out by saying that this game is one of my favorites. It is very fun, if you can handle the challenge.It's a quite odd game, if you think about it. A rhythm based roguelike? You probably haven't played anything like it.As I have said a few times already, it is very challenging. The game will likely smash you into a pulp a few times until you learn how to beat the enemies. Which, shouldn't actually take long, as they all have patterns that you can memorize, as well as animations that will give you a heads up when they are about to attack.Though, if you are still struggling, they have a special room where they will show you... Well, more like force you to learn, how to beat some of the tougher enemies.It also has tons of different items, randomly generated levels, (Or you can put in a seed, if you prefer.) and many different characters, each with different mechanics, so you will probably never get bored."So, you said that it's a rhythm based roguelike. Is the music any good?" You bet. It is really good.The default music is composed by Danny Baranowsky, who has made music for several other great games, including the Binding of Isaac, and Super Meat Boy, but there are also several remixes/remasters made by other artists, or if you really want, you can use any music you want!It is also VERY compatible with dance pads. XDIt also has a story, which is mainly told through cutscenes, which are few and far apart, but they do tell a pretty interesting story.So, overall, I definitely recommend this game. It is awesome, and very fun. It is a must have for your gaming arsenal.100/10

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Crypt of the Necrodancer is a special mixture of the rogue light genre and the rhythm game genre. It forces you to fight your enemies to the beat, making the player resort to their rhythmic intelligence and their reflexes. Without a quick mind and sharp instincts, you'll die. A lot. Most of the deaths are the player's fault. Whether it was being surrounded by enemies, or forgetting an enemy's pattern.To quote Cadence from the game."Every enemy has a predictable pattern. Learn that and you won't suffer as much as a scratch."This game relies on skill, as you can take any amount of luck in your procedurally generated dungeon and win with enough skill. You learn from your deaths, failures, and misplays. I retrieved my heart from the Necrodancer. Can you?

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Very enjoyable, and also at later stages very difficult. It is what it looks like: a rhythm-based almost-roguelike game - an unusual combination of genres which works surprisingly well. The game does not have a vast number of areas, but the  levels are procedurally generated so it is not too predictable and the challenge is great enough that the game will not be over too fast. There are also various unlockable characters with different playstyles and varying levels of difficulty, which helps to extend the life of the game. The soundtrack is good, which is crucial for this type of game, although it is occasionally difficult to pick out the beat which the game expects you to move to. The only major complaint I would have is the aforementioned limited level variety which does become frustrating when replaying the same sorts of levels over and over with any one of the several ludicrously difficult-to-play characters in the game. Overall, however, the game is still well worth buying if fast-paced 2D games hold any appeal for you at all.

Posted: April 7, 2016
												Crypt is a game I admittedly bought pretty much exclusively for Danny B's soundtrack. The music in this game is fantastic. So much so that I bought the game for PS4 as well. But the gameplay is extremely difficult. It's randomly generated, but extremely based on enemy patterns. There's very little room for error, and each run can end in the blink of an eye. It's a game I really want to get better at, if only because it's so unique. If you put a bit of practice into learning each of the enemy's patterns, it is incredibly rewarding to beat each floor, especially for the first time. It's certainly not a game for everyone, but it's a game that you will enjoy if you spend a bit of time learning how to play it. And even if you suck, you can still enjoy Danny B's beautiful soundtrack.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								A harmonious fusion of what should be a pair of the most dissonant genres imaginable. It's a strong roguelike with the spine of a rhythm game, and it pulls it off spectacularly. It is a testament to the game's strengths that it's even a blast while playing as the bard, a character that completely ignores the rhythm component of the game.The rhythm component is much stronger than simply moving to the beat, as the various enemy tells end up with you effectively creating dances around them. And of course, the soundtrack is nothing short of fantastic.The fact that this game is still in early access is extremely exciting, as in it's current state, it's already a beautiful mashup. I can't wait to see what the full release holds.

												Party Hard to Die Hard! Death has some wicked beats!This game is by far the single most frustatingly addicting game I have found and played with great gusto. I the one thing that keeps me coming back to this abusive realtionship with the game is its sick beat. I love how it requires you to do such things as dance and determine rhythm and even though I was in band and marching band much of my life it showed me how good my internal rhythm is. Its god aweful. This game is wonderful and unique and I am glad I made the choice to finally buy this game. Now with that said the game is hard but, that is the fun. The further you get the more excited you become and your progress means something for once. So instead of playing the respawn game at the start of you where ever you died you have to continue from the begining and earn your way back. For some one who wants great music and a fun little rouge-like RPG styled game this is a great choice and honestly well worth it. Planning on buying the soundtrack when I have the cash.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Ahh, Necrodancer, a wonderful mix of fun and utter frustration!This game has one hell of an interesting concept - Roguelikes are a ton of fun, if a little frustrating, and rhythm games which I love playing overall because the selection of music is great. This one has 3 artists, all of which are great, and flow with the story and game perfectly.The selection and designs of the characters are also incredible, you got Cadence, who's the good ol' main character, Melody, who is a ton of fun to wreck with her Golden Lute, Aria who is essentially the Lost and ♥♥♥♥in' frustrating, and many more characters. (My favourite is Dove because she's ♥♥♥♥ING ADORABLE). While these characters are great, I'd love to see remixes for each character rather than just Melody and Aria, that'd make it much more fun to do other characters.The gameplay is also great, where each movement and action you make must be to the beat of the music and the enemy designs are great too, as they all have patterns to the beat. This is even more fun as you can put your own songs in, and most of the time the music and beats sync perfectly!This really is a great game, and the world needs more games like these :D

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												I purchased this game when it was initially in Early Access and actually only played half an hour or so of the game during that phase. The lack of play time wasn't due to it being glitchy or anything, rather I had a few other games on my plate and didn't think there was much depth to Crypt of the NecroDancer. Yeah, the rhythm-based movement was cool, but what else was there?TIME SKIP. The game leaves early access and I suddenly decide that it's worth picking up and playing for a bit after getting a little burned out on The Witcher 3. Returning to it, I hadn't recognized how much depth there truly is in Crypt of the NecroDancer. You have to really plan each of your runs carefully: are you going to try to collect as many diamonds as possible? Are you trying to get to the exit as quickly as you can? It reminded me so much of how my girlfriend and I played through Rogue Legacy, where we had to determine if we intended on collecting as much gold as possible or if we should try to get to the boss rooms as quickly as possible.No doubt the games soundtrack is really catchy and fun to listen to as well, as it should be. What I appreciate is that you're not really hindered significantly if you fail to keep in time with the music, outside of losing a coin multiplier.I can't recommend Crypt of the NecroDancer enough. I have only a few hours logged in currently, partially due to the fact that the game is perfect for just picking up and playing for a few minutes at a time.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												CAUTION: This game is extremely addictive.This is a rogue-like RPG that merges all of your actions, such as moving and combat, with staying in tempo to whatever song is playing, as well as letting you permanently purchase upgrades and item spawns in a hub area for each randomly generated dungeon venture.  Each zone has a few areas which end with a boss fight, and you are able to return to completed zones to grind for gold and diamonds (diamonds are used to purchase upgrades at the hub while gold is used at shops within the dungeons to buy gear, spells, and health).I really like that you can start with a different character who changes the gameplay from rhythm to turn-based so that you can learn the mechanics of the game before adding in the need to stay with the beat.  The ability to use custom songs is an awesome touch, adding even more so to the already excellent replay value.9.75/10

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Best thing I ever spent money on. The replayability is awesome, the beats are sick, the execution is logical. It doesn't cheat you like some rogue-like games do, this is pretty much about how well you control yourself and your mind.The idea itself is golden. I've been a fan of games that incorporate and link as much as possible the soundtrack to the gameplay, like Beat Hazard and o2Jam, but a roguelike music-based game? Well I'd be damned if I didn't pay and play this with my own blood, sweat and tears.The soundtrack is extremely addicting, making you subconsciously hum them while doing other unrelated things like your laundry and taking the bus to work. Add that to the wicked idea that your every decision is based on the song and its beat, this makes for a very challenging feat indeed.The only problem I can see is that the mobs are generally hard to get by. It gets really hard at later stages, when hordes of monsters just swarm with you with many different movement patterns. If you can memorize patterns well, then this will be a piece of cake.Overall, 9.5/10. Highly recommended for sick tunes and sexy shopkeeper.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												There have been many music-based games in recent years. I remember buying Audiosurf in 2008 and thought that it was so unique getting a game that plays on highway-like track according to the song you play. Many rhythm-based games have been distributed over the years and Crypt of the Necrodancer is one of them. This game is different because it looks like it is set in a randomly generated dungeon with a roguelike character strictly moving to the beat of the music.You start the game as Cadence, a female character you control to collect gear, coins, and spells while a variety of monsters try to stop you. It has a very steep learning curve and it takes a while to get used to moving correctly to the beat despite the fact that the monsters have very predictable moves as they try to reach and attack you. If you move to the beat correctly, you will build up a coin multiplier while the maze turns into a disco like settings since it looks like a brightened dance floor. If you miss a beat, the coin multiplier will be lost and you will have to build it back up again. Each zone is divided into a few levels and the final level will be a boss level. Defeat the boss at the end of the zone and you will unlock a new character. There are many characters to unlock and each has such different moves that if feels like you have to unlearn the moves you used with the previous character. There is a character named Eli who can drop an infinite number of bombs and kick them to defeat nearby enemies. This means that you will have to get accustomed to the different attacks that Eli features that Cadence does not feature. Cadence moves to the beat and kills with conventional weapons like swords and whips. Another character, Bard, doesn’t have to move according to the beat whereas another character like Dove cannot kill enemies, but can exit the levels without facing mini-bosses.Besides the diverse characters in terms of number and abilities, the levels include a challenge in which you can rescue NPCs trapped in a cage that require exploration to find the proper key to liberate them. These NPCs will then become available in the lobby so that they can sell gear, spells, and other goodies that will be useful in each zone and its associated levels.The number of diverse characters, the complexity of the movements can provide plenty of replay value. Also, you can play your own mp3s to see how challenging each level in a zone can be. When playing a song from the game’s soundtrack, it is funny to see the shopkeeper sing along to the music. The music that comes with the game is varied and entertaining. The game includes daily challenges and workshop mods to add up to infinite replay value.I think Crypt of the Necrodancer is a game that was well thought out by the developers, combining coolness, diversity, and difficulty. I think people can enjoy the challenges and the diversity of the characters and dungeons/mazes that this game offers. It is unique to combine the traditional roguelike characteristics of the game with rhythm. Just be prepared to put a lot of practice into the game that requires fast thinking since one mistake can easily force you to start over. Beating a level will always feel very rewarding due to the need for precise hand-eye coordination.My Score: 8/10

Early Access Review
								This game is a real joy to play, largely owing to the awesome soundtrack. It was written by the same guy who did the music for Super Meat Boy and Binding of Isaac. He has the best style, it's like Techno Nintendo Metal from the future. Don't let the whole 'rogue-like' thing scare you, this game is lots of fun and when you die it just feels like 'meh'. Worth playing for the sheer uniqueness of it imo. I even convinced my non-gamer roommate to play co-op with me today.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												You *need* this game. Seriously.EDITNow that the final release is out I'm updating my review. Crypt of the Necrodancer is one of those games you really just have to play to understand the hype, and yes this is one of those rare cases where the hype is 100% justified. The game just hits every note perfectly (haha). The gameplay is increadible. Even though the look is familiar, the mechanics are like nothing else out there (which is quite a feat in todays gaming age) but still seems to satisfy on some primal level. It's kind of like speed chess if it were fun. Each enemy moves in a unique pattern and each item effects the behavor of your character. Every move could either result in success or death, but you only have a split second to decide what to do. It really puts you on the edge of your seat especially when playing "all zones" mode. Then there's the music. It's amazing. In fact it's so amazing I bought the soundtrack version and uploaded the songs to listen to on my iPod. Of course thats the kind of music we've all come to expect from Danny Baranowsky of Binding of Isaac fame. The great thing about the music is that it makes you dance. Not in the game, but in real life. I can't play this game without dancing around with a big grin on my face like a complete idiot. My fiance thinks its hilarious, whom by the way, can't stand video games yet still found this game to be entertaining. On top of all that the execution is really what brings it all together. The way the shopkeeper sings to the music, how the music in the fire/ice stage transitions from metal to classical music seamlessly, the quirky sprite animations, and the light up disco tiles, it really brings a smile to your face. Its games like these that remind me why I game in the first place. I'm really quite pleased that amidst all the Call of Duty garbage you can still find little gems like this one.I really can't recomend this game enough! :DCan't stop dancing/10

												DO NOT BUY IT WITHOUT GETTING THE COLLECTORS EDITION. The music is too good.Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game where you move to the changing beat of songs in the game while having to think fast and on your feet. It is very difficult and each zone takes a while to complete and longer to master. Plus it is very mod friendly and you can use your own music. It's a very fun roguelite game where you unlock more items and permenant upgrades as you go and definately pick it up during a steam sale if your wallet is a little tight.

Early Access Review
								I haven't put a lot of hours into this game yet, but it's probably one of the best games I've played in a long time.I generally like most rhythm games, but to have one that incorporates an adventuring game within it, and doing so VERY successfully, is rare to find.  This game doesn't require much time to play through a single round of it, but you can easily lose a lot of time in the game.It's certainly a title to pick up if you enjoy well composed original music set to a rhythm style play that doesn't require "twitch-skills" and also want to adventure through a few dungeons and killing a few baddies along the way.

content:
Posted: February 15
												Im in love with this game; I can't get enough. The gameplay is fun and wondering how your next run is going to go is always exciting. (like a lot of dungeon crawlers) What NecroDancer does differently than other dungeon crawler games is there isnt any real artifical difficulty. Everything is choreographed (except those darn bats) and it never feels like you were cheated out of run; you lost because -you- messed up. (or your hand cramped trying to do Bolt Death Metal)I can't forget of all things the music. With a great composer such a Danny Baranowsky and currently five other styles by other artists, you can guarentee at least seven or eight songs getting stuck in your head.All in all, this game has been a great experience and I look forward to see what else is in store for this masterpiece.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												NecroDancer takes a young woman through randomly generated dungeons...  Dungeons in which she must move in time with the music to stay alive.  In her travels, she occasionally comes across people in cages, whom she attempts to free where possible.  In return, they graciously supply her with items such as armor, weapons, rings, recovery items, and more, which she will need if she ever wishes to see her father again.As I've said above, this game is dungeon crawler with a twist: moving in time with the music.  The enemies, which are diverse and build upon each other, are also restricted to this rule.  If you miss a beat, you'll likely lose a chance at making a move that would put you in a more favorable position.  In addition, if the song ends before you reach the stairs, the game drops you to the next stage immediately.I've only played the game on keyboard and the controls are simple enough.  Something to note is that there are many usable items in NecroDancer, which require you to press two keys at once to use them, which can be frustrating if you mess up.  It might be easier with an 8-way d-pad on a controller.  There's quite a few different unlockable characters you can play as, including the bard, who can move whenever he wants with no regard to the music.  There's also a co-op mode that I haven't experienced.Where this game really shines is that you can painlessly add your own music to play alongside.  You can do this by picking the specific level you want to add a song to, choosing an mp3 file from the window that comes up, and the game will pick the pace of movement for you.  I've had fun with songs with a consistent beat so far, and I'm looking forward to experimenting with adding different genres in the future.NecroDancer looks great, with its 16-bit art style.  The way enemies move in time with the music is fun, because literally all of them can't help but dance!  There's an option that's on by default that makes the dungeons look like a dance floor by alternating the colors of the floor tiles.Pros:*Endless replayability, with randomly generated levels and the ability to add songs*A co-op mode*A great soundtrack*Challenging movement that makes you feel good when you get it downCons:*It's difficult to use items when playing on keyboard*The odd movement can take some getting used to9/10

content:
Posted: February 12
												The game's only failing is that the fun falls apart if you don't play to the beat. The punishment for breaking the beat on most modes is you lose your coin multiplier. This doesn't serve as a direct in the moment penalty, but as a penalty for down the line when you don't have enough money to buy the cool things.It has a great variety of playable characters which change up the challenge. I favored the easier ones over the intense deep end of the difficutly pool.I highly recommend it, especially if you love music games. A challenging and engaging roguelike.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
I. Love. This. Game!(Even though I suck at it.)When I started playing this game, and I couldn't beat the first stage, I wasn't really good at catching rhythm in songs. But now, it's a piece of cake! You can really learn from this game. Anyone who is making music should try it out, to test their rhythm skills, and maybe learn how to play rogue-like dungeon games :PIt has a total of 10 different characters (and another one in the DLC), each having different playstyles than the others.The soundtrack is amazing! It's made by Danny Baranowsky. It features 24 tracks in the base, and 5 extra in the DLC! (on 4th of February 2017, I don't know if Dan will make more soundtrack (which I would really like, it's amazing))Not to mention, there are a couple remixes in the game too!-an EDM remix by A_Rival;-a metal remix by FamilyJules7x;-a freestyle retro remix by Jake 'Virt' Kaufman;-a synthwave remix by Girlfriend Records;-a (i don't know what music type it is) remix by OverClocked;-and a chiptune remix by Chipzel, featured in the Xbox One version!You can also upload your own tracks, and this game will even find the rhythm!The only problem I have with this game, it's really hard. You have to stay concentrated, feel the rhythm, know the patterns and think fast - I often find myself dying from little mistakes, but that's the process of learning, right?I recommend it for everyone. It's worth it, and I love it. You might rage a bit, miss a couple beats and die, but don't all games do that? If you like challenges, this game is for you! But I don't get it, why people say it's not a game for casual players. Who really cares? It's an amazing game! I found myself enjoying it all the time. GET IT!Have fun, and don't forget you have a shovel :necroshovel:

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												To me this game felt like The Binding of Isaac but to a rhythm. Much like that game this is immensely popular but I don’t like it. The game is deliberately very hard, you are supposed to die repeatedly and each time scrape together enough diamonds to get upgrades to allow you to progress a little further. Despite the procedurally generated levels it grows repetitive and annoying very quickly. Given that this is a music based game, the soundtrack is disappointing. Some of the tracks are great but most of them are forgettable.  The music based combat is novel and the enemies are reasonably varied but not enough to redeem the game for me.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Crypt of the NecroDancer is a game unlike any other. It is unique and really fun to play. In my experience with the game I haven't found anything I don't like, you move around a dungeon and kill monsters based on the beat of your heart.The heart beat also adds something new to these sorts of games. Turn based movement has been seen and used before but making it part of the story line and being able to change the rate at which the 'turns' pass is something really special.Pro's:- It is very fun to play and offers a lot of different things to experience.- It is unique and differs a lot from games that you find similar to this one.- The way you progress and unlock new items is really thought out and well designed so that you can really enjoy it fully.Con's:- Honestly, for me their are no con's to this game. It is fun, simple and a good use of your gaming time.I hope everyone else enjoys the game now and in the futer.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Rhythm games and roguelike games are both fairly small niches, and you wouldn't think they would go together well. But apparently they do!They go together as well as chocolate and peanut butter. Butter crackers and salmon spread. Uncooked fish and soy sauce. This is a fantastically fun game. It is rather brutally difficult (just like roguelikes), and the music is head-noddingly addictive (just like rhythm games). It is a beautifully weird marriage made in a version of heaven I had never even imagined. It's early access, so it's too early for a full review, but I love every minute I spend playing this. The only mild flaw I could ever say is that the music gets a little repetitive, as it's a roguelike, so you will be playing levels over and over and over (you can use your own music though).If you have anything better than a hatred of roguelikes and rhythm games, you owe it to yourself to check this out. This game is a perfect example of why indie games are, in a small way, the saviors of the gaming industry. This game is weird, bizarre, unbelievably fun, and a game a AAA studio wouldn't even listen to the first sentence of the pitch for.Also, that trader has some seriously operatic pipes!

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												Finally a game where I can play with just one hand! 8.5/10.Over all Crypt of th NecroDancer embarks into a old school retro dungeon adventure that has you playing to the rythme of the music while ingaging monsters, avoiding traps and completing puzzles. Every map feels different from one another which makes the dungeon experience that much more enjoyable.You earn gold to buy armor, weapons, magic, food ext... While collecting diamonds to purchase upgrades for your hero at the main menu. You can also unlock different modes and characters to further your dungeon experience.I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys rythme games, dungeon games or just a quick game that doesn't require you to sit down for over an hour long to complete a map.This game needs mounts added... I want a Chupacabra mount!I wonder what kind of things I can do with my other hand while playing this game...

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Crypt of the NecroDancer is a rhytm based dungeon crawler with some roguelike elements and great tunes. CotN is a turn based game where every beat serves as a turn. This means that if you miss a beat you miss a turn. You basically need just 4 buttons to play the game: left, right, up and down. These are used also in combination to use items and spells by pressing up+left to eat an apple i.e. though you can assign a single button for these functions also. You find consumables from the levels to heal yourself, spells like fireball or freeze and different weapons and armors. There are also diamonds that serves as a currency in the games hub where you can purchase persistent additions to your adventuring. Besides additional health the rest of the upgrades are added to the map generation for you to find. Enemies are varied as in how often they move (in beats) and in which patterns (up and down, following you etc.) and bosses are tougher and more damage dealing creatures of course. What makes CotN different is the rhytm-system. Roguelike-type-of-games are usually hard already but NecroDancer makes you do important decisions on the fly and likes to punish the player for hesitating. If you thought Spelunky was hard you've seen nothing (this is a warning). You have to study the movements patterns of the enemies and find the right timing and way to deal with each enemy. This changes with your gear since some weapons allow you to attack diagonally and you have to consider the right timing to launch that spell you've been saving. Pros:-Music, music, MUSIC.-Fast paced, quick runs-Graphics are lovely-Challenging -Different game modes and co-opCons: -I didn't like the color effect that you get when coin multiplier gets higher, makes the game look messy particularly in the second zone. -Not sure if the music/movement calibration is the most accurate possible solution-If the beat calibration is of it's pretty much impossible to play the hardcore mode-Could have more items that alter the gameplay Very good distraction for coffee break gaming and for the laughs with friends. I felt that the price was a bit high for the game but not for the soundtrack - and this doesn't mean that the game is bad - just that Danny B makes some badass tunes.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Crypt of the NecroDancer is easily the most addictive game I’ve played in quite some time. It compels you to want to play more, and more, and more!Part of this is the fantastic soundtrack that blends so seamlessly with the rhythm based rogue like.


YouTube™ Video: Crypt of the NecroDancer - Rhythm God - Mac Gameplay 2160p 

			Views: 494		

			NEW Crypt of the NecroDancer, a stylish and engaging rhythm roguelike with an amazing soundtrack. I freaking love this game!		

The story is rather cliche, you’re name is Cadence and you’ve gone to look for a family member. Only to get yourself killed, and then resurrected by the NecroDancer. Now you must move to the beat and fight your way deeper into the darkness.The game is difficult, but don’t let that dissuade you, it’s amazingly good. One of the few early access games that feels more like a completed product that some thrown together tech demo.What’s not to love about it?The 16-bit graphics and art style are beautiful and charming, and animations very well executed and the beat. That cursed beat that compels you to try again, and again.In all the hours that I’ve played I’ve only made it to Zone 3, and here there is a mix of techno and metal. Ice and fire, the dungeon is separated by these two elements. With creatures embodying either of the elements, and music shifting and changing as you move from the blue to red squares.Timing and rhythm is truly everything for the NecroDancer. All creatures in his dungeon must obey the beat, each bouncing and writhing in their own unique and horrific dance. Your yourself must do the same, although your consciousness allows you to move more freely.The simplest way to describe the combat and various weapons is Chess. Each creature, and each weapon, works in a similar way to chess. Do you attack diagonally, or straight forward only. Do you hit ahead of you, or to the side.You must learn each item’s use, and abilities, while doing the same for the enemies that stalk you so. Not surprising that one of the first bosses you encounter is actually an animated chess board. With the King at the far back playing his dark melody to move and order his minions and queen. The pawns are rather useless, but ignoring them spells doom, for they quickly turn into powerful Queens once they reach your walls.Don’t fret though, as you can also empower yourself with magical weapons, items, spells and even more life. Dotted throughout the zones are diamonds. That precious stone is used to upgrade your character and unlock more items, and spells.Along with gems, are towns people, free them as you find them with golden keys and they will join you in the game lobby. Offering you these upgrades, and even to train you against monsters, and even bosses. For a fee of course; more diamonds.If you can’t get enough punishment in the normal play style, there’s hardcore mode. None of your upgrades work, and you have to attempt to clear the entire game with a single run. Die, and you start again. The pinnacle of the masochist gamer.The game is fun, more than fun. It’s a masterpiece of Indie gaming, roguelikes and rhythm games. Hell, you can even play it with dance pad. You can even import your own MP3 collection if you want. Enjoy a fantastic game, and dance!Crypt of the NecroDancer is a must buy!

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								For being creative in the Roguelike genre by adding Rhythm game elements (Dancepad-style controls and gameplay), it's awesome that this game did something out of the ordinary and did it WELL.New to the game? Don't worry, there's a lot of stuff in the game for beginners, from tutorials to training rooms, to get to up to par with the better players. Wanna challenge yourself? Go right ahead! There's daily challenges, seeded runs, speedrunning, and you can remove items you've unlocked from the dungeon. Like modding games? It's got that too. Just throw some pixel art together and make yourself a new character or two, make a dungeon with the level editor, or edit some of the game's XML data for lulz.If you've come for a fun time, the soundtrack, got a recommendation, or to introduce yourself to Roguelikes, you won't be disappointed. Just keep in mind, this game doesn't throw punches. The enemies are tough and there are a lot of them. They do however follow patterns, so try to learn them.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
 This review has been edited from negative to positive. I had initially given this game a negative review (that I've left completely unedited and can be found at the bottom of this review should you choose to read my first thoughts on the game). Thanks to the developers response, I've been able to see the game in a different light. As such, I'm completely revising my review. But if you don't feel like reading all I have to say, the short version of this review is as follows in a conveniently bulleted list: Amazing soundtracks; can choose to play along with the default music, techno remixed music or metal music Fast-paced gameplay that requires patience and quick strategy Controlled entirely with the four directional arrow keys (and enter key for the pause menu) Extreme but fair difficulty; master enemy patterns and you've mastered the game Play with mods from the Steam Workshop Lots of things to unlock Encouraging developer who provided helpful insight in the face of negativity (It means a lot to me) The current positive review Crypt of the Necrodancer is what it looks like; a rhythm-based dungeon crawler. You move to the beat of the music, and the controls are simply the 4 arrow keys; up, down, left, right. Combat is as simple as moving next to an enemy and attempting to move onto the square they occupy to damage the enemy. Sounds simple on paper, but each enemy has a pattern, and I know very well from experience now that if you just try to attack each enemy head-on, you will die many humiliating deaths. Learning how to traverse the map and defeat enemies without getting hit is key to survival, as health restoration items seldom appear.There are practice modes so you can master the enemy patterns, but practice against minibosses and boss fights are locked. However, there are detailed video guides as to how to defeat each boss (and enemy) should you be unable to collect the diamonds to unlock the practice mode(s). Regarding diamonds, one of the nicest features I've found in the game is that the game will warn you if you have diamonds left to spend on upgrades should you attempt to play again (as your diamond count is reset to 0 each attempt). This warning can be disabled, but because it's there, you can maximize on the rewards you've earned to get very much-needed upgrades. These upgrades include (but are not limited to) more base health and different items appearing in chests that would otherwise need to be bought from the shopkeeper mid-dungeon.In conclusion, this game is hard. There's no getting around that; statistically (as of writing this review), only 6.7% of players have completed the game under normal conditions. It may seem like it's impossibly hard (as I initially thought) at first, but this isn't the kind of game you can pick up and master in an instant. It's a game that requires time and practice to be good at. Just like anything in life. In that sense, it exits one's comfort zone of going into a game with skills learned from other games that can be applied. As such, this game is unique and brings something new to the table; a gameplay experience I can't get from playing other games. The old negative review Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fantastic game; the rhythm element is excellently implemented and functions perfectly for me. The music is great and catchy, and the game as a whole gives a new twist on roguelike dungeon crawlers. The steam workshop compatability gives endless possibilities as to gameplay creativity.However, I can't recommend this game because it's egregiously difficult to the point of becoming nearly unplayable. It took me almost my first hour of gameplay just to get past zone 1. As of writing this review, I can't get past zone 2-2 (if I can even make it that far), and after reading many other reviews, it doesn't seem like it will get much better. There are many games that are extremely difficult yet still enjoyable to play after losing; Crypt of the Necrodancer is not one of those games. Incessant game overs are disheartening to say the least, and rather than encourage me to try again, this game encourages me to play something else.

Once you got a hang for the music you then need to get a hang on the patterns enemies use, The best rhythm to stick with for certain weopons, etc. This make it into a whole new style, Where one miss can change EVERYTHING. AND I LOVE IT!

Early Access Review
								Got obliterated by a dragon, some goblins, a couple of horse-riding skeletons & a hellhound to the Benny Hill Theme.10/10In seriousness, for an early access title there's quite a bit of content, and the gameplay is very solid (haven't found a single bug/rough-around-the-edges aspect yet) and highly enjoyable - think Binding of Isaac meets Legend of Zelda meets Dance Dance Revolution. This is a unique little game that blends multiple genres together in a brilliant way, and you can even pick your own music (though the in-game tracks are pretty awesome anyway)! There's even a local co-op mode - I've yet to try this, but can't wait to give it a crack.Though the final quarter & ending of the game (and additional content etc) is yet to be added, I'm having a blast with the alpha and would highly recommend it!

												Definitely one of the few rogue-likes I can enjoy! Success is built much more on skill than item drop luck, like in other rogue-likes.Also you don't drop that deep when you die. The good thing is, that there is a way to deal with them all. There is no imbalanced uber enemy you cannot counter. You just have to be quick and stick to the beat ;-)Extremely recommended if you like rogue-likes, rythm games, pixel graphics and dungeoneering.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
 This review has been edited from negative to positive. I had initially given this game a negative review (that I've left completely unedited and can be found at the bottom of this review should you choose to read my first thoughts on the game). Thanks to the developers response, I've been able to see the game in a different light. As such, I'm completely revising my review. But if you don't feel like reading all I have to say, the short version of this review is as follows in a conveniently bulleted list: Amazing soundtracks; can choose to play along with the default music, techno remixed music or metal music Fast-paced gameplay that requires patience and quick strategy Controlled entirely with the four directional arrow keys (and enter key for the pause menu) Extreme but fair difficulty; master enemy patterns and you've mastered the game Play with mods from the Steam Workshop Lots of things to unlock Encouraging developer who provided helpful insight in the face of negativity (It means a lot to me) The current positive review Crypt of the Necrodancer is what it looks like; a rhythm-based dungeon crawler. You move to the beat of the music, and the controls are simply the 4 arrow keys; up, down, left, right. Combat is as simple as moving next to an enemy and attempting to move onto the square they occupy to damage the enemy. Sounds simple on paper, but each enemy has a pattern, and I know very well from experience now that if you just try to attack each enemy head-on, you will die many humiliating deaths. Learning how to traverse the map and defeat enemies without getting hit is key to survival, as health restoration items seldom appear.There are practice modes so you can master the enemy patterns, but practice against minibosses and boss fights are locked. However, there are detailed video guides as to how to defeat each boss (and enemy) should you be unable to collect the diamonds to unlock the practice mode(s). Regarding diamonds, one of the nicest features I've found in the game is that the game will warn you if you have diamonds left to spend on upgrades should you attempt to play again (as your diamond count is reset to 0 each attempt). This warning can be disabled, but because it's there, you can maximize on the rewards you've earned to get very much-needed upgrades. These upgrades include (but are not limited to) more base health and different items appearing in chests that would otherwise need to be bought from the shopkeeper mid-dungeon.In conclusion, this game is hard. There's no getting around that; statistically (as of writing this review), only 6.7% of players have completed the game under normal conditions. It may seem like it's impossibly hard (as I initially thought) at first, but this isn't the kind of game you can pick up and master in an instant. It's a game that requires time and practice to be good at. Just like anything in life. In that sense, it exits one's comfort zone of going into a game with skills learned from other games that can be applied. As such, this game is unique and brings something new to the table; a gameplay experience I can't get from playing other games. The old negative review Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fantastic game; the rhythm element is excellently implemented and functions perfectly for me. The music is great and catchy, and the game as a whole gives a new twist on roguelike dungeon crawlers. The steam workshop compatability gives endless possibilities as to gameplay creativity.However, I can't recommend this game because it's egregiously difficult to the point of becoming nearly unplayable. It took me almost my first hour of gameplay just to get past zone 1. As of writing this review, I can't get past zone 2-2 (if I can even make it that far), and after reading many other reviews, it doesn't seem like it will get much better. There are many games that are extremely difficult yet still enjoyable to play after losing; Crypt of the Necrodancer is not one of those games. Incessant game overs are disheartening to say the least, and rather than encourage me to try again, this game encourages me to play something else.

												This is right now one of my Favorite game that I have been playing only in 4 hours. But that will changes really soon. Crypt of the NecroDancer is as what I would say a rhythm dungeon explore game, where you try to get to the end of every floor until you find the Main boss and continue on the next zone. But it isn’t that easy. You can only move the character by listen to the beat in the music. If you miss a beat, you cannot move and will be defenseless to the monsters. You only have so many life and that’s your job to not lose. When you beat a monster, they drop gold. With the gold you can buy weapons or Items in the shop in every floor. You can also earn more money by going with the rhythm. But as you should now is, if you miss a beat in the song, you lose your chances to earn more money.There is also Diamonds that you can buy in the lobby to unlock more health, armor, weapons or Items that you can find in chests. There is many character to unlock and there is a 2 player mode. Also you can play this with a keyboard, controller or a USB dance pad!And last thing I know, there is workshop with this game, and you can changes the song in the game to something else with the MP3. Which is really nice!Otherwise the music that are in the game without MP3 is really great. 8/10 You should try this game now when It is on sale for 3,74€. But that’s just me.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												Definitely one of the best rhytm games I've ever played. It's an incredible mix of rhytm game, with a sick soundtrack and really solid beats(meaning you won't risk going off-beat because of irregular or vague tempo), and a roguelike that neither hols your hand nor throws you into battle without help: over the course of your journey to trace the titular NecroDancer, you'll find a rather vast array of helpful items that range from weapons, to armor, to magic spells and scrolls, and finally to helpful gadgets and accessories to further help you... But ultimately, it's up to you to put them to good use, for the dungeons are unforgiving, the monsters many, the spells limited, and your heart dancing to the tune of the master of the dungeon.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												Lol I just copypasted this review so I could lvl my steam prof, its a gud game tho. Unlike many games that carry the label, Crypt of the Necrodancer is a roguelike that is actually quite a bit like Rogue. You control a lone hero in a grid-based dungeon, pushing back the fog of war square by square as you explore each randomly-generated set of chambers. As you journey deeper you gather gear, spells and consumables to help you survive encounters with monsters who behave according to predictable routines. If you die, you start over from the beginning.In a traditional roguelike, your greatest asset is the time you're afforded to think, assess, plan. Crypt of the Necrodancer's defining flourish is that it reduces your thinking time to the space between two beats on the soundtrack. Move to the rhythm and you build up a multiplier, turning the ground into an illuminated dancefloor and boosting the gold you earn from every kill. In order to be able to afford the best gear, then, you should always be moving. Move thoughtlessly, however, and you'll die. The result is a game where you are always taking action but only sporadically acting well. What was once a meditative, considered experience becomes a rush of on-the-fly strategy and occasional finesse—becomes, in short, a dance.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Crypt of the NecroDancer. So what is it? It is a dungeon crawler where turns are taking place in a certain (dictated by song) rhytm. Basically you go on andventure of 4 zones, each having 4 levels. Design of each zone is unique and entertaining, each with different enemies traps and hazards. At end of each level you will meet a Miniboss (7 different types, which most have upraged version of itself), and at the end of each level you will meet a boss (4 types). When you finish a "run" (beat 4 zones in a row) you will meet final boss. But if you are able to defeat him it's not over. After it you will have 2 more characters that push story to play with. "What story?" Every time you beat any zone with a character you will get a cutscene (don't worry you can skip it)."But why did you say 2 more characters  that push story  ?" Because you will have 6 differeant characters that do not push story and are there to make this game even longer!Gameplay feels slick and nice with amazing songs (3 differeant song packs {normal, kind-of-disco and metal one} + a beat analizer so you can adapt your own songs to the game).  Game is quite well balanced and only issue that i have is bosses at end of zones are too easy (excluding "main" ones). Local Co-Op is sweet, game has controller support and achievment system.What could i say more? 10/10

It's worth playing, though I don't know if I'd pay full price for it.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												A respectable roguelike that does more things correctly than most of what's out there.  The basic gameplay of fighting to the beat isn't particularly interesting to me, mostly because of how much it tends to slow things down.  You can opt for a faster tempo of course, but I just prefer to have control over when I move, and not be forced to move just so I don't lose a multiplier.  And they let you do that, thankfully.  It's worth playing, though I don't know if I'd pay full price for it.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												I've been playing this game a lot again lately and i've changed my mind. I'm gonna copy some of my old review in this. (The old review was done when I was called "Hostile Elder Oak")Crypt of the Necrodancer is an amazing game. You just gotta play it a lot to understand.Yeah, I DID edit the files to unlock the level editor but i'm not skilled enough to beat the game. *gasp*It's a unique game. When was the last time you saw a rhythm based dungeon crawler? The closest thing I can think of is "Patapon" for the PSP but it's not a dungeon crawler or top-down. Look it up.You can even put in your own .mp3 or .ogg files for the music. There's a lot of different playable characters, 4 different dungeon types, a level editor, a load of items, lots of enemies, etc.You can even add your own music (and play to the beat of the song).One bad thing is that it's random so you could find a really cool weapon in one run, nothing good in another.Apart from that, I DO recommend this game.That's if you can play it...---------------------------------------------    ORIGINAL (negative) REVIEW:---------------------------------------------As much as I enjoy this game (sometimes), I can't recommend it, unless you like overly hard, unforgiving games, then go ahead.I'll start with the good things. It's a unique game. When was the last time you saw a rhythm based dungeon crawler? The closest thing I can think of is "Patapon" for the PSP but it's not a dungeon crawler or top-down. Look it up.You can even put in your own .mp3 or .ogg files for the music. There's a lot of different playable characters, 4 different dungeon types, a level editor, a load of items, lots of enemies, etc.Now the bad things.Just like Magicite or The Binding of Isaac, The game is pretty much based on luck. Roll a 6 and you win. Roll any other number, you lose. You need to be good at enemy pattern remembrance, have a good eye, be good with music and hope you get good items. Most of the game for me consisted of getting far and then dying some sort of cheap death you couldn't avoid, which isn't fun. It doesn't help that some enemies move randomly. Zone 4 didn't even feel like part of the game.When I said about the load of playable characters, most of them I have are useless.The Monk can get any shop item for free but dies instantly by touching gold, which is a lot harder than it sounds.The Dove (I think) Can't attack. Come on, really?And the level editor? You have to beat the game. Do you really think I would do that?So, should you get it?I would say no. Even if you really want it, I thought the same thing.I'm not saying that the game is badly made or anything. It's actually really well made.

												I refrained for a while from buying this because it didn't convince me that much. I bought it when it was on sale and with about 2 hours played I must say I don't regret one bit buying this.Following the rythm isn't as hard as I personally thought, although it can be sometimes difficult.Each enemy has its own movement patterns, HP and damage they do to you. Fortunately there is a Trainer you can unlock where you can practice with every enemy individually in what I consider a very well done system.The game overall is really fun to play. Very extense on content and secrets, and of course, very challenging. (Also, shoopkeeper singing the level song along the rythm is a plus).Right now I can say I'm in love with this game, and I can't wait to get better at it and keep progressing.

content:
Posted: March 21
												Definitely one of the few rogue-likes I can enjoy! Success is built much more on skill than item drop luck, like in other rogue-likes.Also you don't drop that deep when you die. A "level-accomplished-checkpoint" is every 3 levels after a boss. It gets quite difficult though. There is a constant learning curve to be mastered since the btw awesome music speeds up the pace and the monsters become more dangerous with better abilities. The good thing is, that there is a way to deal with them all. There is no imbalanced uber enemy you cannot counter. You just have to be quick and stick to the beat ;-)Extremely recommended if you like rogue-likes, rythm games, pixel graphics and dungeoneering.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
 This review has been edited from negative to positive. I had initially given this game a negative review (that I've left completely unedited and can be found at the bottom of this review should you choose to read my first thoughts on the game). Thanks to the developers response, I've been able to see the game in a different light. As such, I'm completely revising my review. But if you don't feel like reading all I have to say, the short version of this review is as follows in a conveniently bulleted list: Amazing soundtracks; can choose to play along with the default music, techno remixed music or metal music Fast-paced gameplay that requires patience and quick strategy Controlled entirely with the four directional arrow keys (and enter key for the pause menu) Extreme but fair difficulty; master enemy patterns and you've mastered the game Play with mods from the Steam Workshop Lots of things to unlock Encouraging developer who provided helpful insight in the face of negativity (It means a lot to me) The current positive review Crypt of the Necrodancer is what it looks like; a rhythm-based dungeon crawler. You move to the beat of the music, and the controls are simply the 4 arrow keys; up, down, left, right. Combat is as simple as moving next to an enemy and attempting to move onto the square they occupy to damage the enemy. Sounds simple on paper, but each enemy has a pattern, and I know very well from experience now that if you just try to attack each enemy head-on, you will die many humiliating deaths. Learning how to traverse the map and defeat enemies without getting hit is key to survival, as health restoration items seldom appear.There are practice modes so you can master the enemy patterns, but practice against minibosses and boss fights are locked. However, there are detailed video guides as to how to defeat each boss (and enemy) should you be unable to collect the diamonds to unlock the practice mode(s). Regarding diamonds, one of the nicest features I've found in the game is that the game will warn you if you have diamonds left to spend on upgrades should you attempt to play again (as your diamond count is reset to 0 each attempt). This warning can be disabled, but because it's there, you can maximize on the rewards you've earned to get very much-needed upgrades. These upgrades include (but are not limited to) more base health and different items appearing in chests that would otherwise need to be bought from the shopkeeper mid-dungeon.In conclusion, this game is hard. There's no getting around that; statistically (as of writing this review), only 6.7% of players have completed the game under normal conditions. It may seem like it's impossibly hard (as I initially thought) at first, but this isn't the kind of game you can pick up and master in an instant. It's a game that requires time and practice to be good at. Just like anything in life. In that sense, it exits one's comfort zone of going into a game with skills learned from other games that can be applied. As such, this game is unique and brings something new to the table; a gameplay experience I can't get from playing other games. The old negative review Crypt of the Necrodancer is a fantastic game; the rhythm element is excellently implemented and functions perfectly for me. The music is great and catchy, and the game as a whole gives a new twist on roguelike dungeon crawlers. The steam workshop compatability gives endless possibilities as to gameplay creativity.However, I can't recommend this game because it's egregiously difficult to the point of becoming nearly unplayable. It took me almost my first hour of gameplay just to get past zone 1. As of writing this review, I can't get past zone 2-2 (if I can even make it that far), and after reading many other reviews, it doesn't seem like it will get much better. There are many games that are extremely difficult yet still enjoyable to play after losing; Crypt of the Necrodancer is not one of those games. Incessant game overs are disheartening to say the least, and rather than encourage me to try again, this game encourages me to play something else.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												TL;DR: 9/10. They did almost everything right. Mostly boils down to how experienced you're willing to get, because it's tricky to get used to.Crypt of the NecroDancer is about shanking monsters to a kickass beat. The game stars a girl named Cadence whose entire character, backstory and development can be summarised by "a girl named Cadence". It is very much centered around the gameplay and music working together, which works super well in a pretty flexible way compared to other rhythm-based games. The introduction is short and doesn't add much to the game other than justifying the mechanics, so you'll pretty much have the same experience regardless.The game takes 'turn-based' in a slightly different way. Each beat of the song is represented at the bottom of the screen and symbolises a turn each. If you miss a beat or do something you're not supposed to such as walk into a wall of stone, every enemy still gets a turn while you're standing there hoping nobody noticed that your pants just fell down. Each time you miss a beat, your current combo is broken, meaning you don't have any time to stop and read useful information as even standing still will bring it to a screeching halt.Combo, you say?Why yes indeed, a combo.Maintaining the combo gives a boost to the amount of gold you pick up. Items that you pick up such as weapons or rings may give additional boosts to people who haven't accidentally thrown their flimsy shovel into a solid wall or stood around stroking themselves for too long unless they're a Monk, who for whatever reason is allowed to stroke himself for as long as he likes, which pretty much defeats the entire premise of the game.Comparing two items is a pain, as stopping to read the item's description will cause you to lose your combo, meaning you have to do a god damn raindance around the item just to read the stats and figure out if it's going to increase your chance of winning by 0.3%.The ENTIRE game can be controlled using only 4 buttons/keys, which is about as convenient as an enemy who you can't actually hit with default gear because it won't line up next to you. I'm looking at you, golden slime. Sure, it's an interesting mechanic, but its main flaw is replacing memorising which key to press with memorising which combination of the same keys to press. It does show appropriate key combinations beside relevant items, but stopping to read it in the middle of a room more undead than a haunted mass grave is usually not worth the time. Guessing which combination is hardly worth the risk; you may be trying to heal in the middle of battle and end up throwing your sword across the room.Using your own (or someone else's) music instead of the original game's works pretty decently in terms of functionality, although the soundtrack is good enough that you wouldn't want to replace any of it in the first place.Local multiplayer is an interesting feature, although playing it with a first-timer was akin to participating in a three-legged race with a monkey who has bricks for feet. Unless you're both relatively similarly experienced, one of you is going to drag the other behind. Well I wouldn't say drag behind as much as them stumbling about while you're already buying everything from the shop with a stack of gold, which for this game was about as fun as letting a monkey with bricks for feet kick you in the shins after you finished the race without him, because now neither of you are having much fun at all.And that was after they went through incredibly short tutorial. Sure, it taught the basics, but you only really got to do everything in the tutorial once before it was over and it was clear that it didn't adequately equip a person with the experience they needed to survive unsupervised inside a padded room.If someone wants to play for the first time on your copy of the game, let them play singeplayer first.Overall decent game. Can't say much about price because I almost exclusively buy games when they're on sale.
